Essentials of Skeletal Radiology
3rd Edition
←↑→
6
Diagnostic Imaging of the Musculoskeletal System
Terry R. Yochum
Norman W. Kettner
Michael S. Barry
Melanie D. Osterhouse
Robert J. Longenecker
Claude Pierre-Jerome
Lindsay J. Rowe
MAGNETIC RESONANCE IMAGING
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) phenomenon was first described in the United States by two groups of physicists working independently. Felix Bloch et al. (1) from Stanford and Edward Purcell et al. (2) from Harvard developed a method of analyzing chemical compounds and providing their structural composition. They were jointly awarded the Nobel Prize for physics in 1952 for their early work on this new technology, which they termed NMR spectroscopy. (3)
In 1971, Damadian (4) reported on the capability of NMR spectroscopy to differentiate between healthy and cancerous tissues. Moon and Richards (5) applied NMR spectroscopy to living systems in 1973 while studying individual metabolites of intact red blood cells. That same year Lauterbur (6) developed and produced the first NMR image using thin-walled capillary tubes of water and deuterium oxide (D2O; heavy water). In 1976, Damadian et al. (7) produced the first NMR image of a live animal (a mouse with a surgically implanted chest neoplasm). The following year these workers published the first human image, depicting a crude representation of the thorax at the T8 level. (8) (Fig. 6-1) These images sparked enough interest in the new technology that numerous investigators began working on methods to improve image quality and diminish the overall time necessary to obtain the data to create the image. In 1980, Moore and Hinshaw produced the first recognizable images of the human brain. (3)
Eventually the name of this new technology was forced to change because of the negative connotation associated with the term nuclear. By the mid-1980s, nuclear magnetic resonance imaging became magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). MRI has rapidly gained favor with physicians and patients alike because of its non-invasive nature and lack of ionizing radiation or other harmful biologic effects.
The discovery and development of MRI are the most significant milestones in medical imaging since Roentgen’s discovery
P.486

of x-rays in 1895. MRI, like CT, is capable of providing an axial demonstration of human anatomy, but without ionizing radiation. The soft tissue contrast and spatial resolution also exceed that which is provided by CT. MRI has multiplanar capabilities, enabling anatomic information to be extracted in virtually any orientation without altering the patient’s position within the scanner. Like nuclear scintigraphy, MRI is capable of obtaining physiologic data, but without the radiation dose associated with radiopharmaceutical use. Because of the aforementioned attributes, MRI has quickly gained worldwide acceptance in the medical imaging community.
Figure 6-1 EARLY NMR TECHNOLOGY. A. The First NMR Scanner for Humans. Left to right: R. Damadian, L. Minkhoff, M. Goldsmith. This historic scanner was named Indominable. B. The First NMR Image of a Human. This is an axial image through the chest at the level of T8. The heart (arrow) is seen centrally within the chest cavity. The image was obtained in 1977 with the scanner depicted in panel A. COMMENT: This historic crude image began the cascade of events that led to the development of magnetic resonance technology. (Panel A reprinted with permission from Partain CL, Price RR, Patton JA, et al., eds: Magnetic Resonance Imaging. Philadelphia, WB Saunders, 1988.)
Originally, MRI was used to demonstrate the central nervous system (CNS). Although its clinical applications for the extremities were not initially envisioned, they have now been realized. Numerous applications exist for the evaluation of a wide variety of disorders, including vascular analysis using magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) and the imaging of disorders of the chest and abdomen. In 1982, approximately a dozen magnetic resonance scanners were in use worldwide. Today, several thousand MRI systems are operating in the United States. (9) This section briefly discusses the physics of image production, contraindications for use, and common musculoskeletal applications of MRI.
Glossary
cardiac gating
The method used to diminish the artifact produced by pulsatile vascular flow. The pulse sequence used to obtain the magnetic resonance image is synchronized with the patient’s heart rate and images are continually obtained through only the diastole phase of the cardiac cycle.
echo time (TE)
The time interval from the 90° radiofrequency pulse and echo detection (measured in milliseconds).
fast spin-echo (FSE)
A pulse sequence that uses multiple echoes per repetition time (TR) to obtain the data necessary for image formation. In contrast, conventional spin-echo sequences use only a single echo per TR. The benefits of this newer, fast magnetic resonance technique include reduced examination time, increased spatial resolution, and versatility in neuroimaging; in particular, superb myelographic images of the spine may be obtained. (10)
fat suppression
An imaging technique that suppresses the signal derived from fat, thereby making small areas of pathologic change (which are often seen as areas of high signal because of their fluid content) more evident and increasing the overall sensitivity of the examination. This is usually accomplished through the use of inversion recovery techniques such as short tau inversion recovery (STIR) or chemical saturation (fat sat) sequences.
field of view (FOV)
Represents the size of the image and plays an integral part in determining the overall spatial resolution of the final image. Generally, the smaller the field of view, the greater the spatial resolution.
flip angle
The angular deflection a hydrogen proton experiences when the radiofrequency pulse is applied. Spin-echo techniques displace the nuclear axis of rotation 90° from its equilibrium orientation ( parallel or antiparallel) within the magnetic field.
free induction decay
The loss of energy experienced by an excited proton after a 90° radiofrequency pulse. (11) The proton decays to its equilibrium (low-energy) state in an exponential fashion.
gradient-echo pulsed sequences
A generic term used to describe fast MRI using short repetition time and short echo time parameters. This technique differs from T1-weighted spin-echo sequences in that the radiofrequency pulses (flip angles) are < 90°. This essentially provides a T2-weighted image in less time. Major disadvantages include the susceptibility to artifacts and the poor demonstration of bone marrow.
P.487

Terms used to describe this type of imaging vary according to the manufacturer and include T2*-weighted, gradient recalled echo (GRE), gradient recalled acquisition in the steady state (GRASS), fast low-angle shot (FLASH), fast imaging with steady-state procession (FISP), multiplanar GRASS (MPGR), and spoiled GRASS (SPGR).
hyperintense
Relatively increased signal intensity; areas of high signal intensity are bright on MRI studies.
hypointense
Relatively decreased signal intensity; areas of low signal intensity are dark gray or black on MRI studies.
isointense
Relatively equal in signal intensity.
Larmor frequency
The frequency of precession for a given proton. This frequency varies with the applied magnetic field but is unique for each different type of proton within a given field (i.e., all hydrogen ions in a given magnetic field precess at roughly the same Larmor frequency).
phase contrast
A principle of MRA that is based on phase differences occurring among protons moving through magnetic gradients and stationary protons. The result is that the velocity of blood flow determines the signal intensity; velocities < 80 cm /sec are low signal. Vessel diameter can also be assessed; therefore, flow can be determined by phase contrast.
precession
The rotational motion a given proton experiences as it wobbles about the axis of an external magnetic field. This phenomenon is similar to the motion displayed by a spinning gyroscope or top, relative to the earth’s rotational motion.
proton density weighted
A long repetition time and short echo time MRI technique. The resultant image is unique in that it provides good anatomic detail and has mixed properties of both T1 and T2 relaxation times. This pulse sequence derives its information based on the relative concentrations of water (hydrogen) in the tissue.
radiofrequency (RF) pulse
An applied radiofrequency that is used to change the orientation of the magnetic axes of the hydrogen protons from an equilibrium state to an excited state. The RF is specific for each proton species within a given magnetic field, as defined by the Larmor equation (i.e., Larmor frequency). These pulses are generally described in terms of 90° or 180° pulses.
relaxation time
Following an RF pulse, the excited hydrogen protons return to their equilibrium ( pre-excitation) state within the magnetic field. The time interval that is necessary for this process is known as the relaxation time and incorporates two different relaxation methods that occur simultaneously.
  • T1 (spin-lattice) relaxation time. The time interval required for 63% of the hydrogen protons to re-establish their equilibrium through transfer of energy to the environment (lattice).
  • T2 (spin-spin) relaxation time. The time interval required for 63% of the hydrogen protons to re-establish their equilibrium by energy transfer between protons precessing at slightly different frequencies.
  • T2* relaxation time. The time interval necessary for free induction decay to occur. This results from protons within the tissue sample precessing incoherently because of magnetic field inhomogeneity. (11)
repetition time (TR)
The time between 90° radiofrequency pulses (measured in milliseconds).
signal
A function of the hydrogen proton characteristics and type of pulse sequence chosen. The information obtained from a tissue sample is often described in terms of its signal or signal intensity. Low signal tissues are hypointense and high signal tissues are hyperintense.
signal to noise ratio (SNR)
The amount of usable signal received compared with the noise present within the system at a given voltage. Generally, increased SNRs are achieved with higher-strength magnets and through the use of surface coils. The higher the SNR, the greater the overall image resolution.
signal void
The lack of signal originating from a structure or component of a structure. This appears as a black area on MRI studies.
spin-echo sequences
  • T1-weighted. Pulse sequence that uses short repetition time and short echo time parameters to produce an image that emphasizes T1 relaxation effects and provides superior anatomic detail. This imaging technique produces essentially a fat image in which structures containing fat (e.g., bone marrow, subcutaneous fat) appear bright. Proteinaceous material does likewise. Structures containing water (e.g., edema, neoplasm, inflammation, cerebrospinal fluid, large amounts of iron) appear dark. The substances that appear bright on the T1-weighted image shorten the T1 relaxation effects, whereas those that appear dark on T1-weighted images lengthen the T1 relaxation effects.
  • T2-weighted first echo. Also known as a proton density-weighted image.
  • T2-weighted second echo. Pulse sequence that uses long repetition time and long echo time parameters. This produces a water image in which substances that contain predominantly free or loosely bound water molecules (e.g., neoplasms, edema, inflammation, healthy nucleus pulposus, cerebrospinal fluid) appear bright, whereas substances with tightly bound water (e.g., ligaments, menisci, tendons, calcification, sclerosis) or large amounts of iron appear dark. The hyperintensity of the cerebrospinal fluid relative to the spinal cord and nerve roots is known as the myelographic effect. Fat is also relatively hyperintense on T2-weighted sequences but is not as bright as water.
surface coils
Small coils designed to image a small region of interest (field of view). A smaller field of view provides greater contrast resolution. There is an inverse relationship between the coil diameter and the signal to noise ratio. (12) Numerous types of surface coils exist, varying with the size and shape of the body part to be imaged and with the manufacturer.
three-dimensional (3D) images
Images obtained from a volume of data acquired through a specific anatomic area that can be manipulated (reformatted) into any imaging plane. Coupled with this technique’s ability to produce contiguous thin slices (≤1), 3D MRI studies are ideal for imaging small structures of the knee, wrist, and ankle.
time of flight
MRA contrast (flow-related enhancement) is created by the difference in spins of blood flowing into a slice compared with stationary spins in the surrounding perivascular tissue. Flowing blood has unsaturated spins, whereas perivascular tissue spins are made saturated (no more magnetization). The signal from the stationary tissue is suppressed by multiple gradient radiofrequency pulses with short repetition time and short echo time. Flowing blood responds differently to the multiple radiofrequency pulses and presents a high signal.
P.488

TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
The largest and most costly component of the MRI system is the magnet. Three types of magnets exist: resistive (electromagnetic), permanent, and superconductive. The most frequently employed system today uses superconducting magnets. These magnets are made up of metallic alloys that are maintained at a temperature near absolute zero through the use of liquid cryogens (helium and nitrogen). (1) This process is known as supercooling, and the supercooled electromagnets are known as superconducting magnets.
Magnetic strength is measured in tesla (T) or gauss (1 T = 10,000 G). The magnetic strength of a 1.5-T (15,000-G) magnet is ~ 25,000 times greater than the earth’s magnetic attraction. (2) Five general categories of magnetic field strength are commercially available. The ultra-high-field systems operate at > 4 T. High-field systems range from 1.5 to 4 T; medium-field magnets range from 0.5 to 1 T; low-field magnets range from 0.1 to 0.5 T; and ultra-low-field magnets are generally < 0.1 T. Trucks transport mobile MRI scanners to rural communities and are limited in the size of the magnet they can contain. Most trucks can accommodate magnet sizes only up to 0.5 T.
The larger the strength of the magnet, the greater the signal to noise (SNR) capabilities. When MRI was in its infancy, this translated into a better image. Currently, with updated software and the advent of surface and quadrature coils, some less powerful magnets are capable of producing excellent image quality. In fact, many 0.5 T systems with newer software packages that optimize the available SNR may yield better images than 1.5 T systems with outdated (inefficient) software.
The magnet is housed in a gantry. (Fig. 6-2) Patients are placed on the couch and moved longitudinally in and out of the magnet for spinal examinations. Once inside the magnet, the couch (and patient) are stationary during the entire examination. When surface coils are employed, the patient usually remains outside the gantry.
Figure 6-2 MRI SCANNER GANTRY. This device resembles a CT gantry but is much longer. The bore (center) of the gantry is usually smaller than that of a CT scanner. Note the device within the center of the gantry (arrow), which is used to image the head and neck. The couch is similar to a CT scanner couch in that it moves longitudinally into and out of the center of the gantry. The couch and patient, however, are stationary during the entire examination.
IMAGE GENERATION
Principles of Signal Production
The magnetic resonance image is the end product of an extremely complex process that involves the interaction of hydrogen protons with an external magnetic field. This section provides a brief overview of the process; an in-depth discussion of the physics behind MRI is beyond the scope of this text.
The paramagnetic properties and abundance of the hydrogen proton make it the ideal basis for MRI of living tissue. Only those atomic nuclei with odd numbers of protons or neutrons have the potential to be manipulated (imaged) with MRI. The unbalanced proton in the hydrogen nucleus causes this atom to have an intrinsic charge. Combined with the inherent spinning movement (angular momentum) of the nucleus, this charge provides the paramagnetic properties necessary for magnetic resonance imaging. Charge and spin cause the hydrogen proton to behave as a magnetic dipole, with positively (north) and negatively (south) charged poles.
Normally, protons in the human body are in random orientation. When an external magnetic field is applied, the protons align themselves in either a parallel or antiparallel orientation relative to the magnetic field. This produces a small net magnetization because a slight majority of the protons align with the applied magnetic field (parallel orientation). These protons, however, are not arranged in a static orientation but are in constant motion. Each proton spins along its vertical axis. As it is spinning, it also wobbles slightly around the axis of the external magnetic field. (Fig. 6-3) This motion is analogous to a gyroscope or spinning top in relation to the earth’s axis of rotation and is known as precession. Precession is specific for each atomic species in a given magnetic field and occurs at a frequency known as the Larmor frequency. It results from the inherent electromagnetic characteristics of the examined proton sample and the strength of the magnetic field.
The magnetic field of a magnetic resonance scanner is generally oriented longitudinally with respect to the position the patient will assume (i.e., the patient will lie in the north-south axis of the field). When a patient is placed in the magnetic field, the spinning hydrogen protons in the patient’s tissue align their magnetic axes in either a parallel (north magnetic pole of proton toward north magnetic pole of scanner) or antiparallel (north of proton toward south of scanner) orientation. Slightly more protons will assume the parallel state because this is a lower energy state. As the protons orient themselves about this longitudinal axis, they simultaneously spin about their own magnetic axis while precessing about the longitudinal axis of the magnetic field. When a pulse of radiofrequency energy (RF pulse) that matches the Larmor frequency of the protons is applied at a 90° angle to the magnetic field, the hydrogen protons resonate and absorb the energy of the RF pulse. This causes the protons to become misaligned relative to the magnetic field of the scanner. By carefully controlling the RF pulse, the proton orientation can be made to assume a specific angle of misalignment, usually 90° or 180°. When the RF signal is turned off, the protons realign themselves with the longitudinal axis. (Fig. 6-4) Energy is released during this process and is expressed as an RF signal.
P.489

Figure 6-3 PRECESSION. The dynamic nature of a proton under the influence of an external magnetic field is demonstrated. The orientation of the external magnetic field (B0) is noted. The proton continually spins about its axis (A) as it wobbles, or precesses, around the axis of the magnetic field. This creates a magnetic moment that parallels the orientation of the proton’s axis. COMMENT: This motion is analogous to the spinning of a top relative to the earth’s constant rotation.
In a uniform magnetic field, all atoms of a given species will produce a signal of similar frequency. The magnetic resonance scanner, however, generates a gradient magnetic field, which causes the RF signal from the protons to be specifically altered according to their location within the field. (1) This protongenerated RF signal, which is slightly different for each area within the scanner, is received and processed by computer to generate the actual image.
In spin-echo sequences, the RF pulses are repeated several times. First a 90° pulse is applied, followed by a 180° pulse. The same process is then repeated, starting with a new 90° pulse. The interval between the two 90° pulses is called the repetition time (TR). The time between the pulse and the detection of the magnetic resonance signal is known as the echo time (TE). (Fig. 6-5) It is the manipulation of these two parameters that is responsible for producing the image characteristics.
When the TR and TE are properly selected, the image will display contrast related to differences in proton density, T1 and T2 relaxation times. T1 (spin-lattice) and T2 (spin-spin) relaxation occur simultaneously, and the contributions of each of these parameters can be customized to offer a predominantly T1 relaxation (T1-weighted) or T2 relaxation (T2-weighted) image. If the TR and TE are selected so that the effects of both the T1 and T2 relaxation are minimized, the resulting pulse sequence is known as a proton density-weighted image.
T1-weighted images use short TR and short TE and provide excellent anatomic information. The resultant image is also known as the fat image. Fat is hyperintense (bright) and water (edema, intervertebral discs, cerebrospinal fluid) is hypointense (dark) with this pulse sequence. The T2-weighted image (long TR and long TE) is known as the water image because tissues containing mobile hydrogen protons (intervertebral discs, cerebrospinal fluid, and areas of edema) are hyperintense (bright). Proton density-weighted images (long TR and short TE) provide characteristics of both T1- and T2-weighted sequences.
Figure 6-4 PROTON DEFLECTION IN MRI. A. Random Proton Alignment. Without the influence of an external magnetic field, the randomly aligned protons are in constant motion, precessing around their individual axes of rotation. B. Proton Alignment under the Influence of a Strong Magnetic Field. The electromagnet housed within the MRI gantry exerts an external magnetic force, causing the alignment of the precessing hydrogen protons into parallel and antiparallel positions. A net magnetic moment is created by this alignment. C. Angular Deflection of the Hydrogen Proton. When a radiofrequency (RF) pulse is generated at the appropriate Larmor frequency, the atoms are excited to a higher energy state by altering their orientation relative to the external magnetic field. The angular deflection depends on the type of image being produced (e.g., spin-echo, gradient-echo). D. Proton Reorientation. When the RF pulse is removed, the coil detects the energy transferred from the realignment of protons to their equilibrium position (parallel or antiparallel). The signal received by the transmitter from the reorientation of the proton is what produces the image. COMMENT: This is a simplistic explanation of the complicated series of events that produce an MRI study.
After the initial 90° excitation pulse, the hydrogen protons rapidly decay from an excited (high-energy) state to equilibrium (low-energy state). This process is known as free induction decay
P.490

(FID) and occurs in a sinusoidal fashion. (Fig. 6-6) The time necessary for this process is the T2* relaxation time and is a function of the inhomogeneous magnetic field effect on the hydrogen protons in a given tissue sample. (2,3)
Figure 6-5 SIMPLIFIED MRI PULSE CYCLE. The interval between radiofrequency pulses is the repetition time (TR). Note there is also a radiofrequency signal that echoes from the patient. The time interval from the initial radiofrequency pulse to the signal generated from proton realignment is the echo time (TE).
Figure 6-6 FREE INDUCTION DECAY. Proton decay after a 90° radiofrequency pulse. The high-energy proton oscillates in a sinusoidal fashion and decreases in amplitude over time. This loss of energy (signal) occurs as the high-energy protons interact with incoherently spinning protons produced by the inhomogeneous magnetic field. COMMENT: The rate at which free induction decay occurs is designated the T2* relaxation time.
The effectiveness of a given MRI examination depends highly on the imaging parameters selected. (Fig. 6-7) This is a complex decision, and knowledge of magnetic resonance physics is necessary to choose the appropriate pulse sequences. Most imaging protocols for common disorders of the musculoskeletal system have been well documented in the radiologic literature. However, readers are encouraged to discuss the established protocols used by a particular facility before making a patient referral.
Numerous fast spin-echo and gradient-echo sequences have been developed, and there are many terms and acronyms used to describe these methods. (Table 6-1) Essentially, these techniques acquire imaging information with a reduced scan time. Three-dimensional (3D) volume acquisitions are useful in providing a thin-section evaluation of an anatomic area. This is particularly valuable when assessing minute structures in areas such as the knee, ankle, and wrist. Compared with conventional two-dimensional (2D) image acquisitions, which typically employ a 3- to 5-mm slice thickness, 3D acquisitions are capable of producing a slice thickness as small as 1 mm or less.
Figure 6-7 MRI CONTRAST FORMATION. A. Repetition Time = 2000 Msec. Note the marked contrast differences among tumor, muscle, and fat near the echo time (TE) of 100 msec. The combination of long repetition time (TR) and long TE defines a T2-weighted image, which emphasizes the relaxation characteristics between tumor and its surrounding tissues. B. Repetition Time = 500 msec. Note that large differences in the signal intensity of the tissues are seen at the short TE of 20 msec. COMMENT: These graphs demonstrate the effect of repetition time and echo time on tissue contrast. Both T1 and T2 relaxation occur simultaneously and are necessary for the complete evaluation of tumors and other pathology.
Paramagnetic and Ferromagnetic Substances
It is important to note that a large number of substances are influenced to a variable degree by the magnetic field. The degree
P.491

to which substances are affected is based on the composition and location of the material in question as well as on the strength of the magnetic field. Paramagnetic substances are weakly attracted toward the strongest region of the magnetic field and appear bright on T1-weighted images. Because of its paramagnetic properties, hydrogen is a fundamental part of MRI. Gadolinium (Gd) is a paramagnetic ion that is often used as part of a contrast-enhancing agent. It is attached to a chelating agent (diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid; DTPA) and is typically administered intravenously to aid in the detection or further evaluation of numerous pathologic conditions. Gd-DTPA is the most frequently used contrast agent for MRI. Its uses include the detection of occult CNS lesions; the evaluation of the vascularity, dimensions, and tissue characteristics of a known lesion; and the assessment of symptomatic postsurgical disc patients for recurrent disc herniation or scar formation. Unlike the iodinated contrast used with myelographic and CT examinations, this contrast agent has few reported adverse reactions.
Table 6-1 Common Acronyms for MRI Pulse Sequences

Pulse Sequence

Definition

Manufacturer

T1-weighted sequences

FLASH

Fast low-angle shot

Siemens, Bruker

SPGR

Spoiled gradient recalled imaging

General Electric

FFE

Fast field echo

Phillips

PSR

Partial saturation recovery

Picker

FE

Field echo

Elscint

Gradient sequences

GRASS

Gradient recalled acquisition in the steady state

General Electric

FISP

Fast imaging with steady-state precession

Siemens

FFE

Fast field echo

Phillips

PFI

Partial flip angle

Hitachi

T2-weighted sequences

CE-FAST

Contrast-enhanced Fourier acquired steady state

Picker

PSIF

Reversed FISP

Siemens

SSFP

Steady-state free precession

Toshiba, Shimadzu, General Electric
Ferromagnetic substances are strongly attracted toward the strongest region of the magnetic field. Most contraindications to MRI are related to the ferromagnetic properties of a foreign material. The ferromagnetic properties of a given substance depend to a great degree on the magnetic field strength. A list of ferromagnetic materials that are relative contraindications to MRI is provided later in this chapter.
Kinematic MRI
Kinematic MRI (kMRI) is a member of the growing family of MRI techniques known for the functional information that they provide. Time series of articular movement (kMRI) are now complemented by times series of functional, physiological, and behavioral information and can be obtained using the same scanner technology. Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is used to image vascular flow, diffusion MRI reveals disturbances of fluid restriction as seen in stroke, and magnetic resonance spectroscopy displays the spectral concentration of a range of biochemical metabolites. The most powerful application of these new magnetic resonance technologies is functional MRI (fMRI). It displays changes in oxygen concentration associated with neural activation to provide highresolution imaging of the brain and, in the future, of the spinal cord. For example, fMRI may display the underlying neuronal mechanisms related to cognitive, motor, or sensory function (4), possibly including the evaluation of the normal or abnormal neurocircuitry underlying acute or chronic pain states. fMRI is also used to evaluate therapeutic interventions such as acupuncture. (5,6)
MRI of the spine has traditionally been performed in a recumbent position. Recognition that the spinal column is subjected to the effects of gravity in positions other than recumbence has prompted the development of new techniques to extend the diagnostic power of MRI. (7) These exciting new applications include axial loading of the spine with compression devices and upright weight-bearing and dynamic kinematic MRI (Fig. 6-8). Preliminary evidence demonstrates that these techniques enhance the detection of clinically significant pathology or unmask occult articular pathology unrecognized by recumbent imaging. (Fig. 6-9) (8,9)
In patients with clinical suspicion of lumbar spinal stenosis, a significant decrease in the dimensions of the central canal and volume of the dural sac has been noted when CT and magnetic resonance examinations were performed with axial loading of the spine during slight extension. Therefore, it has been suggested that CT and magnetic resonance examinations should be performed with axial loading of the spine in patients with suspected lumbar spinal stenosis. (10)
Weight-bearing, or upright, MRI and kMRI with flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral bending of the spine has been compared to recumbent MRI (rMRI). Initial reports demonstrated exaggeration of disc bulges, disc protrusions, disc herniations, central canal stenosis, neural foraminal stenosis, and lateral recess stenosis. In some cases false-negative disc herniations on rMRI have been discovered during upright or kinematic MRI. (Fig. 6-10) Under optimal conditions a specific imaging abnormality may be correlated with a specific posture or kinematic maneuver that reproduces the clinical syndrome.
Jinkins’s group observed patterns of osseous and soft tissue change, including disc herniations, spinal stenosis of the central
P.492

canal and neural foramina, and hypermobile spinal instability, on upright weight-bearing ( positional MRI; pMRI) and kMRI compared with rMRI. (Figs. 6-11 and 6-12) They noted the following:
  • Postural sagittal lumbar and cervical lordotic curvature correction from straight or even reversed on rMRI to a more normal curve on pMRI.
  • Increased severity of focal posterior disc herniation on pMRI that was worsened on extension kMRI.
  • Reduction of intervertebral disc height at levels of disc degeneration on pMRI compared with rMRI.
  • Increased severity of central canal stenosis on neutral pMRI, which worsened on extension kMRI, compared with rMRI.
  • Increased foraminal stenosis on neutral pMRI, which worsened on extension, compared with rMRI.
  • Increased translational sagittal plane intersegmental hypermobility in degenerative disc disease and postoperative spinal instability were revealed by pMRI and kMRI. (8,11,12,13)
Figure 6-8 UPRIGHT MRI. Observe that the patient is flexed in the standing position. This allows an MRI scan to be performed not only with the patient upright but also in various positions of kinetic motion (flexion and extension) in the cervical or lumbar spine. This machine, which uses a 0.6-T magnet, also has the capacity to perform recumbent imaging. (Courtesy of Raymond Damadian, MD, Fonar Corporation, Melville, New York.)
Figure 6-9 POSTDISCECTOMY, 8-MONTH FOLLOW-UP. A. T2-Weighted, Recumbent MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note there is some alteration in signal intensity within the middle to posterior surface of the L5 disc. No evidence of recurrent disc herniation is revealed. B. T2-Weighted, Upright MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe the dramatic focal recurrent disc herniation with posterior displacement of the dural sac, which was not demonstrated on recumbent imaging. The circular area of low signal intensity represents disc material surrounded by epidural fibrosis (scar tissue). COMMENT: This 68-year-old male patient presented with a history of recurring low back and leg pain, which was worse on standing. If only a recumbent MRI scan was performed, the recurrent disc herniation would have been missed. (Courtesy of M. Rose, MD, Tampa, Florida, and Fonar Corporation, Melville, New York.)
P.493

Figure 6-10 HIDDEN CERVICAL SPINE DISC HERNIATION. A. Recumbent T2-Weighted MRI, Axial C4-C5 Level. Note the minor posterior spondylophyte formation (arrow). B. Upright T2-Weighted MRI, Axial C4-C5 Level. Observe the focal central disc herniation at C4-C5 (arrow) that was not seen on the recumbent scan. C. Upright Extension, T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Note the positionaldependent focal posterior disc herniation at the C4-C5 level, which was not appreciated on the recumbent scan. Focal disc herniation is also seen at the C5-C6 level, with significant compression of the thecal sac and spinal cord. COMMENT: The dynamic upright studies dramatically demonstrate a hidden disc herniation, which was not revealed on the recumbent scans. Weight-bearing studies allow the clinician to better evaluate any pathology and correlate it with the patient’s signs and symptoms. (Courtesy of Fonar Corporation, Melville, New York).
Figure 6-11 LUMBAR SPINE INSTABILITY. A. Recumbent T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the small disc herniation at the L3-L4 level with minimal anterolisthesis of L3 on L4. B. Sitting T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe the postoperative degenerative intersegmental hypermobility with significant anterior displacement of L3 on L4. This is associated with fluctuating spinal stenosis of the central spinal canal at L3-L4, which is the level immediately above the spinal fusion. COMMENT: This 46-year-old male patient had low back surgery and arthrodesis at the L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels 6 years before these studies were performed. The dramatic anterolisthesis, demonstrating radiographic instability, is seen only on the upright sitting scan. (Courtesy of M. Rose, MD, Tampa, Florida, and Fonar Corporation, Melville, New York.)
P.494

Recumbent MRI may be inadequate in patients with gravitydependent articular derangement. Axial loaded, upright weight-bearing, and kinematic MRI studies hold promise for increased sensitivity in the evaluation of the axial and appendicular joint system. In addition, there are significant clinical benefits to scanning a patient while he or she assumes a provocative position or maneuver along with the demonstration of occult articular disease that is gravity dependent.
Figure 6-12 LUMBAR SPINE INSTABILITY. A. Recumbent T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the minimal degenerative anterolisthesis of L4 on L5. B. Standing T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe that the L4 anterolisthesis is somewhat accentuated in the standing position. C. Standing Flexion, T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note that the L4 anterolisthesis is best demonstrated on the standing flexion study (arrow). COMMENT: This dramatic radiographic instability could not be fully appreciated on the recumbent examination. (Courtesy of Fonar Corporation, Melville, New York.)
P.495

Figure 6-13 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS IN PREGNANCY. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe the fetus in utero (arrow). The vertical striping through the gravid uterus is an artifact. B. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe the large disc herniation and posterior compression of the thecal sac (arrow). COMMENT: This 31-year-old gravid female presented with severe low back pain, intractable sciatica with leg atrophy, and loss of the Achilles reflex. The patient failed chiropractic treatment, and an MRI was performed in the 14th week of pregnancy. She underwent a successful discectomy during her 4th month of pregnancy. The child was born healthy and at 8 years old showed normal development. MRI during pregnancy is indicated only if alternative diagnostic modalities are inadequate or potentially harmful by virtue of ionizing radiation and the woman’s life is threatened. It is recommended that pregnant patients provide written informed consent before examination. (Courtesy of Marsha J. Carry, MS, DC, Manhattan Beach, California.)
CONTRAINDICATIONS
Contraindications to obtaining an MRI examination are based on several factors, and each individual circumstance should be evaluated before the denial of such an examination.
Large patients (> 300 lb) are often too big to fit into the bore of most scanners. Rectangular and open-architecture magnets permit scanning of these individuals. Claustrophobic patients may find that lying within the small gantry for 30-60 min can be a difficult experience. There is an approximate 5% rejection rate because of claustrophobia. Music transmitted through non-ferromagnetic headphones, prism glasses, and open-architecture magnets may reduce the effects of claustrophobia. Medications (such as Valium and Xanax) are sometimes used to sedate such individuals and may also be necessary to image infants and small children.
Contraindications to an MRI examination because of the ferromagnetism of a certain device depend on the magnet strength and the anatomic location of the device. Aneurysm clips (especially those near the circle of Willis), intraocular foreign bodies (commonly seen in welders), subcutaneous metal shards (found in sheet metal workers), and some shrapnel are frequent contraindications to an MRI examination. In addition, cardiac pacemakers or defibrillators, implanted neurostimulators (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation units), some prosthetic heart valves (especially mitral), cochlear implants or other hearing aids, tattooed eyeliner and certain other makeup, life-support equipment, and early (first trimester) pregnancy are also contraindications. (Fig. 6-13) Most surgical clips, including those from vasectomy, tubal ligation, vagotomy, lymph node resection, splenectomy, cholecystectomy, and sympathectomy, are not ferromagnetic and do not prevent MRI examination. Individual patient rejection criteria have been established by each MRI facility and should be stringently enforced.
Joint prostheses, Harrington rods, and most other orthopedic appliances are not contraindications for an MRI. With MRI, these devices produce a tolerable signal void rather than the offending metallic artifact produced by CT.
THE SPINE
Indications for MRI
The current list of indications for MRI of the spine is long and continues to expand. Magnetic resonance technology provides contrast and spatial resolution that are superior to CT and allows optimal visualization of the spinal cord, intervertebral discs, paravertebral musculature, ligaments, and vertebral marrow. (Table 6-2) The multiplanar capability of magnetic resonance, provided by standard spin-echo and 3D volume techniques, produces incomparable image quality over the axial and reformatted images
P.496

of CT. In addition, MRI is non-invasive and delivers no ionizing radiation to the patient.
Table 6-2 Relative Magnetic Resonance Signal Intensities: Basic Imaging Interpretation

Feature

T1 Weighted

T2 Weighted

Feature

T1 Weighted

T2 Weighted

Calcium

Very low

Very low

Postradiation

Cortical bone

Very low

Very low

Week 1

Moderately low

Mildly increased

Tendon

Low

Low

Weeks 2-3

Heterogeneous high

Heterogeneous

Ligament

Low

Low

> 3 weeks

Heterogeneous high

Isointense

Iron, hemosiderosis

Low

Low

Infarction

Fat

High

Isointense

Early

Low

High

Marrow

Late

Low with signal void rim

Low with signal void rim

Yellow

High

Isointense

Red

Low

Isointense

Inflammation (edema, Sudeck’s disease)

Low

High

Water

Low

High

Muscle

Isointense

Isointense

Trauma

Amyloidosis

Moderately low

Isointense

Bone bruise

Low

High

Gaucher’s disease

Low

Low

Occult fracture

Low

High

Aplastic anemia

Untreated

Homogeneous high

Infection

Polycythemia

Isointense

Figure 6-14 NORMAL SPIN-ECHO SEQUENCE MRI, SAGITTAL CERVICAL SPINE. A. T1-Weighted. Note the high signal originating from the vertebral bodies and spinal cord (arrow) secondary to their fatty (myelin) composition. The intervertebral discs are of intermediate signal intensity (arrowheads), and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is hypointense (crossed arrow). B. T2-Weighted. Note the relatively hypointense signal of the vertebral bodies and spinal cord (arrows). The intervertebral discs (arrowheads) are of intermediate to high signal intensity, and the CSF is quite hyperintense (crossed arrow).
P.497

MRI has replaced CT as the gold standard in the evaluation of cervical, thoracic, and lumbar disc disease. No other imaging modality defines the anatomic relationship of the intervertebral disc and the contents of the spinal canal as accurately as MRI. MRI is frequently employed in the evaluation of patients who have sustained trauma to the vertebral column or spinal cord. In particular, unparalleled evaluation of cord injury can be achieved with MRI, clearly depicting the exact location and extent of cord involvement. Other indications for MRI of the spine are congenital disorders, such as Arnold-Chiari malformation and syrinx. Evidence of early tumor infiltration of bone marrow may be observed with MRI much sooner than with CT or even bone scan. In addition, the late stages of metastasis and many primary bone neoplasms of the spine (benign and malignant) are better evaluated with MRI. Enhancement of cord tumor neovascularity with gadolinium further increases the rate of accurate, early detection. MRI coupled with intravenous contrast is also beneficial in the assessment of failed back syndrome, allowing differen-tiation of recurrent disc herniation from postsurgical epidural scar formation.
Imaging Protocols
Techniques
Generally, most MRI facilities have established specific protocols for routine spinal examinations. (Table 6-1)
MRI can be tailored to optimally image pathologic processes as they relate to specific spinal tissues. All spine sequences should be performed using a surface coil to reduce the field of view. Phased array surface coils with a 48-cm field of view allow long segments (multiple regions) of the spine to be imaged simultaneously. (1,2)
The standard sequences of the spine include spin-echo T1- and T2-weighted images. Other commonly used sequences are the gradient, proton density, and short tau inversion recovery (STIR). Gradient echo produces an enhanced “myelographic” effect of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Proton density improves anatomic detail, and STIR demonstrates subtle pathology-related edema. (Figs. 6-14, 6-15, 6-16, 6-17, 6-18 and 6-19)
Artifacts and Anti-Artifact Techniques.
The quality of a given MRI study of the spine can be degraded because of motion artifact originating from CSF pulsations, swallowing, peristalsis, and cardiac and respiratory motions. Therefore, it is necessary to add anti-artifact techniques to MRI protocols. When the thoracic spine is examined, for example, the use of presaturation pulses within the field of view suppresses motion artifacts originating from the heart, diaphragm, and abdominal structures. (3) Identical saturation techniques can be employed to minimize or eliminate the signal from flowing blood in major vessels adjacent to the spine. Pulsation artifacts produced by CSF can also affect the image quality. Cardiac gating and gradient moment nulling techniques diminish the effects these pulsations have on the overall image quality. (4,5,6)
Limited MRI Scan: A New Concept.
An abbreviated scan is indicated for acute trauma to visualize soft tissue injury and bone marrow edema caused by contusion. One source of bone marrow edema is acute spinal compression fracture. (Fig. 6-20) To visualize subtle edema in bone and soft tissue, a sagittal T2-weighted image with or without fat suppression is the most cost-effective sequence. MRI can differentiate, with better certainty than plain film, acute versus remote (old) fracture.
Figure 6-15 NORMAL GRADIENT-ECHO SEQUENCE MRI, CERVICAL SPINE. A. Sagittal. B. Axial. Note that the marrowcontaining structures are low in signal intensity. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) (arrows) and intervertebral discs (arrowheads) are hyperintense because of their water content. C, spinal cord; B, vertebral body; S, spinous process. COMMENT: The hyperintense signal of the CSF contrasts with the intermediate signal intensity of the spinal cord, creating the myelographic effect. This soft tissue contrast enables disc lesions and other extradural pathology to be accurately defined.
Congenital Disorders
Tethered Cord Syndrome
The conus medullaris usually reaches the normal adult level of L1-L2 by approximately 2 months of age. In general, after 12 years of age the tip of the conus should not extend below the L2 level.
P.498

(7) The tethered cord is defined as an abnormally low position of the conus tip, below the level of the L2 vertebral body in adults. Lipomas and thickening of the filum terminale may be seen in conjunction with a tethered cord. (8) (Fig. 6-21) These focal collections of fat and connective tissue must be differentiated from epidural lipomatosis. Epidural lipomatosis may be seen in obese individuals but is most frequently seen in patients receiving exogenous corticosteroids. (9) (Fig. 6-22)
Figure 6-16 NORMAL MRI, SAGITTAL THORACIC SPINE. A. T1-Weighted. The intermediate to hyperintense signal of the vertebral bodies and spinal cord (arrows) occurs because of their fat content. The intervertebral discs (arrowheads) are of slightly lower signal intensity, whereas the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) (crossed arrows) is hypointense. The linear, high signal intensity area extending through the spinal cord and posterior vertebral margin of the T6 vertebral body is artifactual in nature. B. T2-Weighted. The intervertebral discs (arrowheads) are relatively hyperintense compared with the low signal intensity vertebral bodies. The spinal cord (arrows) is intermediate in signal intensity, whereas the surrounding CSF (crossed arrows) is quite hyperintense.
Figure 6-17 NORMAL MRI, SAGITTAL LUMBAR SPINE. A. T1-Weighted. B. T2-Weighted. Note the conus medullaris (arrows) is hyperintense on the T1-weighted image but has a lower signal on T2 weighting. Similar signal changes are seen in the traversing nerve roots of the cauda equina (arrowheads). The cerebrospinal fluid (crossed arrows) is dark or hypointense on the T1-weighted image and is hyperintense on T2-weighted images. Well-hydrated intervertebral discs (curved arrows) are of intermediate to low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and become hyperintense with T2 weighting. Vertebral fatty marrow is high in signal on T1 weighting and of intermediate to low signal intensity on T2 weighting.
Figure 6-18 NORMAL T1-WEIGHTED MRI, PARASAGITTAL FAR LATERAL SPINE. A. Lumbar Spine. Note the low signal intensity dorsal root ganglia (arrows) and radicular veins (arrowheads). The surrounding hyperintense fat provides the contrast necessary to delineate these structures and assess intraforaminal pathology. B. Thoracic Spine. Observe the low signal intensity dorsal root ganglia within the hyperintense intraforaminal fat (arrows).
P.499

Figure 6-19 NORMAL MRI, AXIAL LUMBAR SPINE. A. T1-Weighted, L5-S1 Level. Note that the S1 nerve root sheaths (arrows) contain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and therefore parallel the signal changes of the CSF within the thecal sac (*). Note also the right L5-S1 facet joint (arrowheads) and the spinous process (crossed arrow). B. T2-Weighted, L5-S1. Observe that the CSF (*) is quite hyperintense and provides the necessary contrast for visualizing the rootlets of the cauda equina (arrows). The psoas muscles (P) are seen lateral to the vertebral body. C. Proton Density-Weighted, L4-L5. Note that the CSF (*) is intermediate in signal and contrasts with the low signal intensity of the cauda equina. Observe also the extraforaminal portion of the left L4 nerve root (arrow), the psoas muscles (P), and facet joints (arrowheads). D. Normal Diagram, L4-L5 Level.
The clinical symptoms in tethered cord syndrome are thought to be related to mechanical factors and chronic repetitive cord ischemia. (10) Often a mass or dural adhesions may be implicated as the cause of the restricted cord ascent. This results in stretching of the distal cord and subsequent ischemia. The onset of symptoms usually occurs between the ages of 3 and 35 years. Most patients experience symptoms for the first time during the adolescent growth spurt (11), supporting the hypothesis that the onset of symptoms is related to the development of the lumbar lordosis and stretching of the distal cord. The most common complaint is gait difficulty, ranging from a sensation of leg stiffness to true weakness with hyperreflexia. Frequent findings include bladder dysfunction, sensory abnormalities, back pain, focal hypertrichosis, and congenital foot deformities. Occult tethered cord syndrome presents a diagnostic challenge because symptoms appear much later in life.
MRI Findings.
T1-weighted axial images are the best means for evaluating the tethered cord syndrome. (12,13) They allow for differentiation of the centrally positioned conus and filum terminale from the laterally arrayed nerve roots of the cauda equina. Sagittal images assist in locating the cauda equina and the tip of the conus medullaris. Lipomas are frequently seen in the caudal aspect of the thecal sac, attached to the filum. (Fig. 6-23) These fatty collections are best seen on T1-weighted axial and sagittal images. The key advantages of MRI over myelography and CT myelography (CTM) in the evaluation of tethered cord syndrome are its non-invasive nature, multiplanar capabilities, and ability to positively identify the cause of the condition in most cases.
P.500

Figure 6-20 ACUTE VERTEBRAL COMPRESSION FRACTURE. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Note the biconcave deformity of the T8 vertebral endplates. The increased marrow signal intensity adjacent to the T8 superior endplate (arrow) represents edema. These changes are consistent with an acute injury.
Figure 6-21 LIPOMA: TETHERED CORD. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the high signal intensity mass (arrow) with ventral deflection of a low terminating conus medullaris. These findings indicate a lipoma with an associated tethered cord. COMMENT: The conus medullaris normally terminates at the L1-L2 level. (Courtesy of Kenneth B. Reynard, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 6-22 EPIDURAL LIPOMATOSIS. T1-Weighted MRI, Thoracic Spine. A. Sagittal. B. Axial. Note the increased amount of high signal intensity fat within the posterior epidural space (arrows). Note the anterolateral displacement of the spinal cord and thecal sac. COMMENT: Epidural lipomatosis is usually idiopathic or the sequelae of prolonged cortico-steroid use causing redistribution of fat reserves. (Courtesy of William P. Yapp, DC, Green Cove Springs, Florida.)
P.501

Figure 6-23 LIPOMA: TETHERED CORD. T1-Weighted MRI, Lumbar Spine. A. Sagittal. B. Axial. Observe the low-lying position (L4) of the enlarged conus medullaris (arrow) in an ectatic thecal sac. The region of high signal intensity posterior to the conus (arrowheads) is an extradural lipoma, which extends dorsally through a neural arch defect (crossed arrow). COMMENT: The conus medullaris is normally located at the L1-L2 level.
Figure 6-24 DIASTEMATOMYELIA. T1-Weighted MRI, Lumbar Spine. A. Coronal. B. Axial. Observe the fibrous or osseous septum extending longitudinally through the tethered spinal cord (arrow). This septum divides the spinal cord into two symmetric hemicords (arrowheads). COMMENT: A fibrous or osseous spur increases cord tension and exacerbates the signs and symptoms of tethering. (Courtesy of Stephen J. Mattaga, DC, Burlington Township, New Jersey.)
P.502

Diastematomyelia
Diastematomyelia is a sagittal separation of the spinal cord into two hemicords. (Fig. 6-24) These hemicords are frequently separated by a fibrous or osseous bar that may progressively stretch the cord as the patient grows, producing neurologic symptoms in adolescent and adult patients. Sagittal MRI images are better than CT at demonstrating congenital anomalies of the cord (e.g., tethered cord, lipoma, Arnold-Chiari malformation, syrinx, cyst).
Scoliosis
The majority of scolioses are idiopathic in nature and respond favorably to conservative management. However, intraspinal abnormalities occur in 5-20% of the scolioses seen in children, providing an organic cause for the scoliosis and/or its progression. (14,15) These intraspinal abnormalities include Arnold-Chiari malformation, hemivertebra (structural scoliosis), hydrocephalus, syringomyelia and hydromyelia, spinal cord tumor, myelomeningocele, tethered cord syndrome, and diastematomyelia. (16)
Figure 6-25 LEFT-SIDED SCOLIOSIS: A WARNING FOR ALL. A. Initial Study, 10° Scoliosis, AP Thoracic Spine. B. 1-Year Follow-Up, 34° Scoliosis, AP Thoracic Spine. C. A Reminder of the Sinister Nature of the Left-Sided Curve. This 4-year-old girl presented with a 10° scoliosis that progressed to 34° in 1 year. Note that this is a left-sided scoliosis, the opposite of what is usually expected in classic idiopathic scoliosis. COMMENT: Patients presenting with left-sided scolioses (especially when rapidly progressive) should be thoroughly evaluated to exclude an underlying cause for the unusual curvature. Examination of this patient revealed an Arnold-Chiari type I malformation with syrinx. A posterior fossa decompression with installation of a syringoperitoneal shunt was performed, which allowed for decompression of the syrinx. The patient was then placed in a Boston brace, and the scoliosis was reduced to 24°. The curvature remained stable for 3 years after surgery. (Reprinted with permission from Yochum TR, Barry MS, Gould SJ, et al: Wrong sided scoliosis: When left isn’t right. JNMS 2:195, 1994.)
P.503

Scolioses may be asymptomatic or may result in symptoms ranging from mild back pain to severe back pain with loss of bladder function and lower extremity neurologic deficit. A comprehensive discussion on imaging and treatment of scoliosis is beyond the scope of this chapter, but a brief description of the features and clinical importance of left-sided scoliosis is provided.
Most idiopathic spinal curvatures are convex to the right. The finding of a left-sided scoliosis is worrisome and must be further evaluated, particularly if the curve is large or if rapid progression is observed. (Fig. 6-25) Coonrad et al. (17) reported that of 550 consecutive scoliosis patients, 1.6% (27 patients) had left curves of the thoracic or lumbar regions. Of those 27 patients, 9 had evidence of neurologic dysfunction. Of those, 2 patients had occult syringomyelia. Another study evaluated 18 patients with left thoracic or thoracolumbar scoliosis. Of these patients, 8 had abnormal MRI findings and 6 exhibited non-neoplastic syrinx formation. (18) Yochum et al. (19) reported two challenging cases that exemplify the vast contrast that may be observed in different patients with the same underlying abnormality. Both patients had a progressive left scoliosis secondary to syrinx formation. One case demonstrated neurologic deterioration, and the other was asymptomatic except for the progressive left curve and minimal back pain.
MRI is helpful in detecting syrinx formation and surgical planning as well as in postsurgical follow-up. Longitudinal evaluation of the spinal cord and base of the skull with MRI is critical in the assessment of a rapidly progressing scoliosis (whether it be leftor right-sided) in a child or adolescent. Even when a left-sided scoliosis is asymptomatic, MRI evaluation should be considered. Certainly MRI is indicated for all individuals presenting with severe or rapidly progressive scoliosis (especially a left-sided curve) and for those with neurological symptoms. A timely and accurate diagnosis is of utmost importance in preventing permanent cosmetic disfigurement and/or neurological impairment. Beware of the frequently sinister nature of left-sided curves and ensure that a complete evaluation of these patients is performed, including consideration for an MRI scan of the cervical and thoracic regions of the spinal cord. Table 6-3 provides a list of indications for performing an MRI examination in patients with scoliosis.
Table 6-3 Indications for MRI in Scoliosis Patients

Young patient (< 11 years of age)

Severe or rapidly progressing thoracic or thoracolumbar scoliosis ( particularly left-sided)

No family history of scoliosis

Unusually rigid scoliosis in a young patient

Scoliosis associated with pain that is unresponsive to conservative treatment

Abnormal radiographic findings

Segmentation defects

Platybasia

Basilar impression

Increased spinal canal diameter

Posterior vertebral body scalloping

Pedicle widening

Abnormal neurologic findings

Muscular weakness and/or atrophy

Sensory loss (particularly pain and temperature)

Bladder or bowel dysfunction

Unexplained or painless swollen joint (Charcot’s joint)

Abnormal deep tendon reflexes (increased or decreased)

Cranial nerve abnormality
Arnold-Chiari Malformation
Arnold-Chiari malformation is characterized by a caudal herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum and is often associated with various other abnormal neurological and skeletal findings. Four types have been described.
Type I.
The type I malformation is defined as a herniation of the cerebellar tonsils > 5 mm beyond the most caudal aspect of the foramen magnum. (20,21) (Fig. 6-26) This type of malformation is associated with hydrosyringomyelia (60 -70% of patients); hydrocephalus (20-25% of patients); and segmentation anomalies of the craniovertebral junction (24%), including basilar impression, upper cervical assimilation, and Klippel-Feil syndrome. (22) Arnold-Chiari type I malformations are often clinically asymptomatic (31%) but may present in adulthood with subtle symptoms. Radiographs are important in that they may reveal vertebral anomalies, suggesting an underlying spinal cord abnormality.
Type II.
The most commonly occurring Arnold-Chiari malformation (representing approximately 40% of all such malformations) is the type II variety. (20) This type also involves caudal
P.504

displacement of the cerebellar tonsils. In addition, deformity of the calvaria and displacement of the fourth ventricle and brainstem are seen. Midline cleft defects in the cervical neural arches and myelomeningocele are often associated with this type of malformation.
Figure 6-26 ARNOLD-CHIARI I MALFORMATION WITH SYRINX. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Observe the ectopic cerebellar tonsils projecting caudally to the C1 level (arrow) and the uniformly low signal intensity syrinx that enlarges the entire cervical spinal cord (arrowhead). Note that the borders of the syrinx are well defined. Also note the unrelated changes of degenerative spondylosis at C5-C6 (crossed arrow). COMMENT: MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality to determine the presence of Arnold-Chiari malformations with or without syrinx. It provides a non-invasive means of obtaining this diagnosis.
Figure 6-27 ARNOLD-CHIARI TYPE I MALFORMATION WITH A HOLOCORD SYRINX. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Cervical Spine. Note the caudal displacement of the cerebellar tonsils several millimeters below the foramen magnum (arrow). Observe the large size of the spinal cord (arrowheads) secondary to the huge central canal (*). Note the low signal intensity of the central canal, which contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The cephalad portion of the syrinx extends to the C1-C2 level. C. Gradient-Echo MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Note that the low signal intensity CSF becomes hyperintense on this pulse sequence. The thin margins of the spinal cord are obscured by the large amount of CSF within the syrinx. D. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Note the caudal extent of the syrinx terminates in the conus medullaris (arrow). COMMENT: This 25-year-old male patient presented with cervical spine pain in extension. A neurological examination revealed a unilateral decreased pinwheel sensation on the right in a shawllike distribution. (Courtesy of Mark L. Taylor, DC, Las Vegas, Nevada.)
P.505

Types III and IV.
Types III and IV Arnold-Chiari malformations are rare and exhibit a combination of findings demonstrated in the type I and type II varieties. All types of Arnold-Chiari malformations may be associated with syrinx, progressive hydrocephalus, and scoliosis. (20) A more complete discussion of Arnold-Chiari malformation is presented in Chapter 3.
Syrinx
The term syrinx encompasses syringomyelia, hydromyelia, and syringohydromyelia and is used if the exact location of the cavity within the spinal cord is unknown. Syringomyelia is defined as an eccentrically placed cavity within the parenchyma of the spinal cord. This cavity is lined with altered glial elements and contains CSF. These cavities may be unilocular or septated. Pressure on the medial nuclei innervating the trunk musculature has been suggested as a mechanism for the association of scoliosis with syrinx formation. (23) Elster and Chen (22) detected syringomyelia in 40% of patients with Arnold-Chiari type I malformations.
MRI is the definitive imaging modality for detecting a syrinx and is recommended for young adults and adolescents with rapidly progressive scoliosis or for evaluation of any progressive left-sided spinal curve. A syrinx is best demonstrated on axial and sagittal T1-weighted images, on which the low signal intensity CSF creates a black column relative to the surrounding high signal intensity spinal cord parenchyma. (Fig. 6-27)
Figure 6-28 IDIOPATHIC DURAL ECTASIA. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the erosion of the posterior sacral body and neural arch (arrows) resulting in enlargement of the sacral spinal canal. The eroded margins are smooth, suggesting an indolent process. B. T2-Weighted MRI, Axial Sacrum. C. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the high signal intensity cerebrospinal fluid within the ectatic thecal sac (arrows) and sacral canal enlargement. (Courtesy of Patricia A. Youmans, DC, Colorado Springs, Colorado.)
Perineural Sacral (Tarlov’s) Cyst
The terminology used in describing perineural sacral cysts, which are meningeal cyst-like structures, is quite confusing. Other terms used include meningeal cyst, Tarlov’s cyst, spinal nerve root perineural cyst, meningeal diverticula, and occult intrasacral meningocele. (24) These lesions probably represent various forms of congenital diverticula and are distinct from classic meningocele or myelomeningocele and should not be confused with dural ectasia. (Fig. 6-28)
Diverticula of the spinal nerve root sleeves (including Tarlov’s cysts and spinal nerve root diverticula) can be quite large and may be multiple. They usually involve the dorsal nerve roots and may occur at any level, although they are most frequently observed in the sacral region. Nerve fibers lie within the cyst wall or centrally within the cyst, surrounded by CSF. These cysts are usually asymptomatic, even when quite large. Rarely, neurological symptoms result, requiring surgical excision. (24)
MRI Findings.
Cystic masses in the spinal canal or the neural foramina that exhibit low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images (paralleling the CSF signal changes) are consistent with spinal meningeal cysts (Tarlov’s cysts). ( Fig. 6-29) Bone erosion may occur and is evidenced radiographically by canal widening, pedicle erosion, foraminal enlargement, or scalloping of the posterior vertebral bodies or sacrum. (Fig. 6-30) Parasagittal MRI may demonstrate enlargement of the nerve root sleeve, which must be differentiated from a neural tumor. (Fig. 6-31) It is important to recognize the nature of this lesion to avoid unnecessary biopsy.
P.506

Figure 6-29 SACRAL TARLOV’S CYST. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Sacrum. Note the large, well-defined, low signal intensity cyst adjacent to the S1 level (arrows). This cyst occupies the right lateral aspect of the sacral canal and produces minimal erosion of the posterior margin of S1. C. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe that the sacral cyst (arrow) becomes hyperintense with T2 weighting. COMMENT: Most Tarlov’s cysts are asymptomatic and incidental lesions.
Figure 6-30 GIANT TARLOV’S CYST. A. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Sacrum. Note the large, well-defined mass within the neural canal, adjacent to the S1-S2 segment. COMMENT: The mass is hypointense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2 weighting. These changes are consistent with a benign cystic mass containing cerebrospinal fluid. Note the pressure erosion of the posterior sacral margin (arrows). (Courtesy of Frank E. Seidelmann, DO, Kingsley A. Orraca-Tetteh, MD, and Matthew M. Brown, RT(R), Richmond Heights, Ohio.)
P.507

Figure 6-31 THORACIC NERVE ROOT DIVERTICULUM. T1-Weighted MRI, Thoracic Spine. A. Axial. B. Coronal. C. Sagittal. Observe the marked low signal intensity of the nerve root diverticulum (arrows), which is isointense with the cerebrospinal fluid. Note the minimal erosion of the T11 posterior body and neural arch, which causes slight enlargement of the corresponding intervertebral foramen. COMMENT: Nerve root diverticula are typically asymptomatic and of no clinical concern.
Figure 6-32 EXTENSION TEARDROP FRACTURE OF C2. A. Lateral Cervical Spine. This 40-year-old male suffered a cervical hyperextension injury. Note the small fracture fragment (arrow) avulsed from the anteroinferior aspect of the C2 vertebral body. There is also a posterior subluxation of C2 on C3. The focal enlargement of the retropharyngeal tissues is secondary to edema and hemorrhage. B. Gradient-Echo MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Observe the interruption and increased signal intensity in the anterior longitudinal ligament. Note the low signal intensity avulsed fragment (arrow) adjacent to the anteroinferior margin of the C2 vertebral body. (Courtesy of R. E. Marchand, DC, Calgary, Alberta, Canada.)
P.508

Trauma
Spinal fractures and their complexities have traditionally been imaged by plain film radiography, bone scan, and CT. These modalities, however, are terribly deficient in their ability to demonstrate damage to the various supporting ligaments (short of complete dislocation) and spinal cord contusion. (Figs. 6-32 and 6-33)
MRI has revolutionized the evaluation of trauma to the spine. CT is superior in demonstrating subtle fractures, especially in the posterior neural arch, but it lacks the ability to display ligamentous tears, bone contusions, spinal hematomas, and/or spinal cord contusions. (25,26) (Fig. 6-34) MRI is the only imaging modality to accurately assess these traumatic sequelae.
Figure 6-33 SPINAL CORD CONTUSION. T1-Weighted, Contrast-Enhanced MRI, Cervical Spine. A. Sagittal. B. Axial. Note the well-defined region of increased signal intensity involving the right lateral aspect of the spinal cord (arrows) at the C5 level. Note the minimal increase in the sagittal dimensions of the cord at this level. COMMENT: This young female sustained an injury to her cervical spine, resulting in progressive neurological deficits in the upper and lower extremities. Focally increased signal intensity and expansion of the cord suggest a differential diagnosis that ranges from neoplasm to multiple sclerosis. MRI is the only imaging modality that accurately detects spinal cord contusion.
Fractures
Both CT and MRI are capable of evaluating retropulsed fracture fragments and their position relative to the spinal cord and nerve roots. (Fig. 6-35) CT is better at identifying small bone fragments within the spinal canal. When injury to the spinal cord or nerve root is suspected, however, MRI should also be employed because of its superior spatial and contrast resolution. (Fig. 6-36) In the acute and subacute stages, hemorrhage and bone marrow edema within the vertebral body demonstrate a low signal intensity area within the marrow on T1-weighted images and become hyperintense on T2-weighted images. (Figs. 6-37, 6-38 and 6-39) This signal pattern is consistent with bone marrow edema and suggests that the vertebral fracture is recent (< 6 weeks in duration). A chronic or long-standing fracture does not demonstrate increased signal intensity on any pulse sequence. (27)
Benign Versus Malignant Compression Fracture.
Yuh et al. (28) has suggested that MRI may be helpful in the evaluation of benign versus malignant compression fractures. Benign osteoporotic compression fractures render a low signal intensity band that is often parallel with the endplates on T1-weighted images. If the fracture represents a recent injury, this band becomes hyperintense on T2-weighted images. Gadolinium scans can help characterize the origin of the fracture by enhancing areas of neoplastic replacement. Often, however, benign compression fractures cannot be differentiated from malignancy without biopsy.
Post-Traumatic Syrinx
A significant complication associated with spinal trauma is the development of a post-traumatic syrinx. This entity should be considered in patients who sustain significant injury to the spine and in postsurgical patients. (Fig. 6-40) The pathogenesis of post-traumatic syrinx is not well understood, but the diagnosis, using standard spin-echo sequences, is usually straightforward. If the syrinx is small, however, it may be mistaken for a focal area of myelomalacia. Differentiation usually can be made using T2 weighting. Myelomalacia has intermediate to high signal intensity on the first echo or proton density image, whereas the CSF-filled syrinx has a low signal intensity on this pulse sequence.
Epidural Hematoma
Spinal epidural hematoma may arise from traumatic injury or from spontaneous bleeding (as might be seen in individuals with bleeding disorders), adjacent to neoplasms or vascular malformations, or in areas of previous spinal puncture. (29) The signal characteristics of epidural hematomas vary with the age of the lesion (30) and may have a similar appearance to extruded disc material. (31) Axial images are needed to accurately assess the location of the lesion (epidural versus intradural). (Fig. 6-41) Epidural hematomas are biconcave and produce extrinsic cord compression, whereas subdural hematomas are located within the dural confines and conform to the borders of the thecal sac (i.e., crescent shaped). (27) Intraspinal epidural hematomas arise from venous bleeding and
P.509

are much more common than subdural hematomas, but are still rare. Gundry and Heithoff (31) suggested that these lesions arise from tearing of the fragile epidural veins.
Figure 6-34 FRACTURE OF THE NEURAL ARCH WITH ASSOCIATED C6-C7 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. A. Bone Window CT, Axial Cervical Spine. Note the C6 laminar fracture adjacent to the articular pillar (arrow). B. Gradient-Echo MRI, Axial Cervical Spine. Observe the large, left lateral disc herniation (arrow) at C6 resulting in foraminal stenosis. This finding is not seen on the CT scan. Note the hyperintense area of edema associated with the acute laminar fracture (arrowhead). C. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Observe the acute kyphotic angulation and anterior subluxation of C6 on C7 accompanying the large disc herniation (arrow). COMMENT: This patient developed acute neck pain after a motor vehicle accident. The CT scan showed no herniated nucleus pulposus (HNP), and the acute nature of the laminar fracture could not be confirmed. The axial MRI demonstrates a lateral HNP plus edema within the laminar fracture site, securing the diagnosis of a recent (< 6 weeks) injury.
P.510

Figure 6-35 C6-C7 FRACTURE-DISLOCATION. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Note the anterior dislocation of C6 on C7. Observe the compression fracture and decreased signal intensity of the C7 vertebral body (arrow) representing bone marrow edema. The dislocation has markedly narrowed the spinal canal. B. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical. Observe the subtle, high signal intensity bone marrow edema (arrow), which indicates the acute nature of the fracture. The myelographic effect of the T2-weighted image better demonstrates the canal narrowing with compression and angulation of the spinal cord (arrowhead). In addition, there is a small, hyperintense area within the spinal cord, representing a contusion. COMMENT: This patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident that resulted in quadriplegia. (Courtesy of Steven R. Nokes, MD, Little Rock, Arkansas.)
Figure 6-36 CERVICAL CORD TRANSECTION. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Craniovertebral Junction. Observe the sharply delineated interruption of the spinal cord (arrows), indicating complete cord transection from C2 to the foramen magnum. This condition is fatal. COMMENT: This child was struck by an automobile. MRI may provide the physician with valuable information that limits further invasive investigation.
Figure 6-37 ACUTE COMPRESSION FRACTURE AT MULTIPLE LEVELS. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. B. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Note the ill-defined hypointense signal intensity area within the marrow adjacent to the T4-T7 superior vertebral endplates on the T1-weighted image. This hypointense signal becomes hyperintense on the T2-weighted image, consistent with bone marrow edema. Observe the slight anterior wedging of the T6 and T7 vertebral bodies. (Courtesy of Alan M. Lesselroth, MD, Las Vegas, Nevada.)
P.511

Figure 6-38 OLD OR NEW FRACTURE? A. T1-Weighted MRI, Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the mild concave deformity (arrow) and step defect (arrowhead) of the L2 superior endplate, which suggest an acute origin. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Observe the compression deformity and associated low signal intensity bone marrow edema (arrow), which confirm the acute nature of the compression fracture. Also note the anterior disc herniation at L3-L4 and posterior bulging of the L5-S1 disc. COMMENT: This patient presented with a complicated history of multiple traumas. The clinical challenge was to differentiate between an acute (recent) injury and an old vertebral fracture. An abbreviated sagittal MRI scan (15 min) is a cost-effective method of distinguishing old versus new compression fractures. The presence of bone marrow edema denotes an injury of ≤6 weeks duration.
Figure 6-39 ACUTE T5 COMPRESSION FRACTURE. A. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Note the concave deformity of the T5 superior vertebral endplate resulting from a flexion injury of the thorax 3 weeks earlier. The low signal intensity within the T5 vertebral body represents bone marrow edema (arrows). B. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Observe the hyperintense bone marrow edema (arrows) within the T5 vertebral body. These findings are consistent with an acute compression fracture. COMMENT: MRI is the definitive imaging modality for differentiating recent from old compression fractures.
P.512

Figure 6-40 POSTOPERATIVE SYRINX: THORACIC SPINE. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic. Observe the laminectomy defect (arrows) and focal area of decreased signal within the spinal cord, representing a syrinx (arrowhead). COMMENT: This patient had a history of a multilevel thoracic laminectomy and developed persistent pain near the surgical site. (Courtesy of Thomas E. Hyde, DC, DACB, North Miami, Florida.)
Figure 6-41 CERVICAL SPINE EPIDURAL HEMATOMA. Echo-Gradient MRI, Cervical Spine. A. Sagittal. B. Axial, C2. Note the well-defined collection of high signal intensity ventrally within the epidural space at C2 (arrows). This produces slight posterior displacement and deformity of the spinal cord. COMMENT: This patient presented after a severe motor vehicle accident. (Courtesy of Robert A. Seigel, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
Miscellaneous Traumatic Lesions
Schmorl’s Nodes.
Schmorl’s nodes may be post-traumatic in nature and associated with vertebral compression fractures. Massive herniation of the nucleus through a deformed and fractured endplate can occur and may be a disabling injury. MRI displays the full extent of the nuclear migration and is far more anatomically specific and sensitive than is plain film imaging. (Fig. 6-42) Acute Schmorl’s nodes may be observed on T2-weighted images as a focal intrabody herniation of disc material surrounded by adjacent high signal intensity edema.
MRI provides a unique anatomic visualization of the spinal ligaments, including the anterior longitudinal ligament, posterior longitudinal ligament, interspinous ligaments, and capsular ligaments. Disruption of these ligaments and associated hemorrhagic edema may be demonstrated with MRI and indicates severe injury. These findings may be observed in traumatized patients when there is no plain film evidence of fracture or dislocation.
Spinal Cord Contusion.
Injury to the spinal cord may result in ischemia secondary to direct mechanical compression. This may be caused by displaced bone fragments or articular dislocation. (Fig. 6-43) In addition, during a hyperextension cervical spine injury, congenital spinal stenosis, ligamentum flavum buckling, posterior spondylosis, and herniated nucleus pulposus may trap the cord, resulting in significant cord injury. (Fig. 6-44) Cord
P.513

damage may also occur as a result of vascular injury, especially when the terminal perforating arteries are involved. (32)
Figure 6-42 TRAUMATIC SCHMORL’S NODE, L5 COMPRESSION FRACTURE. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note that the plain film examination underestimates the extent of the injury. Observe the fractured and depressed L5 superior endplate (arrow). B. Proton Density-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. The cortical endplate is interrupted in its midportion with intermediate signal intensity nuclear material extending into the mid-body of L5 (arrows). The lack of high signal intensity bone marrow edema surrounding the Schmorl’s node suggests an old injury. COMMENT: This patient was disabled in an automobile accident. The superior contrast resolution of MRI accurately identified the extent of the injury.
