The TFCC appears as an elongated triangle with the apex directed toward the radius.
MRI is unique in that it is capable of displaying both degenerative and post-traumatic lesions of the TFCC. Clinical findings of an acute TFCC tear include pain and popping along the ulnar aspect of the wrist joint. The central portion of the triangular fibrocartilage (TFC) ligament is thin and is the most common site for degenerative tears. An irregular or linear area of increased signal that communicates with the articular surface on T2*- or T2-weighted pulse sequences is the classic MRI finding of a traumatic TFCC tear. (Fig. 6-162) Tears usually occur within 2-3 mm of the radial insertion (7,14) or close to the ulnar attachment. (14) Occasionally there is an associated avulsion fracture of the styloid process. Fluid collection in the radiocarpal and the distal radioulnar joints has been described as an important secondary sign of acute TFCC tear. (7,14,15) Degenerative tears of the TFCC are often seen in asymptomatic individuals and appear on T2- and T2*-weighted coronal images as a hyperintense area of intrameniscal signal that does not communicate with the articular surface.
Figure 6-161 SCAPHOLUNATE LIGAMENT TEAR. T2*-Weighted MRI, Coronal Wrist. Note the widened scapholunate joint space with a poorly defined scapholunate ligament (arrow). Observe the intact triangular fibrocartilage complex (arrowheads). (Courtesy of Frank E. Seidelmann, DO, Kingsley A. Orraca-Tetteh, MD, and Matthew M. Brown, RT(R), Richmond Heights, Ohio.)
Figure 6-162 TRIANGULAR FIBROCARTILAGE COMPLEX TEAR. T2*-Weighted MRI, Coronal Wrist. Note the normal hyperintense articular fluid extending into the distal radioulnar joint (arrow). This fluid escapes proximally through the vertical tear in the lateral portion of the triangular fibrocartilage (arrowhead). Observe the normal scapholunate (crossed arrow) and lunate-triquetrum (curved arrow) ligaments. (Courtesy of Frank E. Seidelmann, DO, Kingsley A. Orraca-Tetteh, MD, and Matthew M. Brown, RT(R), Richmond Heights, Ohio.)
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) involves motor and sensory dysfunction of the median nerve. It occurs as a result of compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel. Causes include fracture, infection, various infiltrative disease processes, and localized soft tissue pathology. Carpal tunnel syndrome is usually found in patients who are 30-60 years old, with a high female to male ratio (as high as 5:1). (16) Bilateral symptoms are present in > 50% of cases. (16)
Clinical symptoms include pain and paresthesias that are worse at night and often wake the patient. These symptoms follow the classic distribution of the median nerve and thus affect the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, and middle finger and the radial half of the ring finger. Muscle atrophy and loss of function are late findings. Positive Tinel and Phalen signs are helpful orthopedic indicators of CTS.
P.594

Anatomy of the Carpal Tunnel
The carpal tunnel can be broken down into its proximal and distal components. The proximal portion of the tunnel is at the level of the pisiform, and the distal aspect of the tunnel occurs at approximately the level of the hamate.
The carpus has a concave bony contour along its volar surface and is covered by the flexor retinaculum. The bony carpus forms the floor and walls of the carpal tunnel, with the rigid flexor retinaculum representing its roof. The flexor tendons of the hand and forearm as well as numerous neurovascular structures traverse through the tunnel, deep to the retinaculum.
The median nerve is round or oval at the level of the distal radius and becomes elliptical in shape at the pisiform and hamate. The morphologic appearance and position of the median nerve are altered during flexion and extension of the wrist.
Causes
There are numerous causes of carpal tunnel syndrome. Fracture (e.g., Colles, hook of the hamate, proximal metacarpal) and tenosynovitis (repetitive strain injury) of the flexor tendons are some of the traumatic causes. Synovial hyperplasia is frequently seen in inflammatory arthritides (such as gout, pseudo-gout, rheumatoid arthritis, and amyloidosis) and results in an increased volume of tissue within the carpal tunnel, producing subsequent median nerve compression. Tumors of the median nerve (fibromas, neural sheath tumors) and other space-occupying lesions (lipomas and ganglions) may encroach on the carpal canal, producing carpal tunnel syndrome. Other known causes of CTS involve bilateral soft tissue thickening that may occur with pregnancy, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and diabetes mellitus. (17)
Figure 6-163 CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME. T2-Weighted MRI, Bilateral Axial Wrist. Observe the increased signal intensity and swelling of the right median nerve (arrow). In addition, there is increased fluid between the flexor tendons within the tunnel (arrowheads) and slight bowing of the flexor retinaculum (crossed arrow). COMMENT: This 42-year-old female experienced weakness and tingling of the right wrist. The nerve conduction velocity test has approximately an 80% sensitivity for carpal tunnel syndrome. If negative, an MRI examination should be performed for further evaluation.
Electrodiagnostic Testing
The definitive means for establishing the diagnosis of CTS is nerve conduction testing. Plain film radiography seldom offers any contribution to the diagnosis. The use of MRI in the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome should be guided by clinical history and physical findings. MRI is indicated when conservative management has failed, electrodiagnostic testing is equivocal, or physical examination demonstrates a mass or fullness in the carpal region near the carpal tunnel.
MRI Findings
Both coronal and axial MRI studies of the wrist provide valuable information in determining the presence of median nerve damage or deficit. (18) The following changes in the median nerve are present in CTS, regardless of the cause: (7) (Fig. 6-163)
  • Diffuse swelling or segmental enlargement of the median nerve, best evaluated at the level of the pisiform.
  • Flattening of the median nerve, best demonstrated at the level of the hamate.
  • Palmar bowing of the flexor retinaculum, assessed at the level of the hamate.
  • Increased signal intensity within the median nerve at any level, which is well demonstrated on axial T2- and T2*-weighted and STIR images. (19)
THE TEMPOROMANDIBULAR JOINT
Imaging of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) continues to be a technologically challenging task. Plain film radiography, in both
P.595

the open- and closed-mouth positions, renders basic information concerning the integrity of the joint. However, high-quality images are difficult to obtain because of the complex anatomy of this area. Bilateral open- and closed-mouth tomographic projections were used in the early years to evaluate the TMJ. Later, fluoroscopy, with and without intra-articular contrast, was employed to indirectly visualize joint pathology and to assess function. Arthrography allows indirect characterization of disc morphology but is an invasive procedure with associated morbidity and limitations in accuracy. (1) Sagittally reformatted CT images following arthrography have also been used to evaluate the TMJ. This technique, however, does not provide the spatial resolution necessary to accurately delineate the disc and surrounding ligaments. MRI has replaced these modalities. (2,3,4,5) Its non-invasive nature, lack of ionizing radiation, and multiplanar capability make MRI the ideal imaging technique for evaluating the structure and function of the TMJ. (6,7,8)
Figure 6-164 TMJ: DISC DISPLACEMENT. A. Proton Density-Weighted MRI, Closed Mouth Sagittal TMJ. Note the complete anterior displacement of the low signal intensity intra-articular disc (arrow). B. Proton Density-Weighted MRI, Open Mouth Sagittal TMJ. Observe the anterior translation of the mandibular condyle (C) with no change in the position of the intra-articular disc (arrow). COMMENT: MRI is considered the gold standard for evaluating internal derangement of the TMJ.
Figure 6-165 TMJ: A DISC THAT SLIPS. A. Tomography, Closed and Open Mouth Lateral TMJ. Note the location of the mandibular condyle (C) in the glenoid in the closed position (1,2). Note that on the open mouth studies (3,4) the condyle translates and rotates anteriorly. Observe the asymmetric joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation on the mandibular condyle anteriorly. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Closed Mouth TMJ. Note the anterior displacement of the disc (arrow). C. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Open Mouth TMJ. Observe the anterior displacement of the disc (arrow), which remains anteriorly displaced regardless of the position of the mandible. COMMENT: MRI may provide assessment of TMJ dynamics, serving as a functional complement to anatomic assessment. A cine loop format displays the simulation of continuous motion during mouth opening and closing. The current modality of choice to assess the TMJ is MRI. (Courtesy of Kennon E. Rude, DC, Boulder, Colorado.)
Technical Considerations
Sagittal images using T1- and T2*-weighted pulse sequences are used in the evaluation of the articular disc and surrounding ligaments of the TMJ. Surface coil technology allows the field of view to be limited, providing the necessary signal to noise ratio. Thin slices through the articulation may be obtained using 3D volume acquisitions. The reformation capability of 3D techniques
P.596

reduces the need for coronal images; however, when the joint capsule or supporting ligaments are in question, coronal slices should be acquired. The examination should be performed in the full open- and closed-mouth positions to document meniscus position and degree of reduction. (1)
Internal Derangement
Clinical symptoms of internal derangement include craniofacial and cervicocranial pain syndromes, myofascial pain, joint dysfunction and crepitus, and dental malocclusion. (1) The scope of this discussion concerning the TMJ is limited to meniscal displacement and perforation.
Meniscal Displacement
Internal derangement (displacement of the articular meniscus or disc) is the most common imaging finding in the TMJ. The discs often display surface irregularity, fissuring, fibrillation, and fraying, all of which may be identified with MRI. Injury to the bilaminar zone of the meniscus may allow anterior displacement of the disc in the open- or closed-mouth position. A rotational component to the meniscal displacement may also exist. (1)
A grading system characterizing disc morphology and displacement has been described. (9) A grade I disc demonstrates anterior displacement without visible morphologic change. (Fig. 6-164) Anterior displacement of an abnormally shaped disc characterizes a grade II disc lesion. (Fig. 6-165) Helms et al. (10) found that 95% of joints with grade II discs exhibited evidence of osteoarthritis, whereas only 17% of joints with grade I disc lesions showed similar changes.
Disc Perforation
Arthrography remains the best imaging modality to evaluate perforations of the TMJ meniscus. Most patients with a perforated meniscus also have a dislocation. MRI demonstrates the dislocation and adequately outlines the damage to the meniscus. (1)
MAGNETIC RESONANCE ANGIOGRAPHY
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a rapidly advancing modality. (1) MRA made its debut in the 1990s years ago with images of the brain and neck. Two types of MRA imaging sequences developed concurrently: time of flight (TOF) and phase contrast. Both are currently used, although TOF is more widely employed. (2) In the mid-1990s, contrast-enhanced 3D MRA emerged, providing high-quality images without the limitations of the non-contrast studies. The non-contrast studies are time-consuming and subject to artifact, such as motion, signal loss from disturbed flow, and insensitivity to slow flow. (3) Examination times decreased from 10 min to 30 sec with the introduction of gadolinium-contrast enhancement, allowing the examination to be performed in one breath hold, thus reducing motion artifacts. Reduction in flow artifacts and improved image quality resulted not only from the use of contrast but also from the introduction of subtraction techniques and electrocardiogram triggering. (2)
Today, imaging sequences can be obtained in 2D, 3D, phase contrast, and multiple overlapping thin slab acquisition (MOTSA). MOTSA uses many thin 3D TOF slabs joined to form high spatial resolution images. (4) Any of these sequences can incorporate gadolinium contrast. (1,3) The desire to move away from the invasiveness of arteriography has led the charge for the developmental improvements in MRA. (5)
INDICATIONS
Catheter angiography is the gold standard for vascular assessment; however, it has limitations. Conventional catheter x-ray angiography, unlike MRA, uses ionizing radiation and a surgical procedure and is, therefore, invasive. Catheter angiography has a 4% risk of stroke when evaluating carotid arteries in the symptomatic patient. MRA may be used in patients who cannot tolerate an invasive procedure, such as the frail and elderly. (1) MRA contrast is not iodinated, so the risk of iodine allergy is not an issue. (2) In addition, MRA does not require contrast, unlike conventional angiography, and thus can be used in patients suffering from renal insufficiency. (1)
Any vascular territory can be evaluated by MRA. MRA can be used for assessment of the patient with suspected intracranial or extracranial vascular disease (Fig. 6-166) or an abdominal aortic aneurysm undergoing elective aneurysm repair. The information obtained in the latter example includes type and localization of the aneurysm, diameter and cranial caudal extent, aneurysm wall structures and periaortic space, relationship to mesenteric and renal arteries, and presence of iliac aneurysm or stenosis. A limitation of MRA is the susceptibility artifacts produced by patients with stainless-steel stent grafts.
MRA can also be useful for evaluation of aortic occlusive disease. Visualization is technically difficult with conventional angiography, requiring catheter placement in high-risk vessels, such as the upper extremity or translumbar catheterization. MRA does not use a catheter procedure and thus can visualize the occlusion without the increased risk. (3) The aorta is also subject to dissection, being the most frequent and most important acute disease of the abdominal aorta. The significant features required for proper assessment of the dissection are entry and re-entry sites, intimal tear extension, and branch vessel involvement. Contrast-enhanced 3D MRA can identify all three. (4)
MRA is better than conventional arteriography at detecting infrapopliteal arteries suitable for surgical bypass. In the lower extremity, MRA adequately detects arterial stenosis of > 50%, and this accuracy is improved with a 3D gadolinium-enhanced technique. Although conventional arteriography is still the gold standard, some consider this modality inappropriate for assessment of infrapopliteal arteries, owing to its inability to adequately opacify small vessels. (1,3)
The recommended pulse sequence for the lower extremity examination is the 2D TOF. This sequence is capable of imaging slow blood flow and vessels distal to occlusions. Gadolinium contrast-enhanced methods are becoming more popular because of the shorter examination time compared with the 2D TOF. Contrast-enhanced methods are also subject to fewer artifacts. (3) The emerging impact of MRA is the result of its reduced invasiveness and lower cost compared with catheter angiography. This
P.597

trend is likely to continue into the distant future. Contraindications to MRA are the same as those for MRI.
Figure 6-166 MRA: EXTRACRANIAL VASCULATURE. A. 2D Time of Flight MRA, Coronal. Observe the extracranial vasculature of the normal carotid (arrow) and vertebral (arrowhead) arteries. COMMENT: MRA is a minimally invasive (intravenous contrast) means of imaging the extracranial vasculature. Reduced vertebral artery blood flow associated with stenosis is a risk factor for stroke. MRA is indicated when clinical signs of cerebrovascular insufficiency are observed, such as cranial nerve deficits (diplopia), vertigo, dysarthria, and facial numbness. B. 3D Time of Flight MRA, Axial Intracranial. Observe the normal intracranial vasculature of the circle of Willis. The middle cerebral arteries are well seen (arrows). COMMENT: The middle cerebral arteries are a frequent site of embolism, dissection, and aneurysm. These disorders are especially well documented by contrast-enhanced MRA.
Medicolegal Implications
MRI AND MRA
  • All ferromagnetic devices and metallic objects must be removed from the patient before examination because they may become projectile hazards.
  • MRI and MRA are contraindicated in patients with any of the following electronic and/or metallic implants: cardiac pacemakers, aneurysm clips, intraocular metal fragments, cochlear implants, and implanted drug infusion devices. Some other vascular implants and devices, such as prosthetic heart valves and penile implants, may contraindicate the use of MRI or MRA. Patients should be assessed on an individual basis because the ferromagnetic properties of the implanted device and the strength of the magnetic field determine which materials should not be in or around the scanner.
  • The 2002 American College of Radiology white paper on magnetic resonance safety recommends that the attending radiologist determine that the risk-benefit ratio is appropriate before scanning a patient at any stage of pregnancy. The college suggests close consultation with the referring physician. If an alternate means of obtaining the information by non-ionizing imaging (i.e., sonography) is unavailable and the study affects the care of the patient and/or fetus during the pregnancy, then an MRI study is indicated. Magnetic resonance contrast agents should not be routinely employed in pregnancy but considered on an individual case basis. (5)
COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
In 1972 Godfried Hounsfield of EMI Limited in London introduced the first generation of CT equipment, which consisted of an x-ray source, radiation detectors, and electronic devices mounted on a frame or gantry that surrounded the patient being imaged. (1) The CT image depicts a thin slice of anatomy obtained from multiple x-ray absorption measurements made around the periphery of the body. Contrary to conventional tomography, by which the image of a thin section of anatomy is made by blurring out information from unwanted areas above and below the plane of interest, the CT image is constructed by using data taken only from the region of interest. The x-ray tube and detectors were designed to move continuously across the patient.
Hounsfield shared the Nobel Prize for medicine in 1979 for his role in the discovery of CT. The first clinical prototype EMI head scan (Mark I) was installed in early 1972 at Atkinson Morley’s Hospital in London. (1) It proved to be an immediate success, and an improved version was introduced at that year’s meeting of the Radiological Society of North America. (2) The scanner consisted of a stationary anode x-ray tube cooled by circulating oil. (2) The first EMI head scanner in America was placed at the Mayo Clinic in July 1973. (2)
The EMI scanner was designed for brain scanning, and its applications were limited to the head. (2) In the United States a dentist, Ledley, became intrigued with the possibility of applying the technique to other regions of the body. (2) He parlayed this interest into funding for construction of the first whole-body scanner. (2) The first clinical unit was named the ACTA scanner, and it was installed at the University of Minnesota in 1973. (2) Anatomic motion remained a significant problem in the application of this scanner to regions other than the head and extremities. (2)
P.598

Since the development of the first-generation CT scanners, major technical advancements have dramatically increased the speed of scanning and quality of image reconstruction. (2) Fourth-generation CT scanners and, more recently, an ultra-fast (helical/spiral) CT scanner have been introduced. Douglas Boyd and collaborators designed this unit to image the heart. By successfully steering a small, focal spot size electron beam at four fixed tungsten target rings, an artifact-free image of the heart can be obtained in as little as 17 msec, with a single breath hold.
Glossary
attenuation
The absorbed energy of an x-ray beam after it passes through a given substance. Each tissue examined has a specific attenuation or x-ray photon absorption value.
bone window
Window level and width that optimize the attenuation values of bone, allowing cortical and medullary differentiation. The subtle attenuation coefficients of the soft tissues are not appreciated and have a dark gray appearance.
gantry
A round or square housing for the x-ray tubes and scintillation detectors. The patient is placed in the open center of the gantry. Most CT scanners allow angulation of the gantry up to 30°. (Fig. 6-167)
hounsfield unit (HU)
The unit of radiographic density in CT. that reflect the attenuation properties of a given tissue, relative to those of water and air. By assigning constant Hounsfield unit values to air (−1000 HU) and water (0 HU), a relative scale of radiographic densities (gray scale) is generated. The computer then assigns an HU value for each tissue voxel based on its attenuation coefficient. This is expressed as a specific shade of gray on the resultant CT image.
multidetector
Multiple rows of detector arrays providing multislice acquisition in one revolution of the helical x-ray beam.
photon detector cells (scintillation detectors)
High-efficiency photodiodes that absorb and register the attenuated photon beam following its passage through the patient. The photon energy registered by the scintillation detector is processed by the computer to produce the CT image.
pixel
Tiny 2D squares that represent attenuation characteristics from a 3D volume of tissue (voxel). Each pixel is made up of multiple attenuation coefficients that are averaged to
P.599

create a mean measurement of tissue density (expressed in Hounsfield units).
Figure 6-167 CT SCANNER: GANTRY. The CT gantry houses the x-ray tube and photon detectors. The couch is padded for patient comfort and can be vertically adjusted. Its movement in and out of the gantry is precisely controlled, allowing the exact location of each tomographic slice to be determined. Laser-assisted patient placement aids in the overall accuracy of the examination. Most gantries angle up to 30° to provide angled slices through the intervertebral discs.
Figure 6-168 BONE AND SOFT TISSUE WINDOWS: NORMAL ANATOMY. CT, Axial Lumbar. Note the distinction between bone and soft tissue window settings. On soft tissue windows (top row) the soft tissues appear gray and there is poor distinction between cortical and medullary bone. On bone windows (bottom row), soft tissues appear dark and there is optimum differentiation between cortical and medullary bone.
soft tissue window
Window level and width that optimize the attenuation values of soft tissues. Differentiation of cortical and medullary bone is often not possible on these images.
voxel
A volume of tissue projected into the pixel from which the Hounsfield unit is derived.
window level
An arbitrary number chosen by the operator to limit the shades of gray to optimally display a specific attenuation value (tissue density).
window width
A preselected range of attenuation values chosen by the operator to visualize a range of tissue densities. The window level represents the median density. For example, if the window level is set at 200 HU and the window width is 800 HU, the resultant image would display Hounsfield units that measure +600 to −200. Any density outside this range would appear as white or black on the image. (Fig. 6-168)
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
Fourth-generation CT equipment places the photon detector cells in fixed positions around the patient, while the x-ray source rotates within the surrounding gantry. (Fig. 6-169) These CT units efficiently capture the continuous flow of x-ray energy through the use of 1000 or more photon detectors composed of scintillation crystals and photodiodes. (1)
The anatomic information received from the photon detectors is processed through a series of complex mathematical equations. This information is then manipulated into numerous tiny pixels. Each pixel is assigned an attenuation value (Hounsfield unit) and arranged in a matrix to form the final axial CT image. (Fig. 6-170) This image is then viewed on a monitor (cathode ray tube; CRT). The window level and width can be adjusted to change the image characteristics and highlight specific tissue attributes before the hard copy is produced.
Figure 6-169 ROTATE CT SCANNER. This fourth-generation rotating scanner has stationary detector elements in the ring surrounding the patient. The tube and fan beam rotate around the patient as radiation is directed to the region of interest. The detectors measure the residual photon energy, and the computers then encode the attenuation characteristics necessary for image formation.
On most systems, collimation as fine as 1 mm is available. This feature, coupled with the use of a sharp reconstruction kernel, permits acquisition of detailed images of high-contrast objects, such as trabecular bone and the parenchyma of the lungs. (2,3,4,5) All CT information is acquired in the axial plane, except for smaller body parts such as facial bones, wrist, and feet for which sagittal or coronal images can be obtained. Sagittal or coronal images of the spine are created by manipulating the stored computer data from the axial images. This reconstruction or reformatting process is analogous to first viewing a loaf of bread slice by slice, in a transverse or axial orientation, then stacking each slice on top of one another and slicing vertically through the loaf to obtain a coronal or sagittal perspective. (Fig. 6-171) These reconstructed images are significantly less detailed than the axial images from which they were derived. True multiplanar imaging is best obtained using MRI, when applicable.
Helical (spiral) multidetector CT has three main advantages over conventional single-detector CT. First is the shorter examination time. Conventional CT acquires an image in 1-5 sec and then moves the patient a predefined distance for additional images. The helical CT attains a volume of information within 24-32 sec and that data can then be reviewed at any increment between 1 and 10 mm. (6) Second is the capability for retrospective
P.600

image reconstruction, which decreases image degradation from volume averaging.
Figure 6-170 CT IMAGE FORMATION. A. Collimation of the Fan X-Ray Beam. Precise collimation is employed so that a very thin fan beam of x-rays is used to scan thin sections of the body. B. Voxels and Pixels. Each photon detector deciphers a volume of tissue (voxel). Shaded box, a voxel; 7, attenuation coefficient of that volume of tissue (pixel). C. Image Matrix. The CT image is formed from a volume of data received from the detectors and processed by the computer for display (on a monitor or hard copy). The shaded rectangular box represents a voxel, and the shaded square at the end of the voxel is the picture element or pixel. Each image represents a matrix or composite of pixels. Each pixel represents the attenuation coefficient of a given volume of tissue.
Figure 6-171 IMAGE RECONSTRUCTION (REFORMATION). A. Axial Images. The data used to produce a CT image are obtained in an axial format. B. Sagittal Images. C. Coronal Images. The numerical data used to produce the axial images can be used to create sagittal and coronal reformation images. COMMENT: The reformation process is analogous to slicing a loaf of bread. The slices of bread represent the axial images that are initially obtained by the CT scanner. If those slices are stacked one on top of another, that entire loaf of bread may be sliced vertically, producing a different (sagittal or coronal) perspective.
Figure 6-172 MULTIDETECTOR SPIRAL CT: NORMAL ANATOMY. A. AP Lumbar Spine. B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Examples of multidetector spiral CT scans that employ colorcoded reconstruction algorithms for 3D imaging display. High-quality artifact-free images increase the sensitivity for identification of subtle pathology, including fracture, dislocation, ligament injury, and vascular and neural complications. Three-dimensional displays are especially useful in visualizing pathology with complex topography in relation to the surrounding anatomy. COMMENT: Several emerging image-processing techniques are being used with multidetector spiral CT scanning, such as volume-rendered, shaded surface-rendered, and physiologic imaging analysis. These techniques attempt to display a 3D structure and its spatial relationships in a 2D image. (Courtesy of Heart Check, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.601

The third advantage is the ability for improved multiplanar reconstructions (7) owing to the diminished motion artifacts arising from the decreased examination time. For example, motion artifact on one or more images results in an unsatisfactory 3D image regardless of the algorithm used. Helical CT allows full data acquisition within a single breath hold, removing the motion artifact, resulting in approximately 100% success with 3D reconstruction (8). (Fig. 6-172) Three-dimensional reconstructions are useful for planning oncologic therapy (9), determining surgical procedures (10), and assessing anatomically complex regions (e.g., ribs, pelvis, shoulder, sternoclavicular joint, and spine). (9)
There are two fundamental limitations of helical CT. The greater speed of the helical CT examination comes at a price in perceived image sharpness. The larger the pitch (table translation within the gantry) and slice thickness, the worse the spatial resolution. This is unacceptable when assessing the trauma patient. The goal is to minimize the product of slice thickness and pitch while maintaining greater examination speed. (11) The highest quality multiplanar reconstructions occur with thin overlapping slices. (12) Second, the speed of helical CT affects the SNR. Conventional CT has a time delay between slices that allows some tube cooling, whereas helical CT has continuous acquisition without time for cooling, limiting the available tube current. The result is a decrease in the SNR. This decrease is greatest in larger body parts because of the requirement of higher tube currents. (11)
The state-of-the-art CT technology is the multidetector row scanner. This 16-section scanner emerged in 2001 and has the advantage over its earlier spiral counterparts by being faster and providing improved temporal resolution and better spatial resolution in the transverse plane. The image is also isotropic, meaning that the resolution is equally adequate in the sagittal, coronal, and axial planes; therefore, there is no preferred plane for image reconstruction and all planes are equal in resolution. The 16-section scanner even has an advantage over MRI. MRI requires the examiner to choose the plane of imaging before data acquisition, whereas the new CT scanner allows for the optimal plane to be chosen after the examination. This scanner works by allowing simultaneous acquisition of up to 16-submillimeter sections with gantry rotation times of < 0.5 sec. (13,14)
Figure 6-173 NORMAL ANATOMY. A. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial C1. Note that soft tissue windows provide good contrast resolution between the various soft tissues but suboptimally define the bony structures. Note the borders of the dural sac (arrows), which contain the spinal cord (arrowheads) and the lower-attenuation cerebrospinal fluid (crossed arrow). Air is observed in the pharynx (P) and esophagus (E). B. Bone Window CT, Axial C1. By adjusting the window level and expanding the window width, the same numerical data can be displayed with different image characteristics. The bones demonstrate better spatial and contrast resolution, whereas the soft tissues are now poorly differentiated. Note the dens (arrow), lateral masses (arrowheads), and anterior tubercle (crossed arrow) of C1.
Intrathecal, intradiscal, or intravenous injection of radiopaque contrast before CT examination may help in the assessment of certain conditions. Intravenous contrast may assist in delineating soft tissue lesions that are difficult or impossible to see on non-contrast scans. In addition, the pattern of vascular enhancement may provide insight into the histology of a given lesion, allowing differentiation of recurrent disc herniation from reparative scar in the postsurgical patient.
The radiation dose for a 30- to 36-slice standard CT scan of the lumbar spine is 3-5 rads. By comparison, five plain film radiographs of the lumbar spine of an average-size patient using a 100-kHz true high-frequency generator, a 12:1 grid ratio, and 600-speed rare-earth film-screen combination results in a total patient dose of approximately 1 rad. However, a single-phase generator, a 12:1 ratio, and a 400-speed rare earth film-screen combination used to image the lumber spine in the same patient renders a total patient dose of approximately 2.5 rad.
CONTRAINDICATIONS
Few contraindications to the use of CT exist. As with other modalities that use ionizing radiation, patient dose should be kept to a minimum and children should not be scanned without strong clinical indication. Hypersensitivity to iodine products, delayed renal clearance, and congestive heart failure contraindicate the use of contrast infusion. Blood urea nitrogen and creatinine laboratory values should be assessed before intravenous contrast use. The presence of metallic objects near the area of interest may result in significant image artifact from beam scattering. Better detail may be obtained from MRI in some instances. Claustrophobia may occur in a small percentage of the patients scanned.
P.602

NORMAL ANATOMY
CT uses x-ray technology to provide images oriented in the axial plane. By altering the window width and window level, one can target a specific tissue to be optimally visualized. Normally, both soft tissue and bone windows are performed for complete evaluation of a body region. (Fig. 6-173) CT is best employed to evaluate the cortex and surrounding periosteum. MRI provides superior spatial and contrast resolution and is therefore better at evaluating bone marrow and contents of the neural canal. (Fig. 6-174)
Figure 6-174 NORMAL ANATOMY: CT VERSUS MRI. A. Bone Window CT, Axial L5. Note the vertebral body (B), thecal sac (T), nerve root exiting the lateral recess (arrow), and ligamentum flavum (arrowhead). B. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial L5. Note that the epidural fat has bright signal on MRI compared with its low attenuation on CT. C. Bone Window CT, Axial L5-S1. Note the normal and symmetrical nerve roots (arrows) and the round thecal sac (arrowhead). D. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Sacrum. The descending nerve roots (arrows) and the thecal sac (arrowheads) are of low signal intensity and are easily contrasted by the high signal intensity of the surrounding epidural fat (crossed arrow). (Courtesy of James J. Holland, DC, FACO, Sacramento, California.)
INDICATIONS
Computed tomography may be employed in the assessment of numerous pathologic conditions. Several broad categories of disease are discussed in this section: traumatic, infectious, vascular, neoplastic, congenital, arthritic, and metabolic disorders.
Trauma
Traumatic lesions of the musculoskeletal system are frequently well demonstrated on conventional radiographs. In areas of complex
P.603

anatomy, such as the facial bones, spine, and pelvis, however, significant bony infractions may be occult or inadequately demonstrated on plain films. (Figs. 6-175 and 6-176) The use of CT is warranted when radiographs are equivocal or when suspicious clinical findings are not substantiated by the present plain film study. (Fig. 6-177) In cases of comminuted fractures, reconstructed CT provides valuable information concerning the location of bone fragments and their relationship to articulating surfaces. This information is crucial in the preoperative evaluation of intra-articular fractures of any joint. Occult fractures of the bone marrow, however, are better displayed on MRI.
Axial and reconstructed sagittal CT slices offer a clear assessment of the vertebral column. In spinal trauma CT helps exclude or confirm the presence of small bone fragments near the spinal cord by eliminating overlapping structures that may obscure the fractures on plain radiography. (Fig. 6-178) In addition to fractures of the vertebral column, atlantoaxial rotatory subluxations and facet malalignments are well demonstrated by CT. (1) (Figs. 6-179 and 6-180) When cord compression and/or intramedullary lesions are suspected clinically, the CT examination must be complemented by MRI. MRI clearly displays post-traumatic cord injury, including edema and hemorrhage. CT does not have the necessary contrast resolution to adequately evaluate suspected spinal cord injury.
CT is also useful in the diagnosis of traumatic lesions of the orbits (e.g., blowout fractures), paranasal sinuses, and facial bones (e.g., tripod and Le Fort fractures). (1,2,3,4) Three-dimensional reconstruction of the axial images is beneficial in unraveling the overlapping anatomy of the facial skeleton and in preoperative planning. Injury to other complex osseous structures, including the wrist, ankle (Fig. 6-181), shoulder (Fig. 6-182), and sternoclavicular joints as well as the pelvic articulations may be effectively evaluated with CT. The anatomic features of spondylolysis are also well demonstrated by CT. (Fig. 6-183)
Figure 6-175 ATYPICAL JEFFERSON’S FRACTURE. Bone Window CT, Axial Atlantoaxial Joint. Note the fracture of the anterior and posterior ring of C1 (arrows) with minimal displacement of the lateral masses. In addition, observe the small cortical avulsion from the posterior aspect of the odontoid (arrowhead). COMMENT: The typical Jefferson’s fracture represents discontinuity of the anterior and posterior arches, thus resulting in displacement of the lateral masses. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
Post-traumatic, calcified, soft tissue lesions (e.g., myositis ossificans, calcified hematomas) should also be assessed with CT. (Fig. 6-184) The differential diagnosis is especially important and includes malignancy, infection, and aneurysm. Calcifications are seen with MRI as signal voids and are difficult to evaluate accurately. CT better demonstrates the extent and location of the calcifications (periosteal, parosteal, or intramuscular) and is the imaging modality of choice for these calcified lesions. MRI can be useful in showing the uncalcified intramuscular hematomas, which are often not evident on CT scans. Biopsy of questionable calcific lesions in the soft tissues should be avoided until a CT is performed. Careful inspection of the CT appearance of myositis ossificans will show a central lucency with a dense periphery versus the dense epicenter and lucent periphery of sarcoma.
The single breath hold data acquisition time of helical CT eliminates potential motion artifacts in the patient who has difficulty remaining motionless. This abbreviated time allows for betterquality multiplanar reconstruction (MPR) or 3D imaging than that achieved by the long examination times of conventional CT. Two-dimensional MPR has superior anatomic detail but 3D imaging is preferred for surgical planning, owing to the unveiling of complicated anatomic structures. (5)
An example of a complicated anatomic structure is the sternoclavicular joint. Helical CT is the most accurate diagnostic test for noting the presence of sternoclavicular joint dislocations and the degree of displacement. (6) Helical CT can help identify superior rib fractures or shoulder fractures often seen with sternoclavicular joint dislocations. (7) Posterior dislocation may be associated with great vessel injury and thus requires contrast for assessment. (7) The helical CT technique is optimal for contrast studies because data acquisition is obtained during peak contrast levels. (8) These peak contrast levels increase the sensitivity of lesion detection.
Another anatomic structure that is difficult to assess on plain film radiography is the integrity of the tibial plateau. Tibial plateau fractures often go undiagnosed on plain film, but with helical CT a 5-mm displaced tibial plateau fracture has a diagnostic sensitivity of 96% and a specificity of 93%. (9)
Infection
Infectious processes such as discitis, osteomyelitis, and Brodie’s abscess can be evaluated with CT, which shows cortical and juxtacortical involvement as well as cloaca and sequestrum formation. Associated soft tissue involvement is common and may be seen as blurring of the fascial planes. This finding is frequently missed or not apparent on radiography and is better appreciated with CT.
In cases of spinal infections, endplate destruction and paravertebral masses are easily detected on axial CT images. (10,11,12,13) (Fig. 6-185) Disc space infections are more commonly seen in children and in adults who have previously undergone laminectomy or discectomy procedures. (1,14) Sclerosis, irregularities of the destroyed vertebral endplates, and narrowing of the disc space represent the typical signs of discitis on CT images, along with displacement of the epidural fat in the spinal canal from abscess.
P.604

Figure 6-176 STRESS FRACTURE: TIBIA. A. Lateral Knee. Note the localized increase in cortical density on the posterior tibia (arrow), suspicious for a stress fracture. B. Bone Window CT, Sagittal Reformation Tibia. Note the focal eccentric cortical thickening along the posterior tibial cortex (arrows). C. Bone Window CT, 3D Reformation Tibia. Note the cortical thickening on the tibial cortex (arrow). These findings are consistent with a stress fracture. T, tibia; F, fibula. COMMENT: The posterior border of the proximal tibial metaphysis is the most common site for stress fractures of the lower extremity.
Figure 6-177 PILLAR FRACTURE: FREQUENTLY MISSED CERVICAL SPINE INJURY. Bone Window CT, Axial Cervical Spine. Note a fracture line extending into the left articular pillar (arrow). COMMENT: This patient developed severe neck pain after his vehicle was struck from behind. Radiographs (not shown) were normal. Because axially oriented fractures can be missed on CT, coronal reformation is often necessary for detecting these lesions. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
Figure 6-178 BURST FRACTURE WITH RETROPULSION. Bone Window CT, Axial Lumbar Spine. Note the impaction of the L1 vertebral endplate resulting in a double cortical contour (arrow) anteriorly. Another fracture of the posterior vertebral body is noted with retropulsion of a large fragment into the spinal canal (arrowhead). In addition, there is a fracture of the posterior neural arch (crossed arrow). COMMENT: This patient was injured from a fall from a height of several stories. The injuries resulted in paraplegia. CT has revolutionized the evaluation of acute spinal trauma to the degree that many who have entered hospitals paralyzed have been discharged with no neurologic deficit. A major advantage of spinal CT is to guide the surgeon to the specific anatomic location and the eventual treatment of complicated burst fractures of the spine.
P.605

Figure 6-179 TYPE III ODONTOID FRACTURE. Bone Window CT, Sagittal Reformation Atlantoaxial Joint. Note the anterior displacement of a type III odontoid fracture (arrow). As a result of the anterior displacement, there is narrowing of the AP diameter of the spinal canal at C1-C2 (arrowheads). The reformatted image is obtained from the axial image shown in the bottom panel. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
Figure 6-180 VERTICAL VERTEBRAL BODY FRACTURE AND FACET DISLOCATION. A. Lateral Cervical Spine. Note the bilateral interfacetal dislocation with resulting anterolisthesis of C6 on C7. In addition, observe the small defect in the cortex of the superior C5 endplate (arrow), suggesting a minor compression deformity. B. Bone Window CT, Axial C5. Note the vertical fracture line coursing through the vertebral body (arrow), which was not apparent on the radiograph. COMMENT: CT is an ideal modality for the evaluation and detection of fractures in the vertebral column. (Courtesy of Steven P. Brownstein, MD, Springfield, New Jersey.)
P.606

Figure 6-181 TALAR DOME FRACTURE: A CHALLENGING DIAGNOSIS. A. Medial Oblique Ankle. Note the subtle curvilinear lucency (arrow) traversing the medial talar dome of the right ankle, suggesting a fracture. B. Bone Window CT, Axial Right Ankle. Observe the clear evidence of a minimally displaced fracture involving the medial aspect of the talar dome (arrow). COMMENT: This 20-year-old female presented with pain and swelling of her right ankle after a fall. The initial plain films (not shown) were read normal by an outside facility. CT of the ankle provides superior contrast resolution over plain film radiography and is particularly helpful in the evaluation of subtle fractures of the ankle. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, The Western States Chiropractic College, Portland, Oregon.)
Figure 6-182 BANKART’S FRACTURE: SHOULDER INSTABILITY. Bone Window CT, Double-Contrast Arthrogram, Axial Shoulder. Note the fracture and displacement of the anterior rim of the osseous glenoid and the cartilaginous labrum (arrow). COMMENT: This 25-year-old male sustained an injury in a rugby match and experienced pain and recurrent clicking in his shoulder. The Bankart’s lesion may also present without osseous insult. These injuries involve only the cartilaginous labrum and/or anterior capsule and require CT arthrography or MRI for visualization.
Figure 6-183 RETROISTHMIC DEFECT. Bone Window CT, Axial L5. Note the unilateral laminar defect (arrow). COMMENT: Incidentally, the owl’s eyes appearance is noted on the undersurface of the L5 vertebral endplate (arrowheads). This represents the paired parasagittal indentations from nuclear impression, a normal variant. This appearance should not be confused with pathology. (Courtesy of W. Michael Spurlock, DC, Morehead, Kentucky.)
P.607

Figure 6-184 MYOSITIS OSSIFICANS: A MISDIAGNOSIS. A. AP Humerus. Observe that the plain film radiograph demonstrates a poorly defined calcific mass (arrows) immediately adjacent to the humeral cortex. B. Bone Scan, Anterior Humerus. Note the markedly increased radionuclide activity in the soft tissues of the arm (arrow). COMMENT: This 67-year-old male patient presented with an enlarging mass in his left arm without a history of trauma. A biopsy was performed and suggested the presence of a sarcoma. An amputation was scheduled, but the patient fortunately sought a second opinion. C. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial Humerus. Note the increased density in the perimeter of the lesion (arrows) and relatively lucent center. This is the classic appearance of myositis ossificans post-traumatica, which does not require biopsy or amputation. D. T1-Weighted MRI, Coronal Humerus. Note the well-defined margins of the lesion (arrows) and lack of soft tissue invasion, indicating its benign nature. COMMENT: An appropriate diagnostic imaging protocol, with CT preceding scintigraphy, would have likely obviated biopsy and eliminated the reckless diagnosis of sarcoma and the threatened amputation. (Courtesy of James L. Quale, MD, Englewood, Colorado.)
P.608

Figure 6-185 SPONDYLODISCITIS: A DIABETIC WITH SEVERE BACK PAIN. A. Bone Window CT, Axial Lumbar Spine. B. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial Lumbar Spine. Note the widespread destruction of the vertebral body with paraspinal soft tissue extension. COMMENT: Spondylodiscitis usually occurs in the immunocompromised population, including diabetics, the elderly, and HIV patients.
The subtle osseous erosions and soft tissue abnormalities associated with infections of the sacroiliac and hip joints are also readily apparent with CT. Nuclear scintigraphy and MRI are often helpful in the complete assessment of suspected osteomyelitis.
Helical CT is valuable in determining which compartment is infected and the extent of the process. (7) With conventional CT, intramuscular pathology is often missed owing to the lack of differential enhancement between normal and abnormal tissue. Helical CT allows for scanning during the maximum enhancement levels, increasing lesion detection. (8)
Vascular Conditions
Aneurysms of the intracranial or intrathoracic vessels should be evaluated with CT (precontrast and postcontrast images are indicated if dissection or rupture is suspected). Abdominal aortic aneurysms are nicely displayed on CT; however, ultrasound is a more cost-effective and non-invasive method for obtaining virtually the same information. (Fig. 6-186) MRA is the diagnostic test of choice for examining muscle and soft tissue vascularity. However, in select cases, helical CT angiography has advantages. (Fig. 6-187) Helical CT is more economical and is not prone to the flow artifacts typical of MRI. (6)
Figure 6-186 ABDOMINAL AORTIC ANEURYSM. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial Abdomen. Note the pronounced aneurysmal dilatation of the abdominal aorta (arrow). Observe the atherosclerotic plaquing in the wall of the aneurysm (arrowhead). T, thrombus; L, lumen of the abdominal aorta. COMMENT: This elderly male presented with visible abdominal pulsations and focal prominence of the umbilicus. The variation in attenuation within the aneurysm is caused by peripheral thrombus formation and contrast-enhanced flowing blood. Incidentally, note the opacification of the bowel structures and ureters as a result of oral and intravenous contrast administration. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
Neoplasms
A complete description of the CT characteristics of musculoskeletal tumors is beyond the scope of this text. The purpose of this section is to emphasize the importance of CT in the diagnosis of some common benign and malignant neoplasms. CT is useful in further evaluating lesions seen on conventional radiographs and MRI scans as well as in the detection of neoplastic processes previously unseen in areas of overlapping anatomy, such as the vertebral column, pelvis, and facial skeleton. (Figs. 6-188 and 6-189)
Although MRI has replaced most indications for CT in the evaluation of soft tissue neoplasms, the osseous characteristics
P.609

and calcified regions of a neoplastic process are still best demonstrated by CT. (Fig. 6-190) For example, CT is valuable in determining whether matrix calcification and endosteal scalloping are present in a suspected chondroid or fibrous lesion. In addition, Hounsfield measurements provide helpful information concerning a lesion’s composition. Lipomas, for instance, have an attenuation value similar to subcutaneous fat, whereas aneurysmal bone cysts may exhibit a fluid-fluid level with differing Hounsfield values. Retinoblastomas often show matrix calcifications as a helpful hint to establishing the diagnosis. (Fig. 6-191) The reactive sclerosis surrounding an osteoid osteoma often obscures the lucent tumorous nidus, making the plain film diagnosis of this benign neoplasm difficult. (Fig. 6-192)
Figure 6-187 MULTIDETECTOR SPIRAL CT. Abdomen. Note the detailed visualization of the abdominal aortic aneurysm (arrow) relative to the adjacent and surrounding anatomy. COMMENT: Three-dimensional volumetric visualization of a pathology aids in preoperative planning. (Courtesy of Heart Check, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-188 PLASMACYTOMA: ILIUM. Bone Window CT, Axial Pelvis. Note the expansile osteolytic lesion in the marrow of the left ilium with no reactive sclerosis (arrow). This infiltrative lesion has produced endosteal erosion but has not violated the outer cortex. COMMENT: Plasmacytoma, the solitary form of multiple myeloma, usually presents in the pelvis, ribs, and proximal femur.
P.610

Figure 6-189 DENTIGEROUS CYST: MAXILLARY SINUS. A. Water’s Sinus View. Note the large soft tissue density occupying the left maxillary sinus and elevating the orbital floor (arrow). B. Bone Window CT, Sinus. Note the replacement of the normally air-filled left maxillary sinus by the soft tissue mass. There is obliteration of the maxillary sinus floor and medial expansion into the nasal cavity (arrows). Also observe the elevation of the orbital floor by the mass that contains a tooth (arrowhead). These findings are highly suggestive of a dentigerous cyst. COMMENT: Dentigerous cyst is the most common cyst to arise in the mandible and frequently includes a tooth. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, University Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
CT is better suited than any other imaging modality for providing a detailed assessment of the bony cortex, especially when overt findings of cortical neoplasm (including osteoid osteoma), bony expansion, periosteal reaction, or subtle fracture are present. Malignant bone tumors are typically characterized by bone destruction and an ill-defined soft tissue mass (more common in primary malignant bone tumors). (1) (Fig. 6-193) The use of intravenous contrast may help in determining the extension of the tumor. In cases of meningeal carcinomatosis or metastasis to the spine, MRI is the procedure of choice.
The nidus of osteoid osteoma is often small and not visualized on plain film. Helical CT reconstructions from contiguous volumetric data allow easy detection of the nidus, which is important for surgical excision. (15)
Congenital Conditions
CT can be used for the evaluation of congenital malformations, such as closure defects of the neural arch (e.g., spina bifida occulta and manifesta), cervical spondylolysis, and facet asymmetry. In addition, congenital spinal stenosis is well visualized with CT, which allows accurate measurement of the transverse and sagittal dimensions of the spinal canal. In achondroplasia the short, thickened pedicles and laminae are responsible for this stenosis, which is most apparent in the lower lumbar spine. Four normal spinal canal configurations have been described. (Fig. 6-194) In the lumbar spine, 10-20% of the normal population have the trefoil-shaped canal, which has a propensity to develop central or lateral recess stenosis.
Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is initially analyzed with real-time sonography and then followed with CT after casting or in unstable reductions. Because DDH is a diagnosis of childhood, helical CT is preferred because of its faster scan times. In addition, helical CT allows for quality 2D and 3D images of the femoral head’s relationship to the acetabulum. (15)
CT is the definitive diagnostic test for tarsal coalition to be used after plain film radiography. Tarsal coalition may result in rigid flatfoot or peroneal spasm in children. Therefore, the faster scan times of helical CT are essential when imaging children. (15)
Arthritides
The typical manifestations of degenerative joint disease in the peripheral articulations include asymmetric joint space narrowing, osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and cysts (geodes). These features are usually detectable on conventional plain films. CT provides a more accurate assessment of the degenerative changes in the spine and their relationship to the neural structures. Moreover, CT is particularly useful in assessing spinal canal and lateral recess stenosis.
Degenerative disease affects both the osseous and soft tissue components of the vertebral column. Frequently, degenerative stenosis results from a combination of hypertrophic changes that involve the intervertebral disc, discovertebral margin, apophyseal joints, and supporting ligaments. (Fig. 6-195) The bony changes (osteophytes) may be identified on radiographs, but their exact orientation and degree of encroachment into the canal are often not appreciated on plain films. Significant disc trauma often results in injury to the annular fibers and subsequent osteophyte formation.
P.611

This process generally requires at least 1 year, but more often 2 years or more are necessary before these changes are visible on plain films. Occasionally, earlier changes may be seen on CT. In addition, disc lesions (bulges, herniations) and ligament hypertrophy (PLL and ligamentum flavum) often play a major role in canal stenosis and remain undetectable on radiographs. (Fig. 6-196) For these reasons CT is more accurate than plain films in evaluating suspected spinal stenosis.
Figure 6-190 ANEURYSMAL BONE CYST: A MULTIMODALITY PERSPECTIVE. A. AP Pelvis. Note the expansile mass associated with a thin shell of cortical bone (arrow) arising from the right ischium. A component of the mass is seen displacing the pelvic soft tissues (arrowheads). B. Bone Scan, Posterior Pelvis. Note the increased radiotracer activity corresponding to the expansile mass in the region of the right ischium (arrow). C. Bone Window CT, Axial Pelvis. Observe the eccentrically positioned, destructive mass (arrows) arising from the right ischium with expansion into the pelvis. The articular cortex of the acetabulum is not violated by the tumor. D. T1-Weighted MRI, Coronal Pelvis. Observe the low signal intensity mass arising from the right ischium (arrow). This mass compresses the lateral wall of the bladder. COMMENT: This 11-year-old male presented with acute onset of right hip pain and was suddenly unable to bear weight. CT greatly enhances the ability to perceive the extent of significant pathology in flat bones. Plain film radiographs may fool the observer in regard to the actual size of the lesion. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
P.612

Figure 6-191 BILATERAL RETINOBLASTOMA: BRAIN. CT, Axial Brain. Note the well-defined high attenuation conglomerate calcified masses within the ocular globe bilaterally. Observe the proptosis on the right. COMMENT: This patient was 3 years old. Retinoblastoma is the most frequent intraocular malignancy of childhood. Approximately 30% of cases are bilateral; 25% are accompanied by tumor extension through the layers of the globe wall and along the optic nerve tissue plane. (Courtesy of Dennis Hulm, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 6-192 OSTEOID OSTEOMA: ELUSIVE NIDUS. A. Lateral Hip. Note the thickened medial cortex (arrow) in this 2-year-old male with hip pain. The nidus is not always visible on plain film, as in this case. B. Bone Scan, Anterior Pelvis. Note the focal increased uptake in the proximal right femur (arrow), representing the osteoid osteoma. C. Soft Tissue Window CT, Bilateral Axial Thigh. Observe the thickened cortex in the posterior right femur (arrow). COMMENT: Contiguous thin CT slices are required to locate the tiny lucent nidus of an osteoid osteoma (usually ≤ 1 cm). (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
P.613

Figure 6-193 HISTIOCYTIC LYMPHOMA: ILIUM. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial Pelvis. Note the cortical destruction and debris of the left posterolateral ilium (arrow). In addition, a soft tissue mass surrounds the left ilium (arrowheads). COMMENT: This 41-year-old male presented with pain and swelling of the left posterior pelvis.
Figure 6-194 NORMAL SPINAL CANAL CONFIGURATIONS. A. Oval. B. Triangular. C. Deltoid. D. Trefoil (Three-Leaf Clover). These configurations are normal but the possibility of lateral recess stenosis from parasagittal or far lateral disc herniation or degenerative stenosis is more frequently seen with the trefoil-shaped spinal canal. The oval-shaped canal is the most commonly seen in the cervical region. The triangular shape is the most common in the thoracic spine, and the deltoid and trefoil shapes are commonly seen in the lumbar region.
Figure 6-195 CENTRAL CANAL AND LATERAL RECESS STENOSIS. The axial projection of a lumbar vertebra at the level of the lateral recess is demonstrated. There is reduction of the AP diameter of the central canal by a bulging disc anteriorly and hypertrophic ligamentum flavum posteriorly. The nerve roots in the lateral recess are mechanically compressed by the degenerative changes arising from the posterior body and apophyseal joints.
In the lumbar region, spinal stenosis is suggested if the interpediculate distance is < 12 mm or if the area of the spinal canal, at the level of the pedicles, is < 1.5 cm2. (16) In the cervical spine, stenosis is present when the sagittal canal distance is ≤ 10 mm. (1) If clinical symptoms are not present, however, small canal diameter measurements alone are of little clinical significance.
CT images can also demonstrate changes that take place at the facet joints and at the lateral recess, resulting in spinal nerve root compression and radicular symptoms. (Fig. 6-197) The lateral recess is medial to the pedicle and posterior to the vertebral body. Its posterior border is the articular process. As the nerve root sleeve leaves the thecal sac, it passes through the lateral recess before it enters the intervertebral foramen (IVF). Frequently, facet imbrication from decreased disc height and hypertrophic facet disease act concurrently to create lateral recess and/or IVF encroachment. This has been referred to as up-down stenosis. (17) (Fig. 6-198)
In the cervical spine uncinate process osteophytes also contribute to narrow the IVF. (Fig. 6-199) Compression of the corresponding nerve is frequently seen on the axial and sagittally reformatted images as displacement or obliteration of the epidural fat surrounding the nerve root. Stenosis of the lateral recess is often associated with central spinal stenosis.
Patients with lateral recess stenosis of the lumbar spine (lateral nerve root entrapment syndrome) frequently present with symptoms of intermittent neurogenic claudication. The typical patient complains of back and leg pain that is initiated by walking or other weight-bearing activity. The leg pain is usually greater
P.614

than the back pain and is classically alleviated by sitting. This must be distinguished clinically from intermittent vascular claudication. Because the symptoms associated with both neurogenic and vascular claudication can begin with activity and abate with rest, their differentiation may be difficult. Lower extremity pain secondary to vascular claudication almost always begins and remains below the knee. Concurrent low back pain may also be present but is separate from the cause of the leg pain. Neurogenic claudication generally does not occur when the patient rides a stationary bike (because the spine is in slight flexion, increasing the spinal canal size), while vascular claudication manifests with any physical activity, independent of the position of the spine.
Figure 6-196 STENOSIS FROM LIGAMENTUM FLAVUM HYPERTROPHY. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial L3-L4. Observe that the thickened ligamentum flavum (arrows) and posterior disc bulge (arrowheads) narrow the central spinal canal. The thecal sac is compressed by the combined effects of these abnormalities (front-to-back stenosis).
Figure 6-197 DEGENERATIVE SPINAL STENOSIS. Bone Window CT, Axial L5-S1. Note the marked arthrosis of the apophyseal joints (arrows) leading to degenerative spondylolisthesis and central canal stenosis. Intradiscal gas (vacuum phenomenon) is also identified within the L5-S1 disc (arrowhead). COMMENT: Degenerative spondylolisthesis occurs in a small percentage of patients with degenerative disease of the vertebral column. Most patients with degenerative spondylolisthesis are identified by the three Fs: female, > 40 years old, at L4.
Figure 6-198 UP-DOWN STENOSIS. Note that the loss of disc height and hypertrophic degenerative changes of the superior articulating facet have reduced the osseous dimensions of the intervertebral foramen. The combination of these factors results in an increased likelihood of mechanical nerve root compression and lateral nerve entrapment syndrome.
Figure 6-199 NEUROFORAMINAL STENOSIS: A BONY CAUSE. Bone Window CT, Axial Cervical. Note the hypertrophic degenerative changes involving the right von Luschka’s joint (arrow) of this midcervical vertebral segment with resultant encroachment of the neural foramen. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
P.615

Figure 6-200 ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS: SACROILIAC JOINTS. Bone Window CT, Axial Sacrum. Note the widening of the left sacroiliac joint resulting from erosions along the articular surfaces of the ilium and sacrum (arrow). COMMENT: The early changes associated with the inflammatory arthropathies affecting the sacroiliac joints are better evaluated using CT because of its superior sensitivity over plain film radiography. CT is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating all pathologic abnormalities relating to the integrity of the sacroiliac joint. (Courtesy of Gary L. Boog, DC, Lancaster, New Hampshire.)
Inflammatory arthritides are often adequately evaluated on plain film radiography. A thorough clinical assessment, including a complete history and physical examination as well as appropriate laboratory tests, is necessary and will usually provide adequate information for the diagnosis. When the findings are inconclusive or equivocal, CT may be employed to assist in the diagnostic workup. CT is primarily used in this capacity to image the early erosive changes of sacroiliitis that occur most frequently in the seronegative spondyloarthropathies (ankylosing spondylitis, enteropathic spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, Reiter’s syndrome). (Fig. 6-200) Later these changes are accompanied by subchondral reactive sclerosis, gross marginal irregularity, and subsequent ankylosis.
Disc Herniation
Disc herniation is one of the frequent indications for a CT evaluation of the spine in communities where MRI is not available. Herniations generally occur at the posterior or posterolateral aspect of the annulus fibrosus, where the posterior longitudinal ligament is smallest and the annulus is thinnest. The attenuation of the herniated fragment is generally between 90 HU and 120 HU but may be as low as 60 HU. (18) The lack of epidural fat in the cervical and thoracic neural canal prohibits adequate CT visualization of disc herniations in those regions, unless intrathecal contrast is administered (CTM). Conversely, the abundance of fat in the lumbar spinal canal at L4-L5 and L5-S1 usually allows adequate soft tissue contrast for the diagnosis of disc herniation without prior intrathecal contrast injection. (Fig. 6-201)
Evaluation of the relationship of the protruding disc material to the nerve roots (including the dorsal root ganglion) in the lower lumbar spine is frequently possible with CT. MRI has replaced CT and CTM as the imaging modality of choice for disc herniations at any spinal region. The multiplanar capability, contrast resolution, and lack of harmful biologic effects, along with superior physiologic information regarding the bone marrow and disc hydration, have made MRI an indispensable modality in the diagnostic workup of most spinal pathologies.
Figure 6-201 CALCIFIED HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial L5-S1. Note the calcified disc fragment projecting from the left posterolateral margin of the L5 disc (arrow), which posteriorly displaces the adjacent S1 nerve root (arrowhead). COMMENT: This patient suffered from chronic low back pain and sciatica.
Bone Densitometry
Bone mineral density (BMD) values are necessary for predicting which patients with osteoporosis are at risk for spontaneous fracture of the weight-bearing skeleton. Quantitative computed tomography (qCT) can selectively measure the trabecular compartment of the vertebrae and is widely used for the assessment of BMD in patients with osteoporosis. It is also used to monitor changes in BMD during and after treatment. (19,20,21) Some reports have emphasized the superiority of qCT over PA dual x-ray absorptiometry (PA-DXA) in helping to discriminate between healthy women and those with osteoporosis. (19,22)
Medicolegal Implications
COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY
  • Caution should be exercised when using CT, as with any modality that uses ionizing radiation.
  • Overuse and inappropriate use should be avoided.
  • Patients with diabetes, renal compromise, and congestive heart failure should be cautiously evaluated before the administration of intravenous contrast.
  • Blood urea nitrogen and creatinine laboratory tests should be performed on every patient before the use of intravenous contrast. If these tests are abnormal, contrast infusion is contraindicated.
P.616

Figure 6-202 CT MYELOGRAM: NORMAL ANATOMY. Soft Tissue Window, Axial L5-S1. Note the contrast-filled nerve roots (arrows) and thecal sac (arrowhead). Note the normal rootlets, which are of relatively low attenuation compared with the contrast within the adjacent thecal sac. The spinal canal, neural foramina, and ligamentum flavum (crossed arrows) are normal. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
CT MYELOGRAPHY
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
In 1976 Ditcher and Steeling reported the value of water-soluble contrast in association with CT examination of the spine. (1) CTM delineates the borders of the thecal sac from adjacent soft tissue and bone. (Fig. 6-202) Evaluation of intradural pathology using CTM was a significant advancement in spinal imaging. Reconstructed images allow sagittal and/or coronal evaluation, producing a 3D perspective. CTM provides valuable information in the evaluation of degenerative disc disease, spinal stenosis, spinal cord or nerve root compression, and postoperative pain. However, the emergence of MRI as the diagnostic imaging modality of choice for spinal disorders continues to reduce the clinical utility of CTM and myelography.
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
The CTM examination is performed 4-6 hr after a lumbar myelogram and immediately after a cervical myelogram. (1) The time delay serves to dilute the concentration of the contrast within the subarachnoid space and varies considerably among radiology departments. A fixed number is not universally accepted, and may be as short as 2-3 hr. The patient is usually imaged in the prone position so that gravity layers the contrast within the subarachnoid space against the posterior vertebral body margin.
INDICATIONS
In the lumbar spine, CTM is useful in evaluating the nerve root sheaths, cauda equina, pathology of surrounding bone and joints (including spinal canal stenosis), and postoperative changes. (1,2) (Fig. 6-203) CTM of the cervical spine demonstrates the size and shape of the central canal and provides direct visualization of the thecal sac, spinal cord, and nerve root sleeves as well as the surrounding osseous and soft tissue anatomy. (Fig. 6-204)
Degenerative Joint Disease
Degenerative spinal stenosis is the primary clinical indication for CTM. The contrast resolution achieved with CT provides an accurate assessment of both the bony and soft tissue changes seen with degenerative spinal stenosis. With the addition of contrast medium the spinal cord and nerve roots and their relationship to the surrounding osteoligamentous structures are well delineated. (Fig. 6-205) Reformatted CTM images provide information regarding the size and shape of the neural foramina and filling of the nerve root sleeves.
Figure 6-203 CT MYELOGRAM: NORMAL ANATOMY. Bone Window, Axial L5. Note the normal contrast-filled thecal sac (TS). The relatively low attenuation nerve roots are noted in their normal lateral position. The S1 nerve roots (arrows) are seen within the lateral recess of the neural canal. The epidural venous plexus is seen along the posterior margin of the vertebral body (arrowheads).
P.617

Herniated Nucleus Pulposus
Disc herniations may result in distortion and displacement of the epidural fat, thecal sac, spinal cord, and nerve roots. Axial CT without contrast, however, does not provide optimal distinctive resolution among these structures, particularly in the cervical and thoracic regions. The introduction of intrathecal contrast allows improved or complete filling of a nerve root sleeve and enhancement of the internal margin of the thecal sac. (Fig. 6-206) Although improved resolution by means of intrathecal contrast greatly increases the diagnostic accuracy over plain CT, the evaluation of radiculopathy secondary to disc herniation in both the lumbar and the cervical spine is best imaged by MRI. The use of CT myelography for the evaluation of disc herniation will likely evolve into a supplemental role, employed only when MRI or plain CT is equivocal or contraindicated. (Figs. 6-207 and 6-208)
Figure 6-204 CT MYELOGRAM: NORMAL ANATOMY. Soft Tissue Window, Axial Cervical Spine. Observe the normally rounded appearance of the contrast-filled thecal sac (arrow). The contrast agent completely fills the subarachnoid space and surrounds the spinal cord (arrowhead).
Figure 6-205 CENTRAL AND LATERAL RECESS STENOSIS. A. Myelogram, AP Lumbar Spine. Note the symmetric extradural compression of the thecal sac producing an hourglass deformity at L4-L5 (arrow). B. Bone Window CT Myelogram, Axial Lumbar Spine. Observe the marked hypertrophic degenerative changes in the apophyseal joints (arrows) resulting in encroachment and deformity of the thecal sac (TS).
Inflammatory and Neoplastic Disorders
Inflammatory and neoplastic disorders may also be assessed with CTM. Intradural inflammation is known as arachnoiditis and is often associated with postsurgical intradural scar tissue. The characteristic adhesion or clumping of nerve roots is well visualized with CTM.
Just as CTM replaced myelography as the initial diagnostic examination for intraspinal tumors, MRI is now the imaging modality of choice in diagnosing and monitoring these neoplasms. The capacity of MRI to accurately define extradural and intradural pathology is widely recognized. See the MRI sections of this chapter for additional discussion.
P.618

Figure 6-206 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. A. Pathology: Soft Tissue Window CT Myelogram, Axial Cervical Spine. Observe the ventral deflection of the dura by a paramidline disc herniation (arrow). B. Normal Anatomy: Soft Tissue Window CT Myelogram, Axial Cervical Spine. Note the normal volume of subarachnoid space surrounding the spinal cord and the apposition of the dura and posterior vertebral body. COMMENT: The CT myelogram is often performed with the patient prone to approximate the thecal sac to the vertebral body. This posture enhances the detection of subtle disc lesions.
Figure 6-207 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. A. Myelogram, PA Cervical Spine. Note the unilateral nerve root filling defect on the right at C7-T1 (arrow). B. Bone Window CT Myelogram, Axial C7-T1. Observe the extradural effacement of the thecal sac on the right produced by the disc herniation (arrow).
P.619

Figure 6-208 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. A. Myelogram, PA Lumbosacral. Note the poor filling of the left S1 nerve sheath (arrow). B. Soft Tissue Window CT Myelogram, Axial L5-S1. Note the posterior displacement and reduced filling of the left S1 nerve root sheath (arrow) as a result of the posterolateral disc herniation (arrowhead). COMMENT: This patient experienced low back pain with radiation into the left lower extremity. The Achilles deep tendon reflex was absent on the left. (Courtesy of Leonard A. Suiter, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Nerve Root Avulsion
Nerve root avulsions most frequently involve the lower cervical nerve roots and result from a severe force directed to the neck and shoulder region. Two paralysis patterns have classically been described with nerve root avulsions: Erb-Duchenne paralysis involving the C5-C6 nerve roots and Klumpke’s paralysis involving the C7-C8 nerve roots. These conditions are best evaluated with CTM using sagittal and coronal reformatted images. After the injection of intrathecal contrast, extravasation from the torn nerve root sleeve is observed. Often, the nerve root is avulsed from the spinal cord and is no longer present within its dural sleeve. (3)
MYELOGRAPHY
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
The workhorse of specialized spinal imaging before the evolution of CT and MRI was plain film myelography. Myelography provided indirect visualization of spinal canal contents by introducing a radiographic contrast agent into the subarachnoid space. Use of a positive or negative (gas) contrast agent allowed indirect assessment of the thecal sac, nerve roots, and spinal cord contours. Effacement or compression of these contrast-filled tracts may be caused by any of numerous space- occupying lesions, including disc herniation, tumor, hematoma, osteophyte, inflammation, and developmental anomaly.
Plain film myelography remained the mainstay of specialized spinal imaging for > 50 years. Dandy (1) first introduced air into the subarachnoid space as a contrast agent in 1919. In 1922 Sicard and Forestier (2), while treating sciatica with an iodized oil (lipiodol), accidentally injected the agent into the subarachnoid space. This is thought to be the first reported myelogram, albeit inadvertent. Mixter and Barr (3) used lipiodol myelography for the preoperative localization of lesions and assessment of spinal pain. They were the first to report on the clinical significance of the intervertebral disc herniation using this imaging technique. The untoward effects of intrathecal lipiodol (which included meningeal irritation and arachnoiditis) prompted the search for a safer contrast agent.
In the early 1940s iophendylate (Pantopaque) was developed. It was less viscous and less toxic than lipiodol and soon became the contrast agent of choice for myelographic examinations over the next 30 years. Although this new contrast material was less viscous than its predecessors, it was still of a high enough density to obscure dural defects, preventing their recognition on the PA projection. (4)
Although severe acute reactions were unusual with Pantopaque, arachnoiditis and, more frequently, headache, nausea, and vomiting were associated with its use. (5) After the completion of the examination it was necessary to mechanically remove this agent from the subarachnoid space. Invariably, not all of the contrast agent was extracted, creating the potential for continued toxic reactions to this foreign material.
P.620

The first non-ionic water-soluble contrast agent (metrizamide; Amipaque) was introduced in the late 1970s. Meningeal irritation was far less common with this agent. Second-generation, water-soluble agents—for example, iohexol (Omnipaque) and iopamidol (Isovue)—replaced metrizamide in the late 1980s and have proven to be less toxic to the CNS. Use of room air or carbon dioxide as a myelographic contrast agent has been largely abandoned. (6)
Non-ionic, water-soluble agents are currently employed for intrathecal contrast imaging. Overall, a significant reduction in morbidity has been realized through the use of the newer agents. (7) Contrast medium is introduced through small needles and is completely eliminated by transarachnoid diffusion into the blood stream and renal excretion. Partial removal of the contrast agent has been recommended, but most clinicians do not believe this is necessary.
