(8) Severe adverse reactions such as seizures, hallucinations, and confusion are rare, occurring far less frequently than with metrizamide. Mild transient side effects, including headaches, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness, are common in patients undergoing cervical myelography using iohexol (Omnipaque). Bedrest with the head raised is recommended when adverse postmyelographic reactions are reported. Another important advantage of modern water-soluble agents is the better radiographic definition of the nerve root sleeves and intra-arachnoid structures.
The disadvantages of myelography have been its invasiveness and lack of diagnostic specificity, caused by the nature of myelographic pattern detection. Myelography displays neural compression indirectly via changes in the contour of the contrast-filled subarachnoid space. The specific nature of a compressive or adhesive process requires additional diagnostic differentiation. CT or MRI is necessary to characterize the specific nature of the pathology.
Patients who undergo myelography should be encouraged to increase their fluid intake before the examination. Depending on when the examination is scheduled, meals may be restricted. Premedication is generally not required, unless a large dose of contrast material is required or there is a seizure history. Evaluation of the bleeding time, prothrombin time, and partial thromboplastin time is necessary within 2 weeks of the myelogram. Abnormal coagulation is a contraindication to lumbar puncture. (6)
Following the examination, the patient is placed on bedrest with the head elevated for 3-4 hr. This allows the contrast medium to be absorbed. If CT scanning is scheduled after myelography, it will typically be delayed 3-5 hr. In addition to patient safety and comfort, the delay reduces the concentration of intrathecal contrast medium, thereby improving visualization of intra-arachnoid structures. All patients undergoing myelography are placed in observation for at least 6 hr after the examination to monitor untoward effects. (9) There has recently been a trend in imaging centers and hospitals to perform outpatient myelograms. Although the risks and adverse reactions have been dramatically reduced, some risks remain and patients should be kept under observation for a 24-hr period.
The frequency of myelographic examinations has markedly diminished. For nerve root, spinal cord, and cauda equina examinations, myelography has been largely supplanted by CT and MRI.
Glossary
arachnoiditis
Inflammation of the meningeal covering of the spinal cord. A potential complication of the myelographic examination, the incidence of arachnoiditis has decreased with the introduction of modern non-ionic water-soluble agents.
contrast agent
A substance that provides radiographic contrast. In myelography, contrast is injected into the subarachnoid space of the spinal cord. Modern contrast agents are non-ionic and water-soluble. Unlike their fat-soluble predecessors, newer agents diffuse into the vascular system and are excreted through the kidneys, reducing CNS toxicity.
extradural pattern
A myelographic pattern produced by pathologies that impress or indent the dural membrane. A variety of causes, including disc herniation, osteophyte, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, hematoma, abscess, and neoplasm, may produce this appearance. A high-grade extradural block may completely obstruct the flow of contrast through the subarachnoid space.
intradural extramedullary pattern
A myelographic pattern produced by a lesion that arises in the subarachnoid space. The mass is displayed as a round, well-defined defect in the contrast column. The spinal cord is typically displaced.
intradural intramedullary pattern
A myelographic pattern produced by a lesion that arises within the substance of the spinal cord. For this pattern to be visualized, the spinal cord must be enlarged. Often, gradual tapering and narrowing of the contrast column is observed. Ependymoma and astrocytoma are the most common lesions that produce this pattern.
intrathecal
Synonymous with subarachnoid space. This potential space lies between the arachnoid and the pia mater. Contrast injected into this space mixes with CSF and allows the contours of the spinal cord and nerve root sleeves to be visualized.
lumbar puncture
The preliminary procedure performed before introduction of the myelographic agent. Approximately 15 mL of CSF is withdrawn, and contrast is then injected. A needle enters the subarachnoid space between the L2 and L3 or L3 and L4 levels.
myelography
A radiographic examination that introduces positive contrast into the subarachnoid space via a lumbar or cervical puncture. This procedure allows visualization of the inner margin of the thecal sac and nerve root sheaths. Fluoroscopy is used to assess the characteristics of the contrast column. Appropriate radiographic projections are then obtained in the region of interest. After myelography, CT is performed to obtain additional detail and contrast.
water-soluble contrast
A contrast agent that is non-ionic and displays lower osmolality because it does not undergo ionic dissociation (Omnipaque and Isovue). These agents are considerably less neurotoxic than their fat-soluble predecessors (Pantopaque).
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
Myelographic techniques require the injection of a contrast agent into the subarachnoid space by either a lumbar puncture (usually at L2-L3 or L3-L4) or a lateral cervical puncture with the spinal needle inserted at the C1-C2 level. (1) The needle is inserted under fluoroscopic guidance to confirm its position. The stylet is then removed to check for return of CSF. A small amount of CSF is obtained and sent for analysis. Fluoroscopy is used to visualize the myelographic contrast agent as it is slowly injected into the subarachnoid space. For the lumbar puncture the table may be tilted in a head-down direction, causing the contrast to flow to the thoracic and cervical regions.
P.621

Radiographs of the lumbar region are obtained in the prone, lateral decubitus, and oblique positions (steep and shallow angulation). AP, lateral, oblique, and swimmer’s lateral views of the cervical and upper thoracic spine are performed when the contrast column is directed into this area. The accidental introduction of contrast into the brain may occur when the table is tilted head-down and should be avoided because it increases the incidence of adverse reactions. (2)
INDICATIONS
Clinical indications for myelography include the unavailability of CT or MRI, multilevel stenosis, and multilevel spinal disease. Currently, suspicion of disc herniation is not a clinical indication for myelography.
The Abnormal Myelogram
Myelography delineates the inner margin of the thecal sac throughout the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine. The spinal cord size, shape, and position are outlined by the contrast column. The size, course, and configuration of dural root sleeves are also delineated. Variations in normal anatomy, such as asymmetry and deformity of the thecal sac, permit localization of space-occupying lesions to one of three anatomic areas: extradural, intradural extramedullary, and intradural intramedullary. Lesion classification by location within the spinal canal is necessary to arrive at a reasonable differential diagnosis.
Lesions
Extradural.
Extradural lesions reside outside the thecal sac but within the bony confines of the neural canal. (Fig. 6-209) They produce a pattern of dural compression and, with extensive deformity, complete obstruction. (Fig. 6-210) The most common cause of the extradural defect is intervertebral disc herniation. (Figs. 6-211 and 6-212) Other extradural pathologies include posteriorly oriented degenerative osteophytes, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, hematoma, metastasis, and abscess. (Fig. 6-213)
Figure 6-209 EXTRADURAL LESION. Note the deformation and indentation of the dural membrane from an extradural source. The spinal cord may be displaced. Causes producing this pattern include disc herniation, degenerative stenosis, spinal tumor, hematoma, and abscess.
Intradural Extramedullary.
Intradural extramedullary lesions exist within the dura but outside the spinal cord. (Fig. 6-214) Most of these lesions are benign tumors of neurogenic origin, most commonly neurofibroma (Fig. 6-215) and meningioma. (Fig. 6-216) Intradural extramedullary tumors are seen as intraspinal masses
P.622

within the thecal sac, compressing and contralaterally displacing the spinal cord.
Figure 6-210 MULTIPLE MYELOMA: A PATHOLOGIC FRACTURE. A. Myelogram, Lateral Thoracic Spine. Note the mild compression deformity of the superior endplate of T7 and the adjacent complete extradural obstruction of the myelographic column. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Observe the decreased signal intensity (arrow) in association with a mild compression deformity of the vertebral body. In addition there is mild ventral and dorsal expansion of the vertebral body, which has produced the extradural compression noted in panel A. A paraspinal soft tissue mass, which was proven to be myeloma, is noted anterior to the fracture (arrowhead). COMMENT: This elderly male complained of midthoracic pain that was worse at night.
Figure 6-211 HERNIATION OF THE C6-C7 NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. Myelogram, Oblique Cervical Spine. Observe the ventral defect in the myelographic contrast column, the result of a herniated disc at C6-C7 (arrow). COMMENT: Extradural defects most commonly arise as a result of osteophyte or disc herniation.
Figure 6-212 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS. A. Myelogram, Left Posterior Oblique Lumbar Spine. Observe the abrupt termination of the contrast-filled left S1 nerve root at the level of the L5-S1 disc (arrow), indicating a herniation. B. Myelogram, Right Posterior Oblique Lumbar Spine. The normal, contrast-filled right S1 nerve root (arrow) is shown for comparison. COMMENT: In patients with a large spinal canal, the sensitivity of myelography is diminished. The dura in these individuals does not closely approximate the herniation; therefore, the contrast column is not compressed.
Figure 6-213 EXTRADURAL OBSTRUCTION: METASTATIC CARCINOMA. Myelogram, AP Thoracic Spine. Note the absence of the left T10 pedicle (arrow) and high-grade obstruction of the myelographic column (arrowheads). COMMENT: This elderly male presented with a Brown-Sequard syndrome. At surgery, the extradural space was filled with metastatic tumor, resulting in complete obstruction of the subarachnoid space.
Figure 6-214 INTRADURAL EXTRAMEDULLARY LESION. There is a well-defined lesion in the subarachnoid space. Observe the displacement of the spinal cord from the intradural lesion. This pattern is observed with neural tumors such as meningioma and neurofibroma.
P.623

Figure 6-215 SCHWANNOMA: DISC HERNIATION LOOK-ALIKE. A. Myelogram, AP Lumbosacral. Note the large extradural defect at the L4-L5 level (arrow). B. Soft Tissue Window, CT Myelogram, Axial Lumbar Spine. Note the large, smoothly marginated, extradural mass that slightly expands the L4-L5 neural foramen (arrow) and deforms the contrast-filled thecal sac (arrowhead). C. T1-Weighted MRI, Coronal Lumbar Spine. Observe the homogeneous intermediate signal intensity mass (arrow) deflecting the thecal sac toward the midline. These findings are consistent with an extradural schwannoma. COMMENT: Schwannomas, as well as the other tumors of the nerve sheath, may erode bone and enlarge the intervertebral foramen.
Intradural Intramedullary.
Intradural intramedullary lesions represent the third classic myelographic pattern. (Fig. 6-217) The most common malignant neoplasms, astrocytoma and ependymoma, are frequently seen in the thoracic region. Ependymomas of the filum terminale, lipomas, and syrinx may also present with this abnormal myelographic pattern and demonstrate localized fusiform expansion of the spinal cord with thinning and spreading of the contrast column along the lateral margins of the cord. (Fig. 6-218) If the lesion produces complete obstruction, cervical instillation of contrast may be necessary to outline the upper level of the lesion. (1) Difficulty may be encountered in distinguishing intramedullary from extramedullary lesions, particularly when the latter results in bulging of the cord or obstruction within the canal. Currently, complete obstructions are unusual because the water-based contrast agents tend to diffuse past an obstructive lesion.
Today, myelography plays a minor role in spinal imaging. It is relegated to patient evaluation when MRI is equivocal or cannot be performed. It enhances the accuracy of CT, and when they are combined, the resulting examination is termed CTM. (2) CTM is still employed for the evaluation of suspected arachnoiditis. Patients presenting with a clinical picture suggesting a cervical, thoracic, or lumbar disc herniation should no longer initially undergo myelography but instead should be evaluated with MRI. The rapid and clinically powerful advances in non-invasive imaging procedures will continue to benefit spinal imaging into the foreseeable future.
Medicolegal Implications
MYELOGRAPHY
  • Myelography is contraindicated in individuals who are being treated with tricyclic antidepressants, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, and phenothiazine medications. These patients should be referred for MRI.
  • Patients with a history of seizures require prophylactic medication before the examination.
  • This procedure is contraindicated in patients who exhibit clinical signs of dehydration. All patients should be encouraged to increase fluid consumption 12 hr before the examination to ensure that they are well hydrated. This helps diminish the neurotoxic effects of the contrast.
  • Improper injection techniques may produce nerve root injury, arachnoiditis, pulmonary oil emboli, epidermoid formation, or perforation of the annulus fibrosus (and subsequent disc herniation).
  • Headaches, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting are common adverse reactions that subside with time.
  • Meningitis-like symptoms, radiculitis, hyperreflexia, and cerebral or spinocerebellar symptoms (seizures, CNS ischemia, and visual and auditory changes) may occur because of the neurotoxic effects of the contrast.
  • All patients should be screened for iodine sensitivity before the examination.
P.624

Figure 6-216 MULTIPLE MENINGIOMAS. A. Myelogram, Lateral Thoracic Spine. Note the well-defined intradural filling defects at two levels in the thoracic spine (arrows). B. Contrast-Enhanced T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Thoracic Spine. Observe the mild hyperintense signal of the intradural masses within the thoracic spinal cord (arrows). COMMENT: Meningioma and neurofibroma are the most common intradural extramedullary neoplasms. Meningiomas seldom erode pedicles or vertebral bodies. The absence of these findings may help differentiate meningioma from neurofibroma.
Figure 6-217 INTRADURAL INTRAMEDULLARY LESION. Note the diffuse enlargement of the spinal cord with bilateral tapering and narrowing of the contrast column surrounding the lesion. Conditions that produce this pattern include astrocytoma, ependymoma, arteriovenous malformation, and syrinx. These lesions are best demonstrated on AP or PA views.
P.625

Figure 6-218 SYRINGOMYELIA: SHAWL-LIKE SENSORY LOSS. Myelogram, AP Cervicodorsal. Note the symmetric tapering (arrows) of the contrast column from the lower cervical spine extending to the upper thoracic region. This was the result of an enlarged spinal cord secondary to a congenital syrinx. COMMENT: This 34-year-old female had a 5-year history of recurrent right glenohumeral joint dislocation. Syrinx of the cervical cord may result in a neurotrophic arthropathy of the glenohumeral joints with subsequent instability. (Courtesy of Paul H. Young, MD, St. Louis, Missouri.)
DISCOGRAPHY
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
The application of discography in the diagnosis of low back pain syndromes was first described by Hirsch (1) and Lindblom (2) in 1948. Injecting contrast into the nucleus of cadaveric discs demonstrated annular changes in the form of radial tears. Falconer et al. (3) and Erlacher (4) described pain provocation with stimulation of the intervertebral disc. Fernstrom stressed both neurogenic (compressive) and discogenic (inflammatory) causes of back and leg pain. (5)
Discography is an imaging technique that evaluates the integrity of the intervertebral disc. This examination assesses the morphology and physiology of the disc by injecting water-soluble contrast material into the nucleus pulposus. It is particularly useful in evaluating patients when surgery is contemplated for lumbar spine pain and/or radiculopathy and coupled with negative or equivocal CT or MRI examinations. Discography in the cervical spine is limited because of its unreliable results. (6) Fernstrom concluded that discography was valuable in evaluating patients who had spinal pain without evidence of disc herniation. (5)
Glossary
annular fissure
Interruption or tear of the annulus fibrosus that occurs as a result of trauma or disc degeneration.
CT discography
The combination of discography with CT provides a more accurate assessment of intradiscal contrast distribution.
discogram
A contrast examination that is performed by injecting a small volume of contrast agent into the nucleus pulposus. The morphology of the nucleus pulposus is indirectly evaluated and correlated with the patient’s clinical response to the injection. When the patient’s clinical symptoms are reproduced during injection of either the contrast or saline, the examination is provocation positive, hence the term provocational discogram.
extravasation
The escape of a material from a site or compartment. In discography this refers to the escape of radiopaque contrast from the confines of the disc.
THE INTERVERTEBRAL DISC
The intervertebral disc provides the dual function of structural support and articular mobility. To accommodate these tasks, a variety of histologic tissues must be integrated. The dense collagen fibers and fibrocartilage of the annulus fibrosus surrounds the centrally positioned nucleus pulposus and inserts into the hyaline cartilage of the vertebral endplate. Along the periphery these fibers (Sharpey’s fibers) attach directly into the cortical bone of the endplate.
The biomechanical behavior of the intervertebral disc is related to its hydration status. (1) The factors responsible for age-related changes within the disc are related to its biochemical constituents. Aging results in a decline in the proteoglycan concentration and an increase in the ratio of keratin sulfate to chondroitin sulfate. As the collagen and the collagen-proteoglycan binding of the nucleus pulposus increases, a decline in the water-binding capacity occurs, resulting in a dehydrated, fibrous, and rigid intervertebral disc. (2) These biochemical imbalances lead to a functionally impaired disc that exhibits altered load distribution through its individual components (nucleus pulposus and annulus fibrosus). Even the normal repetitive forces initiated by the activities of daily living produce cartilage fibrillation and annular fissuring. Through these tears the nucleus pulposus may progressively migrate toward the perimeter of the annulus and provoke pain. When fissures extend to the outer margin of the annulus fibrosus, herniation of the nucleus pulposus may follow. A variety of factors, including the speed of degeneration, the extent of annular fissuring and healing, and the magnitude of weight-bearing loads, affect the extent of the herniation. (3)
P.626

Bogduk and Twomey (2) proposed that disc-space narrowing is a consequence of nuclear degradation following endplate fracture. Microfractures deform the endplate of the vertebral body and interrupt the vascular channels that deliver nutrients to the endplate and disc. Endplate fractures may also initiate an autoimmune response, further degrading the nuclear matrix.
Pathogenesis of Disc Pain
The origin of low back pain is not explained simply on the basis of disc herniation and nerve root compression. Disc herniation may be the causative factor in only 5% of low back pain complaints. (4) There is a growing recognition that herniations and other disruptive disc lesions, as well as spinal cord and nerve root compression, may remain asymptomatic. (5,6) A direct causeand-effect relationship between annular tears and pain provocation is yet to be established because radial tears are common in asymptomatic individuals and may be age related. (7)
Pain fibers have been identified in the outer third of the posterior annular fibers of lumbar discs. Wiberg (8) demonstrated that pressure on the posterior annular fibers could provoke back pain. Coppes et al. (9) showed nerve fibers in the nucleus pulposus of degenerated discs. New models of back pain emphasize chemical mediators. Proinflammatory by-products from the intervertebral disc such as phospholipase A2 may initiate an inflammatory reaction in the annulus, sensitizing the surrounding tissues, including the disc and dorsal root ganglion. These inflammatory mediators may trigger a chemical neuritis, even in the absence of visible neurologic compression. (10,11) Nociceptive activity, however, cannot be elicited by mechanical stimulation without previous damage to the nerve root. (12) Pain arising in association with the nerve roots occurs in a narrow band and is characteristically sharp, lancinating, and frequently associated with paresthesia. In contrast, somatic pain arising from joints, muscles, ligaments, and the intervertebral disc produces dull and poorly localized pain in the back, pelvis, and thigh. (2)
Figure 6-219 DISCOGRAM: NORMAL ANATOMY. A. AP Lumbar Spine. B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the opacification of the nucleus pulposus of the L3-L5 discs.
Jinkins (13) described a vertebrogenic syndrome consisting of local and referred pain, radicular pain and paresthesia, autonomic reflex alterations, muscular dysfunction, and altered viscerosomatic reflexes. He has suggested that the efferent autonomic fibers drive afferent pain fibers, resulting in referred pain and dysfunction.
A comprehensive understanding of the role that the intervertebral disc plays in spinal and radicular pain remains elusive. Because of this, the invasive nature of discography and its true utility in back pain patients is still disputed, despite periodic resurgence.
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
Patients selected for discographic examination are evaluated using fluoroscopy. The region of interest is prepped and draped. The asymptomatic or less symptomatic side is selected for injection. After local anesthesia the initial spinal needle is advanced using fluoroscopic guidance until it penetrates the annulus and enters the disc substance. A smaller needle is then inserted through the larger needle. Once the smaller needle is in position, normal saline is injected and the volume is recorded. After the saline injection, water-soluble contrast is injected into the disc. The radiographic appearance of the discogram and the presence or absence of a pain response is noted. (1)
CT performed after discography provides a high-resolution assessment of intradiscal herniation routes, sites of maximal protrusion, and herniation size. (2)
P.627

INDICATIONS
Clinical indications for discography include the need for definitively establishing the presence of discogenic pain and isolating a specific symptomatic level. An additional application is the end stage evaluation of a complex spinal complaint that is being considered for surgical intervention.
The Abnormal Discogram
The normal contrast-filled nucleus pulposus appears with an amorphous unilocular, bilocular, or double-wafer configuration. (Fig. 6-219) These patterns are usually confined to a central or slightly posterior location within the disc space but may be altered slightly, depending on the patient’s position. (1) (Fig. 6-220) Discograms are considered abnormal when morphologic changes within the disc are observed or when the injection of either saline or contrast provokes a pain response (provocative discogram). (Fig. 6-221)
The diagnostic significance of this response is confirmed when symptoms are relieved after injection of local anesthetic into the disc. Dissection and annular disruption are observed when the contrast escapes the confines of the nuclear area extending anteriorly, posteriorly (Fig. 6-222), or through intraosseous routes into the vertebral body (Schmorl’s nodes). Reproduction of the patient’s pain pattern on pressurization of the disc is a key finding that, when elicited, provides physiologic information concerning a specific level of spinal anatomy, often correlating with the patient’s clinical
P.628

findings. This pain response is positive and significant even in structurally intact discs.
Figure 6-220 DISCOGRAM: NORMAL VERSUS ABNORMAL ANATOMY. A. Normal Lateral Projection. The normal appearance of the contrast-filled nucleus pulposus is shown. The upper two discs demonstrate the biocular pattern, characterized by two horizontal bars connected vertically. The lower disc reveals a nuclear pattern, which is homogeneous and amorphous. B. Abnormal Lateral Projection. A series of contrast-filled abnormal discs is shown. The upper disc displays flattening of the nucleus with posterior extension of contrast, consistent with a minimal herniation. The lower nucleus pulposus is flattened and depicts complete bidirectional dissection through annular fissures, a finding characteristic of disc degeneration.
Figure 6-221 HERNIATED NUCLEUS PULPOSUS: L4-L5. A. Myelogram, PA Lumbar Spine. Note the extradural defects on the lateral margins of the contrast column that have amputated the exiting nerve root sleeves (arrows). B. Myelogram, Lateral Lumbar Spine. Observe the extradural compression of the ventral margin of the contrast column immediately posterior to the L4-L5 disc space that ascends posteriorly along the L4 vertebral body (arrow). C. Discogram, PA L5-S1. Note that the contrast material injected through the centrally positioned needle tip has extravasated posterolaterally (arrow). (Courtesy of Robert L. Mattin, DC, Perth, Western Australia, Australia.)
Figure 6-222 SUBTRACTION DISCOGRAM: DEGENERATIVE DISC DISEASE. A. AP Lumbar Spine. B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the marked posterior migration of the discographic agent into the posterior annular fibers of the L5-S1 disc (arrow). This finding represents discal degeneration. COMMENT: The injection of saline during discography may provoke pain similar, or identical, to the patient’s chief complaint (provocational discogram). Further confirmatory evidence of a specific level of discogenic pain is obtained if symptoms diminish with injection of an anesthetic agent. Often multiple discograms are necessary to determine the level(s) and extent of surgical intervention necessary. This modality is unique in that it provides both morphologic information and clinical correlation. (Courtesy of James M. Cox, DC, DACBR, Fort Wayne, Indiana.)
In the past discography was occasionally performed before spinal arthrodesis to evaluate the integrity of the discs adjacent to the fusion level. (2) MRI has replaced discography in this capacity because MRI is capable of providing this information non-invasively.
Vanharanta et al. (2) classified CT discograms into four grades of nuclear penetration. (Fig. 6-223) Radial fissures that penetrate the outer third of the posterior annulus are more likely to stimulate nociceptive nerve endings and become symptomatic on injection of discographic contrast. (3) (Fig. 6-224)
The enormous diagnostic challenge of assessing spinal pain syndromes is assisted by discography, especially when coupled with CT. (Fig. 6-225) In a reasonably safe and reliable manner, discography provides a unique anatomic and physiologic description of the disc.
Medicolegal Implications
DISCOGRAPHY
  • Septic spondylitis may occur if a sterile field is not maintained during this procedure.
  • All patients should be screened for iodine sensitivity before the examination.
Figure 6-223 CT DISCOGRAM: NORMAL ANATOMY. Bone Window, Axial Lumbar Spine. The nucleus pulposus is normal in both its position and appearance (arrows). This image demonstrates no evidence of annular tear or dissection of the nucleus pulposus. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Wood River Memorial Township Hospital, Wood River, Illinois.)
P.629

Figure 6-224 CT DISCOGRAM: ANTERIOR DISC HERNIATION. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the internal disruption of the L3-L4 annular fibers with dissection of the contrast agent (arrow) to the anterior margin of the disc. B. Soft Tissue Window, Axial L3-L4. Observe the anterior herniation of nuclear material at the L3-L4 level, with contrast dissecting underneath the anterior longitudinal ligament (arrows). COMMENT: This 33-year-old female experienced low back and anterior leg pain. (Courtesy of James M. Cox, DC, DACBR, Fort Wayne, Indiana.)
Figure 6-225 RECURRENT LOW BACK PAIN: DISC VERSUS POSTSURGICAL SCAR. A. T2-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the loss of the normal disc signal intensity at L4-L5 and the small posterior disc herniation (arrow).
P.630

Figure 6-225 (continued) B. T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Lumbar Spine. C. Contrast-Enhanced T1-Weighted MRI, Axial Lumbar Spine. Note the small, central, contained disc herniation at L4-L5, which demonstrates minimal enhancement on the postcontrast image (arrows). D. Discogram, AP. E. Discogram Lateral. Upon injection of the contrast into the L4-L5 disc space, the patient experienced localized back pain identical to her chief complaint. Note the extravasation of the contrast posterior to the vertebral margins (arrow). The intradiscal contrast also extends laterally and anteriorly to the peripheral annular fibers. F. Bone Window CT Discogram. G. Soft Tissue Window CT Discogram. Note the contrast extending anteriorly to the outer annular fibers (arrow) and posteriorly beyond the posterior vertebral margins (arrowheads), abutting the ventral aspect of the thecal sac. COMMENT: This patient underwent a discectomy and laminectomy (crossed arrow) at L4-L5 4 years earlier. This case nicely demonstrates the use of discography. When MRI is equivocal or does not display information that correlates with the patient’s symptoms, a discogram is often employed to determine whether a given disc abnormality is the exact cause of the patient’s symptoms. (Courtesy of Donald E. Freuden, DC, DABCO, Denver, Colorado.)
P.631

ULTRASOUND
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
Ultrasound is based on the sonar technology developed in the 1950s for use by the military. Originally, ultrasound could achieve only a single dimension, but as the technology advanced, 2D studies, 3D studies, and real-time motion can be displayed. The use of ultrasound for evaluation of the musculoskeletal system came about in the late 1970s. Now, ultrasound is the second most commonly used imaging modality after plain film radiography. (1)
Glossary
anechoic
No echo is received by the transducer. The image is black.
hyperechoic
Bright or white image. The signal received by the transducer is received from a tissue with high sound impedance, resulting in maximum reflection.
hypoechoic
Dark image. The signal received by the transducer is received from a tissue with low sound impedance, resulting in minimal reflection.
isoechoic
Different tissues in an image demonstrating similar sound impedance and reflection, resulting in a similar image.
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
Diagnostic ultrasound uses a transducer to emit high-frequency sound waves and receive the reflected echo. The lower the frequency used, the deeper the tissue penetration at the expense of resolution. Higher frequencies do not penetrate as deep but have better image resolution. For most musculoskeletal uses a 7.5-MHz transducer is adequate. Higher frequency probes (7-13 MHz) are used to evaluate subcutaneous and superficial structures and masses.
A current is applied to a transducer crystal, causing the crystal to oscillate, resulting in sound waves. After exiting the transducer the sound waves travel through tissue until encountering an interface of varying acoustic attenuation. The waves then either reflect or refract. The reflected waves are received by the transducer, converted to electrical current, and made into an image. A bright image represents a large tissue density difference (acoustic attenuation). The bright images are called hyperechoic and dark areas are called hypoechoic. A hypoechoic signal indicates that little sound is echoed back to the transducer. (1)
State-of-the-Art Technology
Unlike the conventional analog ultrasound equipment, the newer devices are digital, allowing higher accuracy and a wider dynamic range. Three-dimensional images can be obtained in real time, without cardiac or respiratory gating. The new harmonic imaging listens for a sound burst at twice the transmitted frequency, resulting in better spatial resolution and improved contrast differences.
Contrast media is now being used. Microbubbles enhance ultrasound signals by boosting the intensity, thus saving a failed B-mode or Doppler study. It allows for evaluation of the microvasculature. Because the injected bolus can be tracked in real time, knowledge of the transit time may soon allow for the discrimination between benign and malignant vasculature.
The probes are also changing. High-density, multifrequency probes are in use. The new probes are used for superficial structure evaluation and ultrasound-guided needle aspiration. (2)
INDICATIONS
Arthritides
Ultrasound is emerging as a valuable diagnostic tool for the diagnosis of inflammatory (rheumatoid) arthritis. Plain film is the reference standard for evaluation of the suspected rheumatoid arthritis patient; however, if the x-ray beam is not tangential to the lesion, small lesions are often missed. Ultrasound can detect such early erosions because of its capacity to achieve multiple angles. Ultrasound reveals joint lesions in patients who have early disease and report only pain. In addition to detecting early lesions, ultrasound is invaluable in determining exactly which structures are involved. Arthritis can be differentiated from tenosynovitis, and structural changes can be differentiated from inflammatory synovium. (1)
Beyond joint erosions, ultrasound is useful in detecting bursae abnormalities. A normal bursa has a hyperechoic lining with a < 2 mm hypoechoic central cleft. Ultrasound is able to demonstrate synovial proliferation and bursal thickening seen with rheumatoid arthritis. In areas of inflammation, echogenic material may also be seen within the bursa. (2)
Ultrasound is comparable to MRI in evaluating extremity synovitis. Ultrasound has a sensitivity of 97% and specificity of 89% for diagnosing synovitis in the hands and feet. For larger extremity joints, ultrasound has a sensitivity and specificity of 92% and 70%, respectively. Diagnostic ultrasound outperforms MRI in the evaluation of tendons. Unlike MRI, ultrasound can adequately differentiate lesions of the tendon from entheses or lesions of adjacent tissue. In addition to diagnostic comparisons, administrative considerations make ultrasound the more favorable examination. MRI is time-consuming, costly, and not as readily available. Thus repeat or routine examinations are difficult to obtain and evaluation of several joints is not feasible. Last, unlike ultrasound, MRI cannot readily provide dynamic studies. (2) Therefore, diagnostic ultrasound should be strongly considered for advanced imaging of arthritides.
Besides imaging considerations, diagnostic ultrasound is valuable in the treatment of the rheumatoid patient. Local pain relief and diminished swelling are best achieved with steroid injections into arthritic joints. Diagnostic ultrasound is useful for monitoring needle placement during the injection process. The exact inflammation location (whether joint, tendon, or bursa) can be determined without the use of radiation exposure. Thus injection treatment is safe, easy, and reliable with ultrasound. (3)
Diagnostic ultrasound is unlikely to be used in the physician’s office because of the time needed to learn the technique and adequately read the images. One study showed that ultrasound interpretation could be inaccurate even after the clinician had viewed 200 arthritide cases. Owing to the technical and interpretative challenges,
P.632

the disadvantage of diagnostic ultrasound is that it probably won’t be readily available in the standard physician’s office. (4)
Table 6-7 Normal Ultrasound Echogenicity

Tissue

General Echogenicity

Transverse Plane

Longitudinal Plane

Tendon

Uniform echogenicity

Hyperechoic round to oval shape

Hyperechoic parallel lines (fibrillar pattern)

Ligament

Uniform echogenicity

Hyperechoic round to oval shape

Hyperechoic parallel lines (more compact fibrillar pattern than tendon)

Skeletal muscle

Low- to mid-level echogenicity

Echogenic short lines or dots with a reticular echogenic pattern of septa

Brightly echogenic intermuscular septae and perimysium (herringbone pattern)

Bone cortex

Echogenic with posterior shadowing

Echogenic with posterior shadowing

Echogenic with posterior shadowing

Hyaline cartilage

Thin hypoechoic rim paralleling articular surfaces

Thin hypoechoic rim paralleling articular surfaces

Thin hypoechoic rim paralleling articular surfaces
Internal Derangement
To diagnose derangement, one must understand normal. The normal tendon is seen as hyperechoic parallel lines in the longitudinal plane and circles in the transverse plane. This is consistent with a fibrillar pattern. (Table 6-7)
Ligaments are similar in appearance but the fibrillar pattern is more compact. (5) Muscle shows a low to moderate echogenicity. The herringbone pattern occurs in the longitudinal plane where intermuscular septae and perimysium are visualized as brightly echogenic. Hyaline cartilage is seen as a hypoechoic rim paralleling the articular surface. Cortical bone is echogenic with posterior shadowing. Peripheral nerves have a speckled appearance in the transverse plane and fascicular in the longitudinal plane. The neuronal fascicles are hypoechoic, and the connective stroma is hyperechoic. (6)
Muscle strains (grade 1) are seen as areas of hyperechogenicity, representing swelling. Grade 2 muscle strains show discontinuity of the echogenic perimysial striae, representing muscle fiber tears. Ultrasound is better than MRI at demonstrating injury to the hamstring, rectus femoris, and gastrocnemius muscles. It also has superior spatial resolution and thus can differentiate between grade 1 and 2 partial tears of these musculotendinous junctions. On MRI, grade 1 and 2 tears appear similar, making MRI able only to differentiate partial tear from complete rupture. Ultrasound shows muscle contusion as a hyperechoic area that later becomes a fluid collection with debris. (Fig. 6-226) Ultrasound can be used to guide aspiration of the fluid collection. (5)
Figure 6-226 SUBCUTANEOUS HEMATOMA. A. Ultrasound, Transverse Thigh Musculature. B. Ultrasound, Longitudinal Thigh Musculature. Note the large hypoechoic hematoma (arrows) with a hyperechoic clot (arrowheads). COMMENT: Acute muscle hematoma is initially hyperechoic and then becomes hypoechoic. (Courtesy of Steven J. Gould, DC, DACBR, Wichita, Kansas.)
Tendinosis is focally or diffusely hypoechoic. Both tendon tears and tendinosis are hypoechoic. To differentiate the tendinosis from a tendon tear, other features must be noted. Tendinosis will show tendon thickening and lack the thinning and well-defined abnormality of a tear. Complete tears will also demonstrate some tendon retraction. Ultrasound has a 93% sensitivity and 94% specificity for the diagnosis of partial rotator cuff tears; it has 100% sensitivity and 85% specificity for diagnosis of rotator cuff rupture (6) (Fig. 6-227). Inflammation within the tendon sheath (tenosynovitis) is represented by an anechoic signal (Fig. 6-228).
Ligament tears are seen as regions of anechoic or hypoechoic hemorrhage. If a hyperechoic foci with shadowing is visualized, then a bony avulsion has resulted. (6)
P.633

Figure 6-227 FULL THICKNESS TEAR: SUPRASPINATUS TENDON. A and B. Ultrasound, Transverse Shoulder. Note the full-thickness tear in the supraspinatus tendon (panel A), resulting in complete absence of tendon visualization. Compare with a normal tendon (panel B) (arrows). The humeral head is outlined by an echogenic signal (arrowhead). COMMENT: Diagnostic ultrasound displays high sensitivity for the diagnosis of full-thickness rotator cuff tears. (Courtesy of Steven J. Gould, DC, DACBR, Wichita, Kansas.)
The joints can also be assessed with ultrasound. Effusion is represented by an anechoic signal. Be careful not to mistake the prominent hypoechoic cartilage in children as joint effusion. (7) Lipohemarthrosis shows a fluid-fluid level, with the anechoic fluid lying on the hemorrhage. (5) Synovitis can be differentiated from fluid because fluid is compressible without flow on Doppler images. (6)
Infection
Although ultrasound cannot demonstrate the cause of fluid collections, these collections are well demonstrated. Thus ultrasound can determine the location of soft tissue infection as within muscle (pyomyositis), joint (septic arthritis), bursa, synovial sheath, or around bone (osteomyelitis). Ultrasound is now the first-line imaging modality for appendicular soft tissue pathologies. Rapid diagnosis of infection is important to reduce morbidity; therefore, ultrasound has the capacity to identify these suspected infectious sites and then guide needle aspiration for tissue culture. In addition, ultrasound is easily repeatable, allowing for follow-up images to document resolution after therapy. Unlike MRI and CT, ultrasound is not degraded by metallic artifact. Thus ultrasound is especially useful for evaluating postsurgical metallic fixations for complicating infection. (8,9)
Figure 6-228 BICEPS TENDON EFFUSION. A. Ultrasound, Transverse Biceps Tendon. Note the normal long head of the biceps tendon, which appears as an echogenic oval structure (arrow) within the tendon groove. The transverse ligament is seen overlying the tendon (arrowhead). Observe the distension of the tendon sheath caused by a large amount of anechoic fluid (crossed arrow). B. Ultrasound, Longitudinal Biceps Tendon. Observe the biceps tendon and surrounding edema. Note the normal parallel lines (fibrillar pattern) of the biceps tendon. COMMENT: Effusion of the biceps tendon sheath is a non-specific finding but is significantly related to disorders occurring somewhere within the glenohumeral joint. (Courtesy of Steven J. Gould, DC, DACBR, Wichita, Kansas.)
P.634

Pediatric
Pediatric patients are ideal candidates for the use of ultrasound owing to their abundance of cartilage, which allows identification of even more anatomy than in the mature skeleton. Ultrasound can identify fractures of the physeal cartilage and the position of cartilage fragments. Occult cortical fractures can be seen owing to the high reflectivity of the soft tissue-bone interface. Ultrasound is especially helpful in diagnosing fractures of the radiographically complex elbow. (10) Child abuse is identified by ultrasound as displacement of the perichondral ring. The perichondral ring cannot be seen on plain film, but it suggests focal avulsion of the ring and attached cortex. Plain film radiography cannot demonstrate non-ossified structures; therefore, unossified epiphyses and apophyses need to be visualized with ultrasound. (11)
The most common application of ultrasound in children is for the diagnosis of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Ultrasound can dynamically demonstrate stability or instability of the DDH hip. Normal posterior displacement of the hip of up to 6 mm is seen in newborns and decreases to 1 mm by 5 months of age. (11) In addition, diagnostic ultrasound can be used to monitor treatment of DDH with the Pavlik harness and assess for DDH complications. One complication is avascular necrosis, which is adequately demonstrated by power Doppler ultrasound. Other developmental anomalies commonly assessed with ultrasound are congenital dislocations, tethered cord, and tibial hemimelia. (7)
Besides developmental anomalies, ultrasound is used to detect pediatric infection. Cellulitis shows a hyperechoic, diffuse thickening of the skin and adjacent tissue with obliteration of the fat-dermis interface. (10,11) Pyomyositis demonstrates a local hypoechoic region within the muscle that represents edema or phlegmon. Although not pathognomonic, osteomyelitis is highly suspicious when fluid is noted against bone. (7) Diagnostic ultrasound can detect osteomyelitis sooner than plain film, which takes 7-10 days in the extremities and up to 21 days in the spine. An abscess may demonstrate the acoustic shadowing of air or the fluid levels of debris. (10)
With ultrasound, fluid lesions can be differentiated from solid neoplasms in the soft tissues. (7) The location of the mass in relation to adjacent structures and the vascularity of the mass can be visualized. Common childhood soft tissue masses assessed by ultrasound include lipoma, hemangioma, arteriovenous malformation, cystic hygroma, synovial mass, and ganglion cyst. (10)
One specific indication for ultrasound is in diagnosing fibromatosis colli. This fibrotic mass is seen as an enlarged sternocleidomastoid muscle in children with a history of birth trauma. (10,11) The patient presents with torticollis that resolves in 4-8 months with conservative care. (11)
Ultrasound is used to diagnose non-opaque foreign bodies, such as wood, plastic, and fibrous material. If surrounding inflammation is present, the fluid will appear hypoechoic. The removal of the foreign body can be guided by ultrasound. (7)
Finally, ultrasound can help diagnose juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. Effusion and synovial thickening will be present even if arthritis is clinically silent. Power Doppler demonstrates the highly vascularized proliferative synovium of active disease. (11)
ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES
Diagnostic sonography has the advantage of being a rapid examination, accessible, portable, and capable of varying planes. In comparison with MRI, ultrasound has higher spatial resolution and lower cost. (1) Probably, the greatest advantage is its capacity to perform dynamic real-time images, thus being correlative to patient symptoms and easily comparable with the asymptomatic side. This examination has no deleterious side effects because it is non-invasive and produces no ionizing radiation. (2)
A major limitation to musculoskeletal ultrasound is anisotropy, created by technical error. This is a hypoechoic signal seen when the ultrasound beam is not perpendicular to the imaged structure. The result is a pseudo-pathology. (2) Besides overcalls, missed pathology occurs with inadequate positioning. For example, knee effusions are best visualized at 30-40° of genuflexion but may be invisible at 90° of flexion. Fluids can also be missed if the operator presses too hard with the transducer and displaces the fluid. (3) In addition, ultrasound is technically difficult and requires a long learning curve both in performance and interpretation. (1) Diagnostic ultrasound of the adult spine lacks data on sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy and is not currently recommended for the routine diagnosis of disc herniation, spinal stenosis, and nerve root pathology. (4)
Medicolegal Implications
DIAGNOSTIC ULTRASONOGRAPHY
  • Diagnostic ultrasound of the musculoskeletal system has an exemplary safety record.
  • There is little or no danger associated with musculoskeletal ultrasound exposure at recommended levels of operation.
  • Ultrasonic exposure requires awareness of thermal and non-thermal effects but is a low level risk in routine practice.
  • Plain film radiography should complement musculoskeletal diagnostic ultrasound to avoid overlooking soft tissue calcification or osseous lesions.
  • Diagnostic ultrasound of the adult spine lacks data on sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy and is not currently recommended for the routine diagnosis of disc herniation, spinal stenosis, and nerve root pathology.
DUAL-ENERGY X-RAY ABSORPTIOMETRY
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
Osteoporosis has a high rate of morbidity from fractures. Over a lifetime, a female has a 1 in 4 chance of developing an osteoporotic fracture and a male has a 1 in 8 chance. Although osteoporosis is more common in women, 3-6% of men > 50 years of age have this disease. (1) Resulting fractures may also increase mortality, as 31% of men with osteoporotic hip fractures die within 1 year of fracture and 17% of women die. (1) Because of the dire consequence of these complications and the asymptomatic nature of osteoporosis, a method to assess bone mineral density in patients with risk factors was needed. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) emerged in the 1980s and is the diagnostic
P.635

measure of choice. The assessment of osteoporosis is the most common usage of DEXA.
Glossary
attenuation
Loss of radiant beam energy owing to absorption, scatter, and beam divergence.
T-score
Number of standard deviations away from the mean bone mineral density, derived from the age of peak bone mass (20-35 years of age).
Z-score
Bone mineral density of a patient compared with the mean for people of the same age.
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
Bone mineral density is used to diagnose osteoporosis, and DEXA is the gold standard for screening density. DEXA uses two x-ray beams of different energy levels. The degree of attenuation is measured as the beam passes through the bone. The dual-energy beams allow for soft tissue corrections, resulting in a bone mineral density. (1) DEXA is rapid, requires low radiation (10% of a chest radiograph), and is inexpensive. In the older patient, hip scans for osteoporosis are preferred to spinal screens because the excess bone density of spinal osteophytes results in false negatives. Other common devices used to assess bone mineral density include heel ultrasound and quantitative CT. (2)
Bone mineral density is defined by the T-score. The T-score is the number of standard deviations away from the mean. The mean is derived from the age of peak bone mass (20-35 years of age). According to the World Health Organization, T-scores of -2.5 or worse constitute osteoporosis. Each standard deviation corresponds to a 10-15% loss of bone, resulting in a doubling of overall fracture risk. A Z-score may also be obtained, which represents the bone mineral density of a patient compared with the mean for people of the same age. The usefulness of the Z-score has been questioned because it is not a recognized tool for the diagnosis of osteoporosis.
Although it is the gold standard, DEXA is not without disadvantages. Distorted results occur because of skeletal size. Larger skeletal size, owing to increased vertebral depth, results in an overestimation of bone mineral density and vice versa. Patients with petite skeletal structures have underestimated bone mineral density. DEXA T-scores are based on white females. In general, men have larger bone structures with overestimated DEXA results, and Asians have smaller bone structures, resulting in underestimated DEXA results. (1)
Another consideration is that DEXA is based on a two-compartment model: soft tissue versus bone or fat versus fat-free mass. Unfortunately, body composition is more complex than this, and DEXA does not account for lean mass, liquid, air, and other body components; therefore, regional changes in fat distribution or hydration status can affect the DEXA results. Because DEXA depends on x-ray attenuation, greater local fat will overestimate the DEXA findings. Bone mineral density may change as much as 5% for each centimeter of local fat. Last, differences in software may also cause result variations. (3)
Limitations for the pediatric population are greater than for the adult. The T-score is based on adult bone mineral density; therefore, the Z-score is better for evaluating children. However, assessment is not that easy. Normal bone mass changes with age, pubertal stage, and gender, so the appropriate reference standard must be used. For example, chronic illness will cause delayed puberty and thus skeletal maturation becomes a greater indicator for bone density than chronological age. Also, DEXA cannot determine the cause of low bone mineral density. DEXA doesn’t differentiate loss of bone mass from undermineralized bone matrix, as seen in osteomalacia. (3)
INDICATIONS
DEXA is mainly used to screen for osteoporosis in patients with risk factors. Such risk factors include low calcium and vitamin D intake, prolonged amenorrhea, certain medications (glucocorticoids, heparin, anticonvulsants), hyperprolactinemia, hypercorticalism, sedentary lifestyle, smoking, and alcoholism. (1,2) Bone density screening is recommended for postmenopausal white women > 65 years of age or for those with one or more risk factors. (2)
Osteoporosis can be primary or secondary. Primary osteoporosis is associated with aging because of deficiencies in estrogen and testosterone. Secondary osteoporosis results from a chronic illness like hyperparathyroidism, gastrointestinal diseases, thyroxine excess, liver or renal failure, connective tissue diseases, and cancer. (1) The risk of fracture is inversely related to bone mineral density; therefore, the prevention of osteoporotic fracture by DEXA is valuable. DEXA can be used to diagnose osteoporosis and to monitor treatment.
Pharmacologic treatment is necessary to prevent fracture when the T-score is < −2. Serial DEXA scans following the introduction of therapy may be indicated after 1-2 years of treatment. With hyperparathyroidism or glucocorticoid osteoporosis, more frequent evaluation may be necessary. Typically, two sites of DEXA evaluation are suggested, usually hip and lumbar spine. However, the condition may dictate the appropriate reference standard. For example, the hip and spine have greater amounts of trabecular bone; therefore, osteopenia will be diagnosed at these sites first. In growth hormone deficiency or hyperparathyroidism, cortical bone is affected to a greater extent; therefore, distal radius or total body studies are more valuable. (3) Two assessment sites will provide more accurate results owing to the false elevation of T-scores with osteoarthritis or metallic hardware, such as Harrington rods or hip replacements. Osteoporosis is diagnosed based on the lower T-score. (2)
Creating reserves of bone mass for a lifetime occurs in childhood up until the 3rd decade of life; therefore, the bone mass obtained during childhood predicts the risk for osteoporotic fractures in the aged. Children are prone to osteoporosis in the following conditions: malnutrition, inactivity, hypogonadism, and chronic steroid exposure. Thus, monitoring bone mineral density in children with risk factors is appropriate. DEXA is preferable to CT and ultrasound. CT has inappropriate radiation exposure levels for children and quantitative ultrasound is less precise than DEXA, with pediatric reference norms being limited. DEXA is fast, precise, available, and has low radiation exposure. (3)
DEXA can be used to assess bone density in the pregnant patient. During pregnancy, there is a dissociation of bone formation and resorption, resulting in increased osteoclastic activity without stimulation of osteoblasts. The net result is bone loss that occurs in the first two trimesters and well into the third trimester.
P.636

This uncoupling of bone formation and resorption results from the fetal calcium requirements. The fetus uses the maternal calcium and phosphate stores for its development. DEXA then may be helpful in assessing pregnant women for their risk of fracture, caused by the weight and posture changes with corresponding low bone density. (4)
In addition to bone mineral density, fat composition can be assessed with DEXA. The excess fat accumulation in obesity can be evaluated accurately and reliably. DEXA demonstrates soft tissue composition by differentiating fat mass from fat-free mass for the whole body and for specific body regions. (5) Fat composition is also an issue for the AIDS patient. The treatment of AIDS has caused the focus of pathology to change from opportunistic infections to new clinical entities, like lipodystrophy. The HIV infection and protease inhibitor therapy results in a redistribution of fat. The typical presentation is fat wasting in the face, arms, legs, and buttocks with fat accumulation in the abdomen and over the dorsocervical spine. DEXA is used to objectively define the fat redistribution in the HIV-positive patient. (6)
CONTRAINDICATIONS
Although the radiation exposure is only 1-5 microsieverts per scan, DEXA is not recommended for the pregnant patient. Additional contraindications are based on technical difficulties instead of safety precautions. The patient weighing > 250 lb cannot undergo central DEXA analysis owing to the inability of the equipment to accommodate the patient’s size. Peripheral studies are recommended for the obese. Distorted results occur in patients with recent gastrointestinal contrast or nuclear medicine studies; therefore, DEXA should be delayed at least 72 hr after these examinations. (1)
Medicolegal Implications
DEXA
  • DEXA is currently the method of choice for the calculation of hip and vertebral fracture risk.
  • Patients with hyperparathyroidism, early menopause, or corticosteroid use should be screened for fracture risk because of the high mortality associated with hip fractures (20% die within the first year).
  • Although radiation is used, it is a low-dose examination (1-5 microsieverts).
  • DEXA is not recommended during pregnancy because of the use of ionizing radiation.
  • There is no indication for more than one DEXA scan per year.
  • DEXA screening of asymptomatic women is not recommended.
  • Selective screening according to specific indications is suggested.
  • Densitometry is indicated at any age if the indication is valid.
NUCLEAR MEDICINE
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVES
A major landmark in the development of nuclear science was the classic experiment of Ernest Rutherford in 1919 at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge, England. (1) Rutherford placed a small amount of radium in a container filled with oxygen and mounted a zinc sulfide screen nearby. α-particles emitted by the radium struck the zinc sulfide screen and produced on its surface pinpoints of light called scintillations, which could be observed and even counted by viewing the screen through a microscope. Rutherford and associate James Chadwick deduced that the underlying process, which must have been occurring inside the container, was not the production of x-rays but rather of positively charged nuclear particles, or protons. When an α-particle emitted by the radium struck a nitrogen nucleus containing seven protons, one proton was ejected. The remainder of the nitrogen atom and the α-particle joined together to form a new atom with eight protons, an oxygen atom. Rutherford had thus achieved the goal of the medieval alchemists: the transmutation of elements.
For the next decade, laboratories in many countries engaged in a scientific race to be the first to develop particle accelerators or atom smashers capable of speeding up subatomic particles to the energies required for effective nuclear bombardment.
In the United States, Ernest O. Lawrence in 1931 at the University of California Radiation Laboratory developed the cyclotron, the first of the circular accelerators. (2) The evolution of this new technology led to the application of radioisotope material to the study of human tissue. The first tracer study in clinical medicine that used radioactivity was the work of Blumgard and coworkers in Boston in 1926. (3) The first biologic experiments using a new artificial radioisotope were reported in 1935 by Hevesy and Chiewitz (4), 12 years after Hevesy invented the tracer technique using a naturally radioactive isotope.
For the past 30 years the major radionuclide used in clinical work has been technetium (Tc). Technetium-99m (99mTc) was discovered by Perrier and Segre (5) in 1937. Radionuclide scanning of the skeleton, liver, thyroid, lung, spleen, and other organs has revolutionized the evaluation of many body systems.
Glossary
ALARA principle
States that procedures should not only maintain radiation doses within legal limits but extend beyond to as low as reasonably achievable.
annihilation radiation
The radiation that arises from a collision between two particles with opposite charges. These particles are typically the positron and the electron. Their collision will result in annihilation and release of radiation into two oppositely directed 510 keV γ-rays. This radiation mechanism is employed in PET scans.
collimator
A device that limits the radiation field entering the γ-camera crystal similar to a radiographic grid. There are a variety of collimator configurations such as converging, diverging, and pinhole. Collimator slits confine the γ-radiation in a uniform direction. This important device improves image quality.
P.637

critical organ
The organ first subjected to the legally defined maximum permissible radiation exposure. The bladder is the critical organ in the technetium-methylene diphosphonate (99mTc-MDP) bone scan examination.
decay
The logarithmic disintegration of a radioactive substance into its daughter products.
disintegration
The process of radioactive decay that results in spontaneous emission of particles from the nucleus.
dose
The quantity of radiation that is delivered to a specific tissue site. In nuclear imaging the units of measurement are typically microcuries.
flare phenomenon
Increased tracer activity in a malignant lesion following chemotherapy. This phenomenon represents healing at the lesion site and is accompanied by clinical improvement.
γ-camera
Synonymous with a scintillation camera. It consists of a collimator, crystal, and photomultiplier (PM) array. γ-radiation is directed into the collimator, where it activates photons in the thallium-activated sodium iodide NaI(Tl) crystal. The photon scintillations are detected by the PM tubes and are electronically encoded for position (X, Y pulses). A photon (Z pulse) that is in a selected energy range is accepted after sampling by the pulse height analyzer.
γ-rays
Photons of γ-radiation.
isotope
Chemical elements that have the same atomic number but different atomic mass. Iodine, for example, has several isotopes, for example, iodine-125 and iodine-131.
pertechnetate (TcO4)
The standard compound formed as technetium is extracted from a generator by passing saline through it.
photon
A quantum of electromagnetic energy.
photopenia
The reduction of normal photon activity that is identified on a bone scan. This finding often accompanies ischemic or rapidly destructive lesions in the skeleton.
positron emission tomography (PET)
An imaging modality that uses positron-emitting radionuclides to produce annihilation radiation. The γ-rays emitted by the annihilation event are localized by detector systems called coincident circuits. Photon localization is displayed in the same manner as scintigraphy.
positron
A particle that is equal to the mass of an electron, but maintains a positive electronic charge. When it contacts a negatively charged electron, annihilation radiation of 510 keV is emitted and detected by coincidence counters. This is the principle of PET.
rad
A unit of radiation absorption; 1 rad = 100 erg/g.
radioactive half-life
The time interval at which the radioactivity of a given sample will decrease to one half its initial value. The half-life of 99mTc-MDP is 6 hr.
radiopharmaceutical
A radioactively labeled compound that is injected into the bloodstream. The compound circulates and is deposited into the target tissue. Synonyms are radionuclide isotope and radionuclide agent. The most commonly employed radiopharmaceuticals in skeletal imaging are (listed in decreasing order):
  • Technetium-99m-methylene diphosphonate (99mTc-MDP)
  • Gallium-67 (67Ga)
  • Indium-111 oxine-tagged white blood cells (111In)
scintigraphy
A nuclear medicine procedure, such as a bone scan. The term is derived from the decay of the radionuclide and its resultant γ-radiation or scintillations. The scintillations are detected by the γ-camera, processed by a computer, and displayed as an image. The number of scintillations corresponds to the concentration of the isotope.
single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)
This technology employs one or more cameras to tomographically record radiation in a defined plane. An image may be displayed in a multiplanar format (e.g., coronal, axial, sagittal). The examination provides increased localization of the radiopharmaceutical uptake. Its utility is maximized in difficult regions such as the spine, temporomandibular joint, and hip joint.
super scan
A bone scan that displays diffuse axial metastatic disease so extensive and uniform that it mimics a normal examination. The pronounced skeletal uptake creates high contrast between bone and soft tissue. Uptake in the urinary system (kidneys and bladder) is faint because less radiotracer is available for excretion.
three-phase bone scan
The three phases of a bone scan are the angiogram or flow phase, blood pool, and delayed or bone phase. The phases represent the temporal course of the radiopharmaceutical tracer.
uptake
An accumulation of the radiopharmaceutical within the target tissue such as bone. A hot spot represents an increase in radiopharmaceutical deposition. A cold spot results from abnormally diminished radiopharmaceutical uptake, or photopenia.
TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS
Nuclear medicine is a vital tool in the diagnostic imaging armamentarium. Images are generated as the uptake and distribution of administered radiopharmaceuticals are detected. Although other imaging modalities may give a better analysis of structural integrity, nuclear medicine can often provide vital information regarding tissue perfusion, physiology, and biochemistry. Physiologic and metabolic changes often precede gross structural alteration of diseased tissue by hours, days, or even weeks. Nuclear medicine evaluation can therefore be a key factor in determining early diagnosis and proper treatment protocols and in establishing an accurate prognosis.
Nuclear medicine is a field of diagnostic imaging that encompasses various techniques and numerous applications. Radionuclide bone imaging and nuclear cardiology account for the majority of nuclear imaging studies. New procedures and applications, however, are constantly being developed. Radionuclide functional brain imaging for the evaluation of dementia, radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies for tumor detection, and molecular imaging of gene expression are examples of the evolving diagnostic applications of nuclear imaging. Planar scintigraphy, SPECT, and PET are briefly discussed in this section.
Radionuclide bone scanning is presently the most frequently performed nuclear medicine technique, accounting for over half the studies performed in nuclear medicine departments. (1) Bone scanning techniques are employed in the evaluation of soft tissue, bone, and joint disorders. Fractures, infections, arthritides, tumors, and osteonecrosis are among the many disorders imaged by skeletal scintigraphy. Although the physiologic sensitivity of radionuclide bone scanning is a major advantage, this modality offers limited anatomic information and diagnostic specificity. To increase anatomic specificity, radiography, CT, or MRI is often performed in conjunction with the bone scan to obtain the necessary anatomic information. (Fig. 6-229)
Skeletal scintigraphy radiopharmaceuticals were first introduced in the early 1960s with strontium-85, strontium-87, and
P.638

fluorine-18. (2,3) Strontium-85 is an avid bone-seeking radiotracer with a long half-life and high radiation dose. These high-risk factors limited its use to only malignant conditions. Fluorine-18 sodium chloride displayed rapid blood clearance and high skeletal affinity, but its half-life was too short, limiting its application for scintigraphy. 99mTc-MDP polyphosphate compounds were successfully prepared and introduced in 1971 by Subramanian and McAfee. (4) Those early pharmacologic agents were tripolyphosphates. They were followed by pyrophosphates and today by diphosphonates. Diphosphonates have faster blood clearance and higher skeletal uptake than previous generations of pharmacologic agents. (5)
Figure 6-229 PAGET’S DISEASE: UNUSUAL CASE OF LYTIC INVOLVEMENT IN THE SPINE. A. Lateral Leg. Note the characteristic appearance of Paget’s disease affecting the tibia. B. Neutral Lateral Cervical Spine. Observe the lytic phase of Paget’s disease involving C2-C4. C. PA Chest. Note that the manubrium is also affected (arrows).
P.639

Figure 6-229 (continued) D. AP Lumbar Spine. Note the T12 vertebral body, which demonstrates the characteristic ivory appearance of pagetic bone (arrow). A compression deformity of the pagetic L3 vertebral body is also evident. E. T1-Weighted MRI, Sagittal Cervical Spine. Note the diffuse low signal intensity marrow replacement involving the neural arch and vertebral bodies of C2-C4. F. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior (Left) and Posterior (Right) Whole Body. Note the increased tracer activity in T12 and L3, as noted on the plain film (panel D). Abnormal activity is also identified in the tibia, pelvis, manubrium, scapula, and upper cervical spine. COMMENT: This 57-year-old male presented with bilateral paresthesia and numbness in the lower extremities. (Courtesy of Gary L. Smith, DC, DACBR, Portland, Oregon.)
P.640

Examination Procedure
Most radionuclide bone scans are performed in three phases (three-phase bone scan). These phases represent the distribution of the tracer over the course of time. The intravenous injection of the radiopharmaceutical agent initiates the three-phase bone scan. Phase one is known as the flow phase or radionuclide angiogram because of the intravascular location of the agent. Rapid sequential images are obtained over the region of interest every 2-3 sec for 30 sec. Approximately half of the radiotracer diffuses from the vascular to the extravascular space in 2-4 min. (1)
The second phase is known as the blood pool phase and occurs when the tracer is located in the extravascular space. A diffusion pattern is obtained by imaging the whole body or region of interest 5 min after injection. Delayed static images are obtained in the third phase, or bone scan phase, between 2 and 4 hr after the injection. (Fig. 6-230) These delayed images represent clearance of the tracer from the vessels and soft tissues and concentration into the skeleton. (Fig. 6-231) Sometimes, 24-hr scans are employed to evaluate osteomyelitis. (6)
Absorbed Patient Dose
The exact radiation dose absorbed by the patient in a three-phase bone scan is difficult to determine. A number of complex factors, including tracer biodistribution, organ pathology, and renal function, influence the dose. Approximately 50% of the injected dose is taken up by the skeleton within 2-6 hr. With normal renal excretion, 50-60% of the tracer is eliminated within 24 hr of injection. Urine concentration of the radionuclide in the bladder exposes it to a higher dose than other organs. The bladder, therefore, is the critical or target organ, receiving the highest dose. This dose may be reduced by pre-examination hydration of the patient and frequent voiding after the completion of the examination. (7) The whole-body dose of a bone scan is approximately 0.13 rad. (8) In contrast, the average dose for a standard CT scan of the lumbar spine is 3-5 rad. There is often metabolic uptake of pertechnetate (which resembles iodine) in the following human tissue: choroid plexus, thyroid gland, salivary glands, stomach, and breast.
Figure 6-230 NORMAL ADULT ANATOMY. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior (Left) and Posterior (Right) Whole Body. The third phase of the scan procedure is shown. Note the symmetric skeletal uptake across the midline. An injection site is noted in the right midforearm (arrow), a normal finding. Note the normally increased activity in the sacroiliac joints and vertebral column, a reflection of higher rates of bone turnover. Clinically insignificant increased uptake is often observed in the knee joints of older individuals (arrowheads), secondary to degenerative arthritis. Accumulation of the radiopharmaceutical agent in the urinary tract (kidney and bladder) is normal (crossed arrows). COMMENT: Bone scanning is a highly sensitive means of detecting a wide range of musculoskeletal disorders. This procedure, however, frequently requires an anatomic imaging modality like CT or MRI for correlative purposes. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.641

Figure 6-231 MULTIFOCAL OSTEOMYELITIS: PATIENT WITH DIABETES. A. AP Left Shoulder. Note the destruction and debris involving the acromioclavicular joint (arrow). B. Angiogram Phase Bone Scan, Upper Torso and Neck. Observe the increased vascular perfusion involving the soft tissues of the left shoulder (arrows). C. Blood Pool Phase Bone Scan, Left Shoulder. Note the diffusely increased tracer activity, consistent with hyperemia (arrow). D. Delayed Phase Bone Scan, Anterior (Left) and Posterior (Right) Whole Body. Note the markedly increased tracer activity involving the clavicle and acromioclavicular and glenohumeral joints (arrows), suggesting osteomyelitis. E. Bone Scan, Dorsal (Left) and Plantar (Right) Bilateral Foot. Observe the diffuse increased tracer activity in the right midfoot and forefoot, consistent with osteomyelitis. (Courtesy of Michael A. Fox, MD, Memphis, Tennessee.)
P.642

CONTRAINDICATIONS
The safety of scintigraphy is reflected in the limited circumstances that contraindicate its use. Pregnancy is a relative contraindication because transplacental transmission of radiopharmaceuticals is possible. The risk to benefit ratio should clearly warrant the use of a scintigraphic examination during pregnancy, as in a workup for skeletal metastases. (1) If a scintigraphic examination is performed, breast milk will carry isotope activity for several days after the study. Formula feeding is recommended under these circumstances. (2)
IMAGE GENERATION
Nuclear medicine techniques employ radioactive tracer agents (radiopharmaceuticals) that are placed into the body by injection, ingestion, or inhalation. The radiopharmaceutical emits γ-rays that are detected by an instrument and transformed into electrical signals that ultimately generate a computer image of the tracer agent activity and concentration. Because the γ-rays have high energy, little is attenuated by the body and the exact distribution and intensity of the tracer in the body is reflected in the images. The intensity, pattern symmetry, and other anatomic characteristics of the organ or tissue are then evaluated. The distribution of radiopharmaceutical uptake, whether increased, delayed, or decreased, provides for a highly sensitive image of normal variation and pathophysiology.
The essential technical elements employed in the production of a nuclear medicine image are as follows:
  • A pharmacologic agent that distributes into the organ tissue or compartment of interest.
  • A radionuclide that emits γ-radiation of sufficient energy to escape the target tissue or compartment (e.g., vascular, ventricular, intestinal compartments) and reach a detector. The radiopharmaceuticals are used in tiny trace amounts.
  • A γ-ray detector with computer processing, image production, and recording systems.
Radiopharmaceutical Agents
A radiopharmaceutical chemically combines a radionuclide and a pharmacologic agent. A radionuclide is an element that emits γ-radiation while undergoing radioactive decay. The optimal radiopharmaceutical must be an efficient diagnostic agent, easy to produce, safe, and available at a reasonable cost. The ideal agent for bone scanning should emit principally γ-radiation, exhibit a convenient half-life, possess the appropriate chemical properties (e.g., stability and low toxicity), and be taken up by metabolically active bone tissue.
γ-Radiation, unlike β- or α-particles, yields relatively high energy photons in a range between 70 and 500 keV. Most nuclear imaging detector systems operate in this energy range, which is sufficient to pass through body tissues relatively unattenuated for detection by a γ-camera. The half-life of a radiopharmaceutical (the period necessary for half the radionuclei to decay) must be long enough to provide ample time for its preparation and administration. The half-life must be short enough, however, to limit patient radiation levels to values that are as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA principle). (1)
After their administration, radiopharmaceutical agents are designed to be preferentially localized to particular targets; these might be organs, tissues, anatomic spaces, or metabolic pathways. Physiologic differences between normal and pathologic tissue produce different patterns of radiopharmaceutical uptake and distribution. The resultant image may show areas of increased γ-emission called hot spots. Areas of decreased γ-emission are known as cold spots.
Dozens of radiopharmaceuticals are now employed in nuclear imaging. The most widely used radionuclide is 99mTc-MDP. Its half-life of 6 hr and principal photon energy of 140 keV are convenient and have resulted in widespread use. The diphosphonate class of compounds labeled with 99mTc-MDP are used almost exclusively for bone imaging.
Since the early 1970s and into the 1980s, 111In and 67Ga have been employed to detect infection, inflammation, and certain tumors (such as lymphoma and hepatocellular carcinoma). (2,3) (Fig. 6-232) Today these agents are most commonly used for tumor localization; the evaluation of fever of unknown origin; AIDS; and inflammatory disorders of the lungs, abdomen (peritonitis), and pelvis. They are also used to differentiate osteomyelitis and postoperative complications that suggest infection. (4)
67Ga citrate uptake is maximized at sites of tumor, infection, or inflammation. The administered 67Ga binds with iron-binding proteins to form a complex that attaches to a tumor surface or enters the focus of an infection. Between 10% to 20% of the injected gallium is excreted through the gastrointestinal tract (the critical organ) within 24 hr. Scans are then typically obtained 48 hr after injection. The half-life of 67Ga is 78 hr. (5)
111In oxine leukocyte imaging is performed 18-24 hr after administration of autologous labeled white blood cells (WBCs). The 111In labels leukocytes, monocytes, red blood cells, platelets, and plasma proteins. Tissue uptake of labeled WBCs indicates an inflammatory or infectious response. 111In leukocyte scintigraphy is sensitive and specific for the detection of pulmonary, abdominal, and pelvic infections. (5) Concerns over the high dose (13-20 rad) and potential infection from the withdrawal, handling, and reinjection of labeled WBCs have prompted the development of new agents, which include immunoglobulins and labeled antigranulocyte antibody agents. (6,7)
Tracer Mechanisms
The precise mechanism of skeletal uptake of the radiopharmaceutical with 99mTc-MDP is not fully understood. The radiopharmaceutical is thought to localize preferentially because of a combination of increased blood flow and increased surface area on the hydroxyapatite (bone) crystal.
