(8,9) The agent is adsorbed or bound onto the mineral portion of the bone crystal and collagen, concentrating at sites of new bone formation. Increased functional demand on the skeleton results in new bone formation, increasing the volume of crystal formed. This functional histologic response precedes the gross structural (radiographic) changes by several weeks or months. The ability of bone scanning to detect these early physiologic or pathologic alterations accounts for its use in the imaging of subtle skeletal disorders.
P.643

Figure 6-232 HODGKIN’S LYMPHOMA: POSITIVE 67Ga SCAN. A. Bone Scan, Anterior Chest. Observe areas of abnormally increased radiotracer activity, consistent with tumor, in the right supraclavicular (arrow) and mediastinal (arrowheads) regions. Sites of activity involving the nasopharynx (crossed arrow) and lacrimal glands (curved arrow) are normal. B. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial Chest. Observe the soft tissue mass (arrow) in the right mediastinum. COMMENT: Lymphoma demonstrates a pronounced affinity for 67Ga. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
PLANAR SCINTIGRAPHY
In planar scintigraphy the γ-radiation emitted by a radiopharmaceutical that is administered intravenously is detected by a γ-camera or scintillation camera. The γ-camera consists of a collimator, coupled with a NaI(Tl) crystal detector and photomultiplier technology. The scintillation detector radiates visible light when struck by γ-photons. Photomultiplier tubes transform these light photons into electronic signals. After amplification the density and spatial coordinates of the photons are plotted by a computer. (Fig. 6-233) The detector-computer interface generates high-resolution images that correspond to the radiopharmaceutical location and concentration. Modern planar scintigraphic imaging systems simultaneously image the anterior and posterior aspects of the whole body or provide overlapping static views of a region. Images are then stored on film by means of a multiformat camera. (1)
Figure 6-233 γ-CAMERA SYSTEM. The principles of γ-ray emission, collimation, detection, localization, and image display are shown. (Modified from Wolbarst AB: Physics of Radiology. Norwalk, CT, Appleton & Lange, 1993.)
P.644

Figure 6-234 TRIPLE-HEADED SPECT SCANNER. A modern multidetector system with three scanner heads. COMMENT: The triple-headed scanner provides superior resolution for musculoskeletal applications of nuclear imaging. SPECT technology provides a three-dimensional anatomic perspective. Reconstructed images can be displayed in coronal, sagittal, and transverse planes. (Courtesy of Department of Nuclear Medicine, Veterans Administration Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
High concentrations (increased activity) of the radiopharmaceutical photons are displayed as a dark area. The absence of photons (photopenia) produces a corresponding area of decreased activity, resulting in lighter areas on the image. Contrast in the image is influenced by technologic factors, tissue uptake, and attenuation by overlying tissue.
SPECT
The image contrast and resolution of planar scintigraphy may be enhanced by introducing the tomographic characteristics of SPECT imaging. Planar imaging summates all planes of isotopic (point source) tracer activity to form an image. The modern multihead rotating SPECT camera systems display tracer activity in only the selected image plane. Like CT scanning, a multiplanar format provides the potential for axial, coronal, or sagittal views. This results in increased image contrast, as well as variable spatial orientation and improved resolution. (2) Applications include evaluation of the musculoskeletal system, heart, brain, and abdomen. (3)
In SPECT technology, between one and four γ-cameras or scintillation cameras on a rotating gantry are used to provide images in a selected tissue plane. The cameras travel in a circular or elliptical motion, allowing more accurate imaging of the patient with improved spatial resolution and sensitivity. (Fig. 6-234) SPECT images may be displayed in a 3D format like CT and MRI. (Fig. 6-235) This multiplanar capability greatly enhances diagnostic accuracy, particularly in the evaluation of spinal pain. In the musculoskeletal system, clinical challenges such as tumor surveillance, symptomatic spondylolysis (Fig. 6-236), apophyseal joint pain,
P.645

and pseudo-arthrosis following spinal fusion are a few examples of conditions addressed by SPECT imaging. The technical advantages of SPECT, provided by its tomographic capability, significantly enhance the diagnostician’s ability to accurately localize and identify a wide range of musculoskeletal lesions. (4,5,6,7)
Figure 6-235 NORMAL ANATOMY. SPECT Scan, Sagittal Cervicothoracic. Note the progressive scan through the sagittal plane of the cervical spine. The radiotracer activity in the middle of the scan is caused by vertebral bodies (arrows) and the sternum (arrowheads). COMMENT: The tomographic characteristics of SPECT scanning provide additional detail often not available with planar imaging. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-236 SPONDYLOLYTIC SPONDYLOLISTHESIS: POSITIVE SPECT SCAN. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the 15% anterolisthesis of L5 on S1. B. SPECT, Coronal Lumbar. Note the bilateral, but asymmetric, uptake in the L5 pars (arrows). COMMENT: SPECT imaging drives patient management by providing physiologic information about the activity of a pars defect. (Courtesy of Gary D. Konstant, DC, Watertown, South Dakota.)
Normal Bone Scan
In the normal adult three-phase bone scan, activity is highest in the most metabolically active parts of the skeleton. During pediatric osseous development, all zones of epiphyseal and apophyseal activity avidly take up the tracer agent. Generally, the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the most metabolically active bones and thus exhibit the greatest amount of normal tracer uptake.
Regions of the skeleton subject to maximal mechanical stress contain a high ratio of trabecular to cortical bone. These areas normally display increased uptake and are typically axial (spine and pelvis) in location. The skull and extremities of adults produce less tracer activity. In the normal bone scan, symmetric photon activity about the midline (sagittal plane) is anticipated, producing mirror images of radioactive uptake. Normal variation from this symmetry is seen in the spine and sacroiliac joints of scoliotic individuals. The kidneys and bladder are identified on the normal bone scan because of radiopharmaceutical concentration by the urinary tract, which should be less than that of the lumbar spine. Renal disease and chemotherapy may result in renal uptake greater than that of the lumbar spine. (8) (Fig. 6-237)
Any disorder that decreases or increases blood flow and /or osteoblastic activity will result in an abnormal scintigram. (Fig. 6-238) For example, ischemia results in an area of photon deficiency, whereas inflammation triggers vasodilatation and produces elevated photon activity.
Photopenic areas are seen when osteoclastic activity exceeds the osteoblastic (reparative) response. This can occur in multiple myeloma (Fig. 6-239), aggressive osteolytic tumors, and early acute osteomyelitis. Conversely, increased accumulation of the radiopharmaceutical suggests increased bone deposition and longer-standing inflammatory processes. (9)
Indications
Plain film radiography is typically employed in the initial evaluation of a patient with acute trauma or an unresponsive, persistent, painful chief complaint. Radionuclide bone scintigraphy provides valuable information when clinical findings are compelling but plain films are negative or equivocal. (10) A comprehensive list of clinical indications for skeletal scintigraphy has been established. (Table 6-8)
P.646

Figure 6-237 BONE SCAN: UNIQUE NORMAL UPTAKE. 99mTc-MDP Planar Bone Scan, Anterior Whole Body. Note that no abnormal radiotracer uptake is present in the skeleton. Note the focal radiotracer uptake within the breast tissue (gynecomastia) (arrows), which is considered to be an incidental finding, because this patient was receiving hormonal treatment for prostate carcinoma. Other areas of normal uptake often seen on bone scans include the stomach, colon, thyroid gland, choroid plexus, and salivary gland. COMMENT: This 65-year-old male patient was being treated for prostate carcinoma. (Courtesy of Michael A. Fox, MD, Memphis, Tennessee.)
Figure 6-238 PAGET’S DISEASE: CHARACTERISTICALLY HOT BONE SCAN. A. AP Leg. Note the pagetic involvement of the proximal tibia and the pseudo-fracture in the midshaft of the tibia (arrow). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Observe the marked diffuse radionuclide uptake involving the entire right tibia. COMMENT: Paget’s disease frequently extends to the subarticular margin of one end of a long or short tubular bone. (Courtesy of Dawn E. Bedrosian, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
P.647

Figure 6-239 MULTIPLE MYELOMA: UNUSUAL ONE-EYED PEDICLE SIGN. A. AP Thoracic Spine. Observe the absence of the T7 pedicle (arrow). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Thoracic Spine. Observe the photopenia corresponding to the T7 segment (arrow). COMMENT: It is unusual for multiple myeloma to involve the pedicle. More commonly, osteolytic metastatic carcinoma will target the pedicle. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Scintigraphic Examination
Planar scintigraphic evaluation is often used for surveillance and evaluation of patients with known malignancy. (Fig. 6-240) In these patients it is employed to assess diffuse or localized severe musculoskeletal pain of acute or chronic onset. Scintigraphy also aids in the correlation of positive laboratory findings (elevated alkaline phosphatase, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and follow-up of familial (hereditary multiple exostoses) or metabolic abnormalities involving the skeleton. (11) The radioangiogram and blood pool phase are frequently positive for active pathology and are, therefore, often helpful in determining the time frame of a pathophysiologic process.
Table 6-8 Clinical Indications for Skeletal Scintigraphy

Trauma

Occult fracture

Stress fracture /insufficiency

Bone bruise

Soft tissue injury

Active spondylolysis (acute)

Estimation of fracture age

Infection

Cellulitis

Osteomyelitis

Septic arthritis

Vascular

Infarction

Hyperemia

Osteonecrosis

Reflex sympathetic dystrophy

Neoplasm

Benign

Detection/recurrence

Malignant transformation

Malignant

Detection

Recurrence

Metastasis

Arthritis

Inflammatory (rheumatoid)

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

Metabolic

Paget’s disease

Fibrous dysplasia

Miscellaneous

Prosthesis

Loosening

Infection

Disease course

Advancement

Regression

Therapeutic response

Complications

Clinical features

Unresponsive to therapy

Other imaging normal
Three-Phase Bone Scan
Three-phase bone scanning techniques permit detection of radiographically occult musculoskeletal pathology, including shin splints, stress fractures, facet syndrome, spondylolysis, infection, osteonecrosis, and tumors. (Fig. 6-241) Skeletal scintigraphic techniques may also be employed to evaluate prostheses, bone grafts, complications of trauma or surgery, and tumor recurrence and post-therapeutic response. (12,13) (Fig. 6-242) In addition, overuse
P.648

or acute musculoskeletal injury may provoke an increase in the radiopharmaceutical uptake of muscles (rhabdomyolysis), tendons, bursae, and ligaments. Three-phase bone scanning techniques may also be used to assess vascular perfusion and the viability of soft tissues and to differentiate cellulitis from septic arthritis and osteomyelitis. (14) (Fig. 6-243)
Figure 6-240 METASTATIC CARCINOMA: WIDE-SPREAD DISEASE. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior (Left) and Posterior (Right) Whole Body. Observe the numerous areas of markedly increased tracer activity in the spine, ribs, pelvis, and proximal long bones. Urine contamination in the patient’s undergarments (arrow) is a frequent artifactual finding in elderly patients. COMMENT: This 72-year-old nonsmoker presented with chest pain and a known diagnosis of bronchogenic carcinoma. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-241 OSTEOMYELITIS OF THE ISCHIOPUBIC SYNCHONDROSIS: DIFFERENTIATION FROM NORMAL VARIANT. A. AP Pelvis. Note the focal lytic destruction involving the right ischiopubic synchondrosis (arrow). The contralateral side is normal (arrowhead). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Pelvis. Observe the diffusely increased radiotracer activity involving the right ischium (arrow). COMMENT: The normal developing ischiopubic synchondrosis was erroneously identified years ago by Van Neck as avascular necrosis. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
P.649

Figure 6-242 ACUTE CHEST PAIN: IATROGENIC FRACTURES. 99mTc-MDP Planar Bone Scan, Anterior Whole Body. This elderly patient received an extended period of aggressive chest compression during CPR. Note the numerous areas of radiotracer uptake within the anterolateral portions of all of the ribs and the distal sternum (arrow). These findings are consistent with iatrogenically induced fractures. (Courtesy of Michael A. Fox, MD, Memphis, Tennessee.)
The limited diagnostic specificity of radionuclide scintigraphy frequently requires a multimodality approach to imaging. In this regard scintigraphy parallels the application of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The elevated ESR, like an abnormal scintigram, is a sensitive indicator of disease, but requires correlative testing (additional laboratory work, radiography, CT scan) to provide specificity. (Fig. 6-244) The accuracy of MRI is competitive with scintigraphy across a wide range of diagnoses. (15,16) Unlike MRI, nuclear scintigraphy provides a whole-body evaluation, whereas MRI is a regional modality. It is likely that complementary roles for MRI and scintigraphy will continue to exist for many diagnostic questions.
Trauma
Acute or chronic trauma may result in the complete or incomplete disruption of bone and cartilage. Plain film radiography remains the initial diagnostic imaging modality in the trauma workup. If clinical concerns remain after equivocal or negative findings on the initial radiographs, radionuclide scintigraphy should be considered to assess the musculoskeletal system and exclude radiographically occult osseous and/or soft tissue injury. The increased blood flow associated with bone repair results in marked radiopharmaceutical accumulation. Nuclear scintigraphy plays an important role in the child-abuse workup, in the follow-up of traumatic complications such as fracture non-union, and in the assessment of tumor response to therapy. (17,18)
Occult fractures are not immediately apparent with plain film radiography but demonstrate an increased perfusion on the angiogram phase of the scintigraphic examination. In addition, there is increased radiotracer accumulation on the blood pool images and intense, poorly defined accumulation on the delayed images. (19) (Fig. 6-245)
Matin (20) outlined the scintigraphic presentation of fractures in their various phases after injury. The acute phase, lasting 3-4 weeks, produces increased flow activity, blood pool accumulation, and on a bone scan a broad intense zone of radiopharmaceutical uptake concentrating in the fracture line. Fractures, including those seen in the elderly, can be scintigraphically detected at initial presentation. Abnormal tracer uptake is observed within 24 hr of fracture in 95% of non-osteoporotic patients < 65 years of age. In patients > 65 years the site of injury may initially be scintigraphically normal, but it will exhibit abnormal radiotracer uptake within 72 hr in 95% of patients. (20)
The subacute phase of fracture, lasting 8-12 weeks, reveals a more diffuse persistent uptake with a focally intense area at the fracture line. In the chronic phase there is a progressive decline in the intensity of the abnormal radiotracer activity over 1-2 years, particularly in the weight-bearing bones (spine, femur, tibia). Following long-bone injury, scintigraphic activity returns to normal in 64% of patients at 1 year, 91% at 2 years, and 95% at 3 years. (21) Focal areas of abnormal radiopharmaceutical localization may persist as a result of chronic remodeling and degenerative repair.
Compression fractures of the spine reveal a horizontal band of increased tracer activity, typically affecting the superior endplate. (22) (Fig. 6-246) In one study scintigraphic activity in vertebral fractures normalized in 59% of patients within 1 year, 90% in 2 years, and 97% in 3 years. (23)
Stress Fracture
Stress fractures are classified as either fatigue or insufficiency injuries. These fractures differ in their affected patient populations and presenting clinical histories. The basic pathophysiology involved in these chronic injuries is, however, similar. Osteoclastic resorption, the initial event in the bone remodeling that occurs in response to repetitive loading, weakens the cortical bone. (24) Osteoblastic activity is subsequently initiated and bone remodeling follows. If the source of the stress is reduced, remodeling is successful and healing follows. If it is not, a complete fracture will evolve. Stimulation of the periosteum results in pain, but radiography in the early stages is frequently negative.
Stress remodeling or indeterminate stress lesions are indicated by abnormally increased activity on bone scans of patients who have been symptomatic between 4 and 8 weeks but have negative radiographs. Stress fractures may be scintigraphically difficult to differentiate from occult fractures or bone bruises. A thorough history and careful physical examination must be correlated with the scintigraphic findings.
P.650

Figure 6-243 OSTEOMYELITIS: PAINFUL HEEL. A. Lateral Calcaneus. Note the focal osteolytic area within the posteroinferior aspect of the calcaneus (arrow). In addition, there is increased density and irregularity of the calcaneal apophysis (normal variant) in this 12-year-old patient. B. Radionuclide Angiogram Phase, Calcaneus. Observe the hyperemia of the calcaneus in the involved foot (arrow). COMMENT: Normally there is intense physeal tracer activity in pediatric patients. Therefore, epiphyseal or metaphyseal diseases may be obscured by the normally increased uptake in these structures. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 6-244 FIBROUS DYSPLASIA: A GREAT IMITATOR. A. Bone Window CT, Axial Skull. Observe the subtle expansion of the right diploic space (arrow). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Note the focal increased tracer activity on the calvaria (arrow) corresponding to the site of the lesion on the CT image. COMMENT: This 37-year-old female complained of chronic headaches. Fibrous dysplasia may show mild radiotracer uptake or no uptake or may be cold. This appearance, when correlated with the plain films and clinical findings, should exclude metastatic disease. (Courtesy of Kort W. Harshman, DC, Springfield, Missouri.)
P.651

Figure 6-245 OCCULT STRESS FRACTURE: HIP PAIN IN A MARATHON RUNNER. A. AP Pelvis. Note that the radiograph is normal. B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior Pelvis. Observe the linear band of increased activity involving the left medial femoral neck, consistent with a stress fracture (arrow). COMMENT: This 31-year-old female runner presented with left hip pain. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-246 THORACIC SPINE COMPRESSION FRACTURE: HOT BONE SCAN. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Thoracic. Note the increased radionuclide activity at the T6 level (arrow), suggesting a recent injury. COMMENT: Compression fractures in the spine often result in increased tracer activity for as long as 1 year and occasionally up to 2 years. MRI, demonstrating bone marrow edema, is the most accurate and sensitive imaging modality in distinguishing the age of a compression fracture (old versus new). (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
The bone scan, however, becomes positive at approximately the same time symptoms of a stress fracture develop. Focal fusiform uptake within a long bone in the proper clinical setting is diagnostic of a stress fracture. (25) (Fig. 6-247) In addition, a diffuse increase in osseous activity is observed surrounding the stress fracture, which reflects the acceleration of osseous remodeling. Eventually, uptake becomes more focal and intense. Plain film radiographs usually reveal the stress fracture 2-12 weeks after its demonstration on the bone scan and 3-4 weeks after the onset of symptoms. (Fig. 6-248)
Figure 6-247 STRESS FRACTURE: LEG PAIN IN AN ADOLESCENT ATHLETE. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Bilateral Lower Extremity. Note the increased fusiform tracer activity in the right lateral tibia (arrow), consistent with a stress fracture. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.652

Figure 6-248 MULTIPLE STRESS FRACTURES: SYNCHRONOUS PRESENTATION. A. AP Femur. Observe the focal periostitis involving the medial diaphysis of the femur (arrows). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior Femur. Note two focal zones of increased activity, consistent with synchronous stress fractures of the femur (arrows). COMMENT: This athlete was evaluated for thigh pain. Stress fractures in the femoral diaphysis are rare. (Courtesy of Thomas E. Hyde, DC, DACBSP, North Miami, Florida.)
Figure 6-249 SACRAL INSUFFICIENCY FRACTURES: HONDA SIGN. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Pelvis. Observe the H-like pattern of tracer uptake in the sacrum. COMMENT: This elderly patient had severe pain in the region of the sacral base with a normal radiographic examination. Persistent lumbosacral pain in geriatric patients with osteoporosis and negative radiographs warrants consideration of radionuclide scintigraphy to exclude insufficiency fractures from a more sinister disease process, such as neoplasm.
Insufficiency fractures have been described in the lower extremities, sacrum, ilium, and pubis. Insufficiency fracture of the osteoporotic sacrum reveals a butterfly appearance on bone scan (Honda sign), with the alae of the sacrum and the sacral body representing the wings and trunk of the butterfly, respectively. (19) (Fig. 6-249) When plain film radiographs are normal, unexplained, intractable pain in the lumbosacral or sacroiliac region should prompt the consideration of radionuclide scanning. Subtle areas of marrow abnormality, however, can be normal on planar bone scans and demonstrate abnormal hyperintense signal intensity on T2-weighted or STIR MR images. (Fig. 6-250)
Radionuclide scintigraphy permits differentiation between stress fractures and shin splints or tibial stress syndrome (soleus syndrome). Shin splints produce pain and tenderness along the medial border of the tibia as a result of disruption of Sharpey’s fibers from the soleus muscle-tendon complex. (26) This periostitis produces an elongated linear pattern of activity in the posteromedial tibial cortex, in contrast to the more focal accumulation seen with stress fractures. (27) Scintigraphy is also of assistance in the diagnosis and management of active versus inactive spondylolysis in athletes. (Fig. 6-251) MRI studies of the pars may show bone marrow edema in active lesions in the radiographic or preradiographic phase of spondylolysis. (Fig. 6-252) (See Chapter 5.) Healing of this lesion is reflected by reduced tracer activity. (28) This information is beneficial for patient management and can guide the return to athletic training.
Bone Bruise
The presence of localized extremity pain after trauma, normal radiographs, and a small area of increased tracer accumulation on bone scans is consistent with a bone bruise. The bone bruise
P.653

does not display the fusiform appearance of stress fracture or linear pattern of shin splints but rather a focal area of ill-defined radiotracer uptake. (19) This injury is thought to lead to minimal intraosseous bleeding with periosteal elevation and repair. Additional causes have been suggested, including transient osteoporosis, focal reflex sympathetic dystrophy, and trabecular microfractures. (29) The abnormal radiopharmaceutical accumulation may represent evidence of increased bone turnover or remodeling. The pathophysiology and clinical significance of bone bruises remains to be established. (30) MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality in the detection of bone bruises.
Figure 6-250 HIDDEN TUMOR OR INSUFFICIENCY FRACTURE OF THE SACRUM? A. 99mTc-MDP Planar Bone Scan, AP Pelvis. Note the localized radiopharmaceutical uptake in the region of the left sacroiliac joint. B. T1-Weighted MRI, Coronal Sacrum. C. Gradient-Echo MRI, Coronal Sacrum. Note the diffuse low signal intensity within both the right and left portions of the sacrum. These areas become hyperintense on the gradient-echo images and are consistent with marrow edema adjacent to insufficiency fractures (arrows). COMMENT: This 77-year-old female presented with a history of mastectomy and long-standing lumbosacral pain that was treated conservatively with continued progression of symptoms. Plain films (not shown) were normal. The bilateral nature of this case on MRI shows the sensitivity of magnetic resonance versus bone scan, which demonstrated only unilateral abnormality. Elderly patients with chronic lumbosacral pain that is unresponsive to conservative management should be further evaluated to exclude insufficiency fractures of the sacrum. This patient was initially thought to have metastatic disease; biopsy of the sacrum proved to be representative of an insufficiency fracture. (Courtesy of Ian F. Murray, MD, and Dan K. Westmoreland, MD, Memphis, Tennessee.)
P.654

Figure 6-251 SPONDYLOLYTIC SPONDYLOLISTHESIS: NEGATIVE PLANAR BONE SCAN WITH POSITIVE SPECT. A. AP Lumbar Spine. B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note that the plain films reveal a 30% anterolisthesis of L4 on a transitional L5 segment. C. 99mTc-MDP Planar Bone Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Note that the planar bone scan is normal. D. SPECT, Coronal Lumbar Spine. E. SPECT, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the bilaterally increased tracer activity involving the L4 pars (arrows). This radiopharmaceutical uptake demands a reduction in physical activity, especially in extension, to reduce or eliminate the patient’s pain. A Boston overlap brace was prescribed. This 37-year-old female dancer presented with localized persistent low back pain. (Courtesy of Vastoni Deuksar, MD, and Alan M. Lesselroth, MD, Las Vegas, Nevada.)
P.655

Figure 6-252 PRERADIOGRAPHIC PHASE OF SPONDYLOLYSIS: A CHALLENGING CASE. A. 99mTc-MDP Planar Bone Scan, Posterior Spine. Note that the examination is normal. B. SPECT Scan, Coronal Lumbar Spine. C. SPECT Scan, Sagittal Lumbar Spine. Note the markedly increased activity in the L4 pars-pedicle junction bilaterally (arrows). D. T2-Weighted MRI, Far Lateral Sagittal Lumbar Spine (Right). E. T2-Weighted MRI, Far Lateral Sagittal Lumbar Spine (Left). Note the hyperintense signal in the pars-pedicle area, which is consistent with bone marrow edema (arrows).
P.656

Figure 6-252 (continued) F. T1- Weighted MRI, Axial L4. Note the decreased signal intensity areas in the posterior elements of the L4 vertebrae (arrows), consistent with bone marrow edema. COMMENT: This 16-year-old football player had back pain for 3 months with no radiographic evidence of spondylolysis in the lumbar spine on plain films (not shown). This patient was in the preradiographic phase of spondylolysis. His planar bone scan was normal, but SPECT was positive in the area of the L4 pars. The MRI reveals bone marrow edema, indicating the active nature of the pars lesion. The patient was placed in a custom-made Boston overlap brace in near zero lordosis. His deep-seated low back pain resolved after being braced for only 2 weeks. (See Chapter 5.) (Courtesy of Richard L. Green, DC, Boston, Massachusetts.)
Osteonecrosis
Osteonecrosis is the result of skeletal ischemia. The ischemic event can be related to trauma, such as fracture or dislocation, or to a wide range of pathologic states that disrupt the vascular supply of bone. These include collagen vascular diseases, corticosteroid use, radiation injury, alcoholism, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hemoglobinopathies, Gaucher’s disease, and Caisson’s disease. The hip is the most common site of involvement. (Fig. 6-253) Other common sites include the knee, shoulder, and carpal navicular. (Fig. 6-254) Osteonecrosis may be asymptomatic but is typically associated with acute aching pain that is often worse at night. (14)
In early osteonecrosis the radiographic examination is often normal. Nuclear scintigraphy may show decreased or absent uptake. Later, after the bone has become revascularized and begins to remodel, bony demineralization and spotty sclerosis are demonstrated radiographically, and increased radiotracer uptake is identified on the bone scan. If the necrotic process progresses, collapse, deformity, and flattening of the joint surface may become evident radiographically. This stage is characterized on the scintigram by a rim of increased radiopharmaceutical uptake surrounding a photopenic zone. This finding parallels the double line sign of osteonecrosis, a sign often observed with MRI. Finally, the typical plain film features of degenerative arthrosis become apparent. Bone scanning at this point reveals intense uptake on both sides of the articulation. The use of SPECT in the evaluation of osteonecrosis has greater sensitivity than conventional or planar imaging. (23)
CT may be helpful in evaluating the stages of osteonecrotic destruction. MRI, however, is the most sensitive means of early detection of osteonecrosis. (31)
Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy Syndrome (Sudeck’s Atrophy)
Reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome (RSDS) represents an exaggerated neurovascular response to traumatic or surgical injury and leads to severe pain, vasomotor instability, and trophic disturbances. The term sympathetically maintained pain syndrome has more recently been used to describe this condition. (19,32,33) RSDS produces a characteristic scintigraphic pattern consisting of diffuse increased uptake that is usually most pronounced in a periarticular location. (Fig. 6-255) The sensitivity and specificity for RSDS using radionuclide imaging varies by location. The sensitivity of the delayed image pattern in the hand is 96% and in the foot is 100%. Specificity in the foot has been reported at 80% and in the hand at 97%. (32)
Osteomyelitis
Although plain film radiography may be diagnostic for the evaluation of a suspected musculoskeletal infection, its sensitivity for
P.657

early disease is low. (34) The characteristic radiographic findings of early osteomyelitis require 1-3 weeks to develop. This radiographic latent (occult) period depends on location and is approximately 10 days in the extremities and 21 days in the spine. (Fig. 6-256) Frequently, co-existing disorders may mimic or duplicate both the clinical and radiographic features of osteomyelitis. Such disorders are particularly frequent in diabetic patients and consist of peripheral vascular disease, cellulitis, and neurotrophic arthropathy. (35) The failure to provide a prompt and accurate diagnosis of osteomyelitis will likely result in significant morbidity.
Figure 6-253 OSTEONECROSIS: A HIDDEN CAUSE OF HIP PAIN. A. AP Spot Hip. B. AP Tomogram Hip. Note that the plain films and tomograms are normal. C. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior Pelvis. Note the mildly increased radiotracer uptake within the left femoral head. This examination was erroneously read as normal. D. T1-Weighted MRI, Coronal Pelvis. Note the well-circumscribed zone of low signal intensity in the left femoral head (arrow), confirming the diagnosis of osteonecrosis. COMMENT: This 50-year-old female was involved in a motor vehicle accident 2 years earlier in which she sustained hip trauma. The most sensitive imaging modality for the assessment of osteonecrosis is MRI, which is the gold standard for detection of osteonecrosis. (Courtesy of Donald E. Freuden, DC, DABCO, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 6-254 SPONTANEOUS OSTEONECROSIS OF THE KNEE. A. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Bilateral AP Knee. Note the focal area of increased radiotracer uptake in the medial aspect of the right distal femur (arrow). COMMENT: Spontaneous osteonecrosis of the knee refers to idiopathic osteonecrosis that affects the medial femoral condyle in the adult. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.658

Figure 6-255 REFLEX SYMPATHETIC DYSTROPHY SYNDROME: SEVERE POST-TRAUMATIC FOOT PAIN. A. Angiogram Phase, 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Bilateral Dorsal Foot. Note the areas of increased radiotracer activity in the right foot (arrow). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Bilateral Plantar Foot. Observe that tracer activity is increased in the right hindfoot, midfoot, and proximal interphalangeal joint (arrows). These findings are consistent with the vasomotor instability seen with reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome. COMMENT: This patient sustained an ankle fracture and presented months later with residual progressive right foot pain. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Three-phase radionuclide scintigraphy allows evaluation of the vascular flow and uptake in soft tissues and is a sensitive means of identifying skeletal infections. (36) Accordingly, its sensitivity in the evaluation of osteomyelitis has been reported between 90% and 100%, with a specificity of 73-79%. (37) The addition of a fourth phase, provided by a static 24-hr image obtained with identical counts and settings, significantly increases the specificity. (38)
The positive scintigraphic findings in soft tissue infection consist of increased uptake on the radionuclide angiogram and blood pool phases and diffuse uptake on delayed images. Septic arthritis also produces findings of increased activity on the radionuclide angiogram and blood pool images but with marked periarticular uptake on the delayed images. (Fig. 6-257) If radionuclide scintigraphy is performed within 24-48 hr of the onset of symptoms, a cold spot or photopenic zone may result. This finding is seen only in the course of hematogenous osteomyelitis, particularly in children. It is caused by the localized occlusion of the capillary vasculature, which causes impedance of radiopharmaceutical access. Osteomyelitis in children may be multifocal and may mimic neoplasm, thus requiring a biopsy. (39) The differential diagnosis of osteomyelitis and septic arthritis may require additional radionuclide imaging with 67Ga-citrate or 111In-labeled WBCs. (Fig. 6-258) Diabetic patients, complex trauma victims, and postsurgical patients pose the greatest difficulty in the differentiation between osteomyelitis and septic arthritis. (36,40,41,42) Needle aspiration of the joint or open surgical biopsy may be the most expedient means of confirming the diagnosis.
The presence of increased activity on bone or joint images may also result from traumatic or inflammatory joint disorders such as seropositive arthritis (e.g., rheumatoid) and seronegative spondyloarthropathies (e.g., Reiter’s syndrome, psoriatic arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis). (14,43,44,45) (Fig. 6-259) (See Chapter 10.) The presence of these conditions is generally suspected on clinical grounds and confirmed by laboratory testing and radiographs. Radionuclide scintigraphy is employed only in special clinical circumstances.
67Ga-citrate has been employed in the localization of both infectious and inflammatory (aseptic) lesions. (Fig. 6-260) Like 99mTc-MDP, it is taken up by bone, but it also localizes in regions of infection. 67Ga displays high specificity for acute osteomyelitis because of its affinity for bacterial and cellular debris in addition to leukocytes. (8,46)
67Ga has proven valuable in the evaluation of young children with suspected osteomyelitis because of the high incidence of false-negative 99mTc-MDP bone scans. (37) It may be employed when the bone scan is inconclusive or demonstrates a photopenic area. The accuracy of combined bone-gallium imaging in evaluating osteomyelitis is not likely to be compromised by prior skeletal injury or other skeletal lesions. (47)
Chronic osteomyelitis may occasionally be exacerbated by a superimposed acute infection. When this occurs, it is necessary to distinguish the chronic process from the acute exacerbation. Plain film radiography lacks the necessary sensitivity required to accurately evaluate this complication. (36) Since bone turnover is present in both acute and chronic osteomyelitis, bone scintigraphy by itself is also ineffective in assessing chronic osteomyelitis. The resolution of this diagnostic dilemma rests in the combined use of 99mTc-MDP and 67Ga-citrate. (36) The acute infectious process reveals avid gallium uptake, exceeding the usual technetium uptake
P.659

seen with chronic osteomyelitis. Therefore a 67Ga pattern of skeletal distribution that does not coincide with the pattern of 99mTc-MDP suggests recurrent osteomyelitis. (48)
Figure 6-256 SEPTIC DISCITIS: LUMBAR SPINE. A. Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note that the examination appears normal. B. Lateral Lumbar Spine. The 2-week follow-up radiograph reveals destructive changes involving the inferior endplate of L5 (arrow). C. Tomography, Lateral Lumbar Spine. Note the enhanced visualization of the destructive changes and the narrowed disc space. D. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, AP (Left) and Lateral (Right) Lumbar Spine. Observe the diffusely increased tracer activity, corresponding to the lumbosacral junction (arrows). This pediatric patient had a 3-week history of fever and refused to bear weight. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Children’s Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
P.660

Figure 6-257 OSTEOMYELITIS: CHRONIC HEEL PAIN. A. Lateral Calcaneus. Observe the ill-defined osteolysis in the anterior calcaneus, surrounded by reactive sclerosis (arrow). These findings suggest chronic osteomyelitis (Brodie’s abscess). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Medial Right Foot. Note the marked tracer uptake involving the anterior calcaneus. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-258 ACUTE OSTEOMYELITIS: PERSISTENT ANKLE PAIN. A. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Bilateral Ankle. Note the focal increased tracer activity in the left ankle (arrow). B. 111In White Blood Cell Scan, Bilateral Ankle. Note the increased radiopharmaceutical activity in the left ankle (arrow). The combined findings of these examinations are consistent with osteomyelitis. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.661

Figure 6-259 INFECTIOUS SACROILIITIS: IV DRUG USER. Bone Scan, Posterior Pelvis. Note the focal area of increased uptake at the L5-S1 apophyseal joint (arrow). There is also markedly increased radiopharmaceutical activity involving the right sacroiliac joint (arrowhead). COMMENT: IV drug use predisposes the individual to infections in the S joints: sacroiliac, symphysis pubis, sternoclavicular, and spinal articulations. (Courtesy of Dawn E. Bedrosian, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 6-260 OSTEOMYELITIS: MONOARTHRITIS. A. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Note the marked radiopharmaceutical uptake at the right knee (arrow). The photopenic zone over the pelvis is the result of shielding (arrowhead) used to improve skeletal resolution by eliminating bladder counts. Note the increased activity in the left forearm, consistent with the injection site (crossed arrow). B. 67Ga Scan, Bilateral Anterior Knee. The 72-hr scan yields diffusely increased tracer activity involving the right knee, indicating an infectious disease process. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
The 111In leukocyte scan circumvents the osteogenic mechanism and traces the migration of WBCs into an inflammatory process. (Fig. 6-261) Epstein et al. (49) recommended 111In leukocyte imaging as the initial nuclear scan in the workup of active head and neck infections. 111In leukocyte imaging has a reported sensitivity of 90-95% in acute osteomyelitis, but this varies by location. In central skeletal locations, such as the spine, 53% sensitivity was reported. Chronic osteomyelitis results in a lower concentration of the labeled leukocytes in active bone marrow. This factor reduces the sensitivity for detection of chronic osteomyelitis in the axial skeleton. (50) The high radiation dose associated with 111In leukocyte imaging precludes its widespread use in pediatric evaluation for osteomyelitis.
Photopenia occurs in over half of the patients undergoing 111In-labeled leukocyte scans performed to rule out osteomyelitis in the spine. (51) This decreased uptake must be differentiated from other causes such as metastasis, Paget’s disease, surgical defects, radiation, fractures, and antibiotic therapy. The role of MRI in the evaluation of osteomyelitis is increasing because of its superb contrast resolution and sensitivity to bone marrow and soft tissue changes. (15)
P.662

Figure 6-261 SEPTIC ARTHRITIS: KNEE. A. Bone Scan, Bilateral Anterior Knee. Note the marked increase in tracer uptake on both sides of the knee joint, highly suggestive of septic arthritis. B. 111In White Blood Cell Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Radiotracer activity is increased in the region of the right knee (arrow), supporting the diagnosis of infection. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-262 HETEROTOPIC BONE: POSTOPERATIVE HIP PAIN. A. AP Right Hip. Note that a total hip prosthesis was implanted, with prominent heterotopic ossification bridging the ilium and femur (arrows). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior Pelvis. Note the increased activity associated with the heterotopic bone (arrows). Also note the bilateral photopenia of the femoral prostheses (arrowheads). (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.663

Prosthesis Evaluation
A differential diagnosis that includes septic loosening, aseptic loosening, heterotopic ossification, trochanteric bursitis, or fracture should be considered in patients with prior total hip arthroplasty and hip pain. (Fig. 6-262) Aseptic prosthetic loosening is the most frequent diagnosis in this clinical setting. Plain film radiographs are helpful in excluding fracture, heterotopic bone formation, and loosening of the bone-cement interface (52); however, plain films are unable to distinguish between aseptic and septic loosening. Distinction between these two causes of loosening is imperative because surgical intervention is necessary when infection is present but is not usually required with aseptic loosening. Radionuclide imaging techniques are widely used and have played an important role in the investigation of septic loosening (52), but needle aspiration of the joint or open surgical biopsy may be required.
Skeletal Neoplasms
Plain film radiography is the initial modality employed for the imaging of suspected skeletal neoplasms. Early detection of lytic skeletal tumors, however, is difficult because 30-50% demineralization must occur before the lesion is radiographically demonstrable. (53) Radionuclide scintigraphy is considerably more sensitive than plain film radiography in the detection and determination of the extent of a skeletal lesion. (40) Bone-seeking radiopharmaceuticals localize in skeletal lesions early in the pathologic process. Scintigraphic techniques are helpful for early benign and malignant tumor detection, and they have played a major role in the differential diagnosis, post-treatment assessment, and surveillance for tumor recurrence; but many of these applications have more recently been eclipsed by MRI.
Radionuclide skeletal scintigraphy is the most commonly performed nuclear imaging procedure in the United States for the diagnosis and follow-up of patients with malignant disease. Although imaging modalities such as CT and MRI are also used to assess soft tissue and bone tumors, the total-body survey capacity of radionuclide scintigraphy remains a significant advantage and is important in clinical staging.
Benign Skeletal Neoplasms.
Benign skeletal neoplasms are often incidentally detected on plain film radiographs or are noted with whole-body scintigraphy. No definitive scintigraphic criteria exist to distinguish benign from malignant neoplasms. Matin (18) suggested three parameters to help distinguish benign lesions of bone from those that are malignant. These non-specific parameters include lesion uptake, location, and the multiplicity of lesions. Many benign neoplasms may reveal mild to moderate radiotracer uptake. (23) These include non-ossifying fibromas, fibrous cortical defects, bone cysts, enchondromas, and stable osteochondromas. Benign lesions displaying marked uptake include osteoid osteoma, giant cell tumor, growing osteochondroma, bone cysts with pathologic fracture (e.g., simple bone cyst, aneurysmal bone cyst), fibrous dysplasia, Paget’s disease, and bone infarction. (54) (Fig. 6-263) Osteoid osteomas usually display a characteristic round focus of intense uptake. (55)
Primary Malignant Neoplasms.
Radionuclide scintigraphy has played a significant role in the diagnosis, staging, and follow-up of osseous and soft tissue neoplasms. Despite its limited specificity, a bone scan is a standard diagnostic test for the early diagnosis of malignant osseous involvement. Soft tissue sarcomas may involve the skeleton secondarily, resulting in abnormal scintigraphic activity locally or at distant osseous sites. (56,57)
Radionuclide scintigraphy may reveal evidence of soft tissue extension, paraneoplastic syndrome, or pulmonary or distant osseous metastases. (58,59) Primary malignant tumors of bone reveal their presence by the intense radiotracer uptake and increased activity on blood pool images. This is related to the neovascularity and hyperemia associated with the tumor. Radionuclide scintigraphy does not, however, sufficiently define the extent of the primary tumor for surgical planning. The neovascularity and reactive bone changes typically obscure and overstate the lesion’s borders. MRI and CT play significant roles in further characterizing the extent of the lesion within bone and adjacent soft tissues. (8) Scintigraphy is helpful when metastasis from a primary osseous neoplasm is suspected in a distal skeletal location.
Multiple Myeloma.
Nuclear scintigraphy should not be performed in an attempt to initially diagnose or to determine the extent to which a patient is affected by multiple myeloma. A radiographic skeletal survey is more useful and accurate. Scintigraphy is recommended only as a baseline examination in the assessment of fracture activity (age of lesion). Multiple myeloma stimulates the production of an osteoclast activating factor (OAF). This enhances osteoclastic activity, causing bone destruction to occur at a much greater rate than the reactive osteoblastic activity. This results in a normal scintigram until the lesion is large enough to be identified as an area of photon deficiency. (Fig. 6-264) Photopenic areas (cold spots) may also be seen in aggressively lytic neoplasms, such as the bubbly metastases of renal cell and thyroid carcinoma as well as neuroblastoma. (53) These highly aggressive lesions lack significant reparative osteoblastic response to counteract the lysis, resulting in a reduced radiopharmaceutical concentration.
Figure 6-263 PAGET’S DISEASE: SCAPULA AND OCCIPUT. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Cervicothoracic Spot. Note that the entire left scapula is outlined by increased tracer activity. Incidentally, diffuse uptake is noted in the posterior occiput. COMMENT: Paget’s disease is one cause of generalized increased calvarial thickness. (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, Deaconess West Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri.)
P.664

Figure 6-264 MULTIPLE MYELOMA: NEGATIVE BONE SCAN. A. AP Hip. B. Lateral Frog-Leg Hip. Observe the radiolucent appearance (arrows) and subtle endosteal scalloping (arrowhead) of the proximal femoral metaphysis. C. Lateral Skull. Note that the skull has multiple punched-out lesions. D. Soft Tissue Window CT, Axial Hip. Note the thinning of the femoral cortex (arrow) and the tumor-filled marrow. E. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Skull. F. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior Pelvis. Observe that both the skull and the pelvis are unremarkable. COMMENT: This 76-year-old female complained of left hip pain. Bone scans are classically false-negative in multiple myeloma because lesions do not typically provoke an osteoblastic reparative response. (Courtesy of William E. Litterer, DC, DACBR, Fellow, ACCR, Elizabeth, New Jersey.)
P.665

Skeletal Metastasis.
The extremely high sensitivity (95-97%) of skeletal scintigraphy and the ability to image the entire skeleton in a single examination have made it the imaging procedure of choice for the detection of osseous metastatic carcinoma. (8) It often provides the initial evidence of bone metastasis from a carcinoma because lesions may otherwise remain undetected radiographically for months or years. Bone scans are also frequently used for baseline evaluation in initial staging, for monitoring the response to treatment for both chemotherapy and radiotherapy, and in the detection of complications such as pathologic fracture and osteonecrosis. (16) However, MRI is equally as sensitive and more specific than bone scan in detecting metastases. Unfortunately whole-body MRI as a staging survey is under investigation.
The typical scintigraphic pattern of metastatic carcinoma displays diffuse multifocal lesions randomly scattered throughout the axial skeleton. (Fig. 6-265) The differential diagnosis includes fracture, Paget’s disease, osteomyelitis, metabolic bone disease, and occasionally osteoarthritis. (54) Osteoarthritis is a frequent cause of multiple focal lesions on a radionuclide scintigram. These lesions usually demonstrate a less-intense area of tracer uptake than metastasis, but occasionally they may be large enough to obscure an adjacent area of malignancy. This is particularly problematic in the vertebral column, where apophyseal arthrosis and spondylosis provoke significant tracer uptake. This circumstance warrants the use of SPECT for more accurate localization of the abnormal uptake. (5) The presence of acute or even antecedent trauma involving the ribs is also a clinical challenge. Rib fractures arising from a traumatic event typically demonstrate a linear scintigraphic pattern. This non-random or linear pattern virtually excludes metastatic disease, which displays a random distribution of tracer activity. (60) (Fig. 6-266)
Figure 6-265 METASTATIC CARCINOMA: HISTORY OF BREAST CANCER. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior (Left) and Posterior (Right) Whole Body. Observe the numerous foci of increased tracer activity in the axial skeleton, which are the result of metastatic malignancy. The patient was catheterized and the bladder was emptied to increase the image quality. Note the urine-filled bag (arrow) and empty bladder on the posterior scan. COMMENT: This 34-year-old female presented with severe back pain. She underwent a previous mastectomy for breast carcinoma but denied radiation and chemotherapy. Two serial 6-month bone scans were negative. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Paget’s disease is often an incidental finding and can usually be differentiated from metastasis by correlation with plain film radiographs and/or the distribution of the involved bones. (Figs. 6-267 and 6-268) (See Chapter 11.) When there is a solitary site of tracer uptake on a radionuclide scintigram in a patient with a known primary malignancy, it is generally considered to be metastatic disease until proven otherwise. In a patient with a known primary neoplasm, the probability of a focal hot spot in the axial skeleton or proximal extremities being indicative of metastatic disease is quite high. When the identical circumstance arises in the skull or distal extremities (elbow to hand, knee to foot), this percentage is reduced to < 50%. (54) Solitary rib lesions are far less likely to be metastatic disease than multiple lesions. Tumeh et al. (61) found only 10% of solitary rib lesions to be metastatic; myeloma was more common. Plain film radiographic correlation is mandatory when scintigraphy reveals a solitary lesion in a patient with a known malignancy. Negative or equivocal plain film radiography, in this circumstance, requires confirmation by CT, MRI, or biopsy.
Diffuse, widespread metastatic disease may present with an intense scintigraphic pattern known as the super scan. (23) This diffuse and relatively uniform activity throughout the axial skeleton may simulate a normal bone scan; however, because of the increased skeletal accumulation of tracer, there is minimal or absent renal activity. In addition, there is an unusually high bone to soft
P.666

tissue background ratio with an increased ratio of uptake in the axial versus appendicular skeleton. Radiographic correlation is another means of avoiding this catastrophic pitfall. Diffuse osseous metastases producing the super scan most often arise from malignant primary neoplasms in the breast and prostate.
Figure 6-266 METASTATIC CARCINOMA: PROGRESSIVE LOW BACK PAIN. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior (Left) and Posterior (Right) Whole Body. Note the widespread sites of markedly increased tracer activity, consistent with skeletal metastasis. A urine-filled bag from a draining catheter is noted inferior to the pelvis (arrows). This elderly male had a history of treated small cell carcinoma of the lung and presented with low back pain. (Courtesy of Timothy Schneider, DC, St. Louis, Missouri.)
Figure 6-267 PAGET’S DISEASE. A. AP Pelvis. Note the characteristic cotton wool appearance of pagetic bone and obliteration of Köhler’s teardrop (arrow), one of the first signs of Paget’s disease affecting the pelvic brim. B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Anterior Whole Body. Observe the increased activity in the right ilium (arrow). The linear pattern of increased activity on the anterior ribs (arrowheads) and at the tip of the sternum (crossed arrow) is consistent with recent fracture repair. C. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Note the increased activity occupying nearly the entire right hemipelvis (arrow) as a result of Paget’s disease. Abnormal increased activity over the calvaria is also noted. COMMENT: The linear pattern of rib fractures present in this case helps differentiate it from metastatic disease, which usually displays a non-linear (random) pattern of increased radiotracer activity. (Courtesy of Dawn E. Bedrosian, MD, Denver, Colorado.)
Figure 6-268 PAGET’S DISEASE: UNUSUAL BONE SCAN. A. Lateral Skull. Note the linear zone of radiolucency traversing the calvaria (osteoporosis circumscripta) (arrows). B. 99mTc-MDP Bone Scan, Posterior Whole Body. Observe the band of increased tracer activity traversing the calvaria, consistent with the advancing edge of the lytic phase of Paget’s disease (arrow). An additional area of abnormal uptake is seen at the skull base (arrowhead). (Courtesy of Department of Radiology, University Hospital, Denver, Colorado.)
P.667

Healing metastatic lesions in bone increase the radiotracer accumulation in response to reactive new bone formation. This is known as the flare phenomenon. (62) With the administration of chemotherapy, the bone scan may appear to worsen or flare, suggesting increased metabolic activity. The flare phenomenon occurs in patients undergoing cyclic chemotherapy and actually represents a favorable response to treatment. Radiographic correlation with evidence of increased sclerosis may be present within 2-6 months. With progressive healing the flare phenomenon will decrease over time. Serial examinations may be necessary to confirm the flare phenomenon and differentiate this appearance from progressive disease, which demonstrates increased, rather than decreased, tracer activity with time.
Metastatic deposits may be so aggressive that they completely replace areas of the skeleton, producing photon-deficient lesions or cold spots similar to those seen with myeloma. An area with little or no tracer uptake, often surrounded by a rim of increased uptake, may indicate a cold metastatic lesion. In addition, early metastatic invasion may not stimulate reactive bone formation, resulting in a false-negative radionuclide scan. (40)
Figure 6-269 PET SCANNER. A. Typical Pet Scanner. The patient couch and gantry are shown. Superficially, this appears much like the typical hardware of a CT scanner. B. PET Brain Scan. Observe the abnormal uptake within the brain resulting from a high-grade brain neoplasm (arrow). This examination was performed using 18F-fluorodeoxyuridine. (Panel A courtesy of Siemens Medical Systems, Inc., New York, New York.)
Osseous metastasis from breast carcinoma often presents as a solitary lesion. When such a scintigraphic lesion is observed in the sternum, there is a high probability that metastatic disease exists. (63) The recurrence of breast cancer is usually first identified in the skeleton, frequently in the thoracic spine.
Prostatic carcinoma is the most common malignancy among men in the United States. The advent of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing has provided a sensitive means of detection in patients who are at high risk for prostate cancer. Radionuclide scintigraphy should be employed in patients in whom the PSA is elevated, in those who display the appropriate symptomatology, and in those who have been hormonally treated. In patients with proven prostate carcinoma, bone scanning also plays a role in prognosis. It determines whether bone metastasis has occurred and to what extent the skeleton is involved. (54)
In bronchogenic carcinoma, osseous metastases may develop from direct extension or via hematogenous routes. A positive radionuclide bone scan is a poor prognostic sign in patients with bronchogenic carcinoma. (53) Metastatic carcinoma beyond the elbow or knee (acral metastasis) is unusual, with the exception of aggressive bronchogenic carcinoma. On occasion, it may be isolated
P.668

to the hands or feet, presenting radiographically as a blow-out lesion. (64)
POSITRON EMISSION TOMOGRAPHY
PET is a technique in nuclear medicine that also provides a tomographic format for biochemical and physiologic imaging. PET has been used in the assessment of brain activation mapping and cardiac perfusion and is emerging as a powerful imaging tool in oncologic applications. (1,2) PET has also been shown to be superior to some standard imaging techniques in nuclear medicine. Its major disadvantages include its higher cost (two or three times the cost of a planar bone scan) and significant technical challenges. Advances in these areas could lead to the development of less expensive systems and expand the role of PET imaging in nuclear medicine.
PET scanners require radiopharmaceuticals that emit positrons. A positron is a positively charged electron (antimatter) that instantly collides with an electron, annihilating both particles. This high-energy collision emits two oppositely directed γ-rays. The radiation is measured by rings of detectors encircling the patient. The geometrically placed detectors record coincident radiation counts and, like SPECT, display them in a tomographic plane. (Fig. 6-269) The resolution of modern PET scanners is about 3 mm, which is superior to both planar and SPECT imaging. (3)
PET imaging involves technical issues of immense complexity. The half-life of these agents (seconds to minutes) is so short that a cyclotron must be maintained on site for their production. This is one factor that accounts for the high cost of PET imaging. A significant barrier is also imposed by the limited reimbursement of PET examinations, since the majority are classified as investigational. Recently, the diagnosis and staging of lung cancer with PET has been approved for reimbursement by Medicare as it differentiates benign from malignant nodules with higher sensitivity than CT.
The clinical applications of PET imaging in the musculoskeletal system have focused on the evaluation of bone and soft tissue tumors and are currently investigational. (1) The most common radiopharmaceutical in this application is fluorine-18-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG). Imaging with FDG provides information concerning the distribution and magnitude of glucose metabolism. It is this metabolic basis of PET imaging that distinguishes it from other imaging techniques. In preliminary trials, significantly increased tracer uptake was seen in high-grade malignant soft tissue lesions, thus allowing differentiation from low-grade and benign neoplasms. It is likely that PET will have an increased effect on nuclear imaging, particularly in oncologic application, despite the cost and technical challenges. (2)
Medicolegal Implications
NUCLEAR MEDICINE
  • Caution should be exercised when using nuclear medicine, as with any modality that uses ionizing radiation.
  • Overuse and inappropriate use should be avoided.
  • Use in children, during pregnancy, and during breastfeeding should occur only when absolutely necessary.
  • Dehydration is a direct contraindication.
  • Radiopharmaceutical injection should be performed before dialysis.
